Title: Acer Swift 3 review: Better as a budget device than as a mid-range laptop
Summary: Our $899 review unit isn't very different from its $479 counterpart.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Includes USB-A ports and an HDMI port
Cons: 16:9 aspect ratio
Product Name: Acer Swift 3
Verdict: So while the Acer Swift 3 doesn't have any glaring imperfections, it doesn't provide as much value as other laptops in or near its price range. Many of the necessary features are there on paper—metal body, fingerprint sensor, USB-C along with USB-A, decent battery life, and more—but the Swift 3 doesn't push those features quite as far as I need them to go to recommend it in the $899 configuration that I tested. When I can get more for my money, I almost always will do so, and there are other laptops that give you more for the same price.

Title: Garmin Venu review: Fitness expertise with many pixels left to fill
Summary: Garmin dives into AMOLED with this $399 smartwatch, but the execution is shallow.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Bold and bright AMOLED display.
Cons: Only one case size.
Product Name: Garmin Venu
Verdict: However, I do believe Garmin can make its software more AMOLED-friendly by using more exciting graphics and animations while also maintaining the stellar battery life that the Venu currently has. Garmin wearables may never be as intuitive as Apple's or Samsung's because they aren't as closely tied to a smartphone OS, but the company can certainly make the experience of using a $399 smartwatch feel more appropriate. If users can get the exact same software experience on a $350 device as they can on a $399 device, most users (who are not display sticklers) will likely choose the more affordable option.

Title: HP Elitebook x360 1040 G5 review: A little bit bigger, a little bit better
Summary: It's similar to HP's 13-inch convertible, but extra screen space makes a difference.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Relatively compact design, even with its 14-inch display
Cons: No microSD card slot
Product Name: HP Elitebook x360 1040 G5
Verdict: But there are some things that HP just can't replicate, like Lenovo's superb typing experience on its ThinkPad X1 family. Some business customers also favor ThinkPads' nondescript design, and you won't get that in an HP business notebook in the same class. But the new Elitebooks are formidable opponents for Lenovo's business notebooks, and customers shouldn't overlook the middle child in the Elitebook x360 family. It's definitely worth the extra cost if you enjoy having a relatively large screen in a small convertible, but those who aren't as picky about screen real estate can opt for the slightly less expensive 13-inch model.

Title: HP Spectre x360 13 review: A high-end two-in-one that’s hard to beat
Summary: There wasn't a lot to fix, so HP added a few features to make this convertible even better.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Camera kill switch and mic-mute button.
Cons: Both Thunderbolt 3 charging ports are on the same side.
Product Name: HP Spectre x360 13
Verdict: Most of my issues with the new Spectre x360 13 are small—the hoarded Thunderbolt 3 ports, the small arrow keys, and the narrow trackpad. Aside from the screen's aspect ratio, I'm most disappointed that the new laptop doesn't last as long as the previous model (20 hours versus a whopping 30.5 hours, respectively, on our Wi-Fi test). But the new Spectre x360 13 still manages to have a battery life that beats out all of the competition, so the reality isn't

Title: Samsung Galaxy S20 vs. iPhone 11 Pro: A deeper division lurks beneath the spec sheets
Summary: There are more important concerns for buyers than feature lists.
Author: Samuel Axon
Product Name: Samsung Galaxy S20 vs. iPhone 11 Pro: A deeper division lurks beneath the spec sheets
Verdict: That doesn't mean it's acceptable to be mean or toxic about these differences. It's important to have productive discussions about the issues at hand. But debates comparing the new Galaxy phone to the latest iPhone ultimately aren't really about the megapixels, and we all know it.

Verdict: Dual LTE connectivity makes the Swift 7 unique, and those who are most intrigued by that feature may want to consider the Swift 7 seriously. However, there are other devices that can be equipped with LTE, namely the forthcoming HP Spectre x360 13 that starts at $1,149, so the combination of thin-and-light and always connected can be found elsewhere. Others who don't absolutely need the thinnest laptop ever should consider more affordable and more powerful options like the

Title: OK Computer: The iPad Pro 2020 review
Summary: Pointer support and an AR sensor come to the iPad.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: It's the world's best tablet for power users, full stop
Cons: App support for all this power and these new features still isn't there
Product Name: OK Computer: The iPad Pro 2020 review
Verdict: I'm not sure even Steve Jobs saw where that puck was headed.

Title: HP Elite Dragonfly review: Luxurious, professional, expensive
Summary: This is a whole new look for the Elitebook line, and it starts at $1,549.

Cons: 16:9 display aspect ratio.

Verdict: Regardless, the HP Elite Dragonfly is an impressively portable and powerful machine, but it's also pricey. Comparable

Title: Pixelbook Go review: A cheaper Pixelbook does not come without compromises
Summary: Keeping costs low means eliminating some features from Google's new $649 Chromebook.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Thin-and-light, minimalist design.
Cons: Glare-filled screen.
Product Name: Pixelbook Go
Verdict: That competition won't matter to Google hardware enthusiasts, but it's certainly important to Chrome OS enthusiasts looking for the best device for their needs and budgets. And after using the Pixelbook Go for nearly a week, I found myself wishing for a Pixelbook 2.0—I wish Google had come out with two new devices this year: the $649 Pixelbook Go with only two configurations (Core m3 and Core i5) and an updated Pixelbook priced at $999 or more with all of the things we loved about the original, plus new features and internals. Maybe we'll get that in the future, but for now, those considering the Pixelbook Go should only look closely at the two most affordable options. Otherwise, look to the original Pixelbook if you're ready to drop $999 or more on a Google-made Chromebook.

Title: 2019 16-inch MacBook Pro review: Bye-bye, butterfly
Summary: Apple’s new laptop seems designed to address three years of user complaints.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Better video performance than the MacBook Pro has recently been known for
Cons: No Wi-Fi 6
Product Name: 2019 16-inch MacBook Pro
Verdict: The Mac is still not for everybody, and it likely never again will be. But the 2019 16-inch MacBook Pro is now a better fit for the users Apple has been trying to reach. Bye bye butterfly; hello faster render times.

Title: The 2019 iPad races to the bottom (price-wise), but it’s not so bad down there
Summary: Apple's new entry-level tablet delivers the basics, and that will be enough for some.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Affordable pricing for a tablet of this quality
Cons: Notably slower performance for games and creative applications than the rest of Apple's 2019 mobile and tablet lineup
Product Name: The 2019 iPad races to the bottom (price-wise), but it’s not so bad down there
Verdict: I still believe the iPad Air is the best choice for most people who can afford it, but for kids or for organizations or individuals who have to pinch those pennies and only need the basics, the seventh-generation iPad is still worth considering. It gives you the majority of what's good about the iPad at a significantly lower price point. Just be ready to spend a lot more on that Smart Keyboard if you plan to try to get work done.

Title: iPadOS review: The iPad is dead, long live the iPad
Summary: Step by step, Apple is taking the iPad in a wholly new direction.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Safari now shows desktop versions of websites by default, and it does a better job of making them work well on the iPad
Cons: The home screen improvements don't go far enough to reinvent a very dated and often frustrating implementation
Product Name: iPadOS
Verdict: In any case, Cupertino's efforts to respond to long-time user feedback herald a very interesting new chapter for the Apple ecosystem. And doing serious work on a true tablet has never been easier.

Title: Fitbit Inspire HR review: A worthy $99 investment in your health
Summary: Fitbit packed many essentials into its $99 replacement for the Alta HR.

Cons: Limited number of watch faces.
Product Name: Fitbit Inspire HR

Title: Huawei Matebook 13 review: A cheaper Matebook X Pro with killer performance
Summary: This $1,299 laptop is stiff competition for Huawei's own $1,499 Matebook X Pro.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Minimalist yet sturdy design.
Cons: No Thunderbolt 3.
Product Name: Huawei Matebook 13
Verdict: Nevertheless, I question why most would even consider the Matebook X Pro when the Matebook 13 now exists. Will users be willing to spend around $300 more for Thunderbolt 3, killer battery life, and a larger, higher-resolution screen? Especially when that does

Summary: Ars tests out the biggest flagship laptops to see which are worth your money.
Author: Valentina Palladino

Title: Mini-review: Fitbit’s Versa Lite favors affordability over unnecessary features
Summary: If the original Versa was overkill for you, the Versa Lite may be a better option.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Lightweight, attractive design with interchangeable bands
Cons: No altimeter
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: But if you can live without those features, spending $160 on the Versa Lite is a worthwhile decision. It will appeal to those who want to stick to a strict budget, and that's something that not many other smartwatches do. However, if you can afford the regular $200 Versa, I think it's the better device if for nothing else than its more reliable battery life and the inclusion of an altimeter.

Title: XPS 13 2019 review: One small move made Dell’s best laptop even better
Summary: Key fixes in this year's model mean the $899 XPS 13 has few things holding it back.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Compact, attractive design with large screen area.
Cons: 16:9 aspect ratio will bother some.
Verdict: The biggest drawbacks to the XPS 13 are common among Ultrabooks available today: limited USB-A ports (or in this case, none) and noisy fans. Dell would have had to make the notebook thicker to fix the former and sacrifice power and thermal management to fix the latter. Those tradeoffs would have resulted in a very different notebook—I think Dell made the right choices with the new XPS 13 laptop.

Title: 2018 iPad Pro review: “What’s a computer?”
Summary: The iPad Pro raises the bar for performance, but has too many other limitations.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Astonishing performance for a tablet, pushing up against many powerful laptops
Cons: It doesn’t support external storage over USB-C, and has many other limitations like that
Product Name: 2018 iPad Pro
Verdict: Until all those maybes become reality, the rest of us will still be waiting. And it really is too bad, because the potential is already there.

Title: Withings Pulse HR review: A longer-lasting competitor to Fitbit’s Alta HR
Summary: A 20-day battery life defines this unassuming, $129 tracker.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Water-resistant, stainless-steel design.
Cons: Tap-only OLED display is very small and often unresponsive.
Product Name: Withings Pulse HR
Verdict: For that reason (and the somewhat lackluster nature of the Health Mate app), the $99 Alta HR remains my top fitness tracker for most users. However, the Pulse HR is a great option for those who want to rarely take off their fitness band and those who value connected GPS more than the smartwatch features that other manufacturers are now trying to squeeze into their hybrid trackers.

Title: Pixel Slate review: Paying the “Google” premium for Chrome OS
Summary: Starting at $599, the overpriced tablet showcases Chrome OS' promising tablet future.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Sturdy, minimalist tablet design.
Cons: No Thunderbolt 3 ports.
Product Name: Pixel Slate
Verdict: But if you can live without a fingerprint sensor and that cute little "G" on the slab's back corner, HP's Chromebook x2 provides comparable performance and includes a keyboard and stylus in its $599 price tag. It may not be made by Google, but it's still a better value Chrome OS tablet.

Title: Huawei Watch GT review: When hardware and software don’t mesh
Summary: Huawei's wearable OS could be great, but it doesn't fit this $230 smartwatch.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Striking AMOLED display.
Cons: Generic design.
Product Name: Huawei Watch GT
Verdict: Overall, the Watch GT is a solid smartwatch, and LiteOS is a decent, lightweight operating system to power smartwatches. But the two don't jive together. I don't think Huawei should overhaul LiteOS entirely, but rather a few changes to the Watch GT would make it a more suitable device for the company's OS. Huawei should ditch most of the premium components, sacrifice a bit in the quality of the AMOLED display, introduce a smaller case size, and maybe even remove the onboard GPS and add a connected GPS feature. Such a device would be a better match for LiteOS, and it likely wouldn't cost $230 either.

Title: Lenovo Thinkbook 13s review: ThinkPad influences at a great price
Summary: Almost anyone can appreciate this solid Windows laptop that starts at under $750.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Modern, professional design
Cons: No IR camera
Product Name: Lenovo Thinkbook 13s
Verdict: The biggest competition for the Thinkbook 13s is HP's Envy 13 laptop. Both are great machines, but you can currently get the Envy 13 with a Core i7 processor, 8GB of RAM, and 256GB SSD for $749. The Envy 13 is the device to get if you like a flashier laptop, but the Thinkbook 13s is a solid alternative for those who prefer professional, utilitarian design and privacy features above all else.

Title: iPad Air and iPad mini 2019 review: Apple’s tablets strike an ideal balance
Summary: These are clearly more appealing to most people than Apple's 2018 iPad or iPad Pro.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Exceptional CPU performance in both tablets
Cons: First-generation Apple Pencil support is good, but second-generation would have been a lot better
Product Name: iPad Air and iPad mini 2019
Verdict: For everyone else, these small refinements make for the most easy-to-recommend true tablet solutions on the market apart from maybe aftermarket 2017 iPad Pros—especially this new Air.

Title: Blackmagic eGPU Pro mini-review: Quiet, fast, and extremely expensive—like a Mac
Summary: The higher-end cousin to Blackmagic's first Mac eGPU delivers where it counts.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Significantly more graphics power than you'll get in any Mac laptop's configurable options, and plenty for most professional applications and games
Cons: There's still no easy way to use an eGPU like this in Boot Camp on any Mac except the Mac mini
Product Name: Blackmagic eGPU Pro mini-
Verdict: If you're of that mind, we can recommend this admittedly pricy graphics solution. But as is the case with Macs themselves, you can get more power for less if you don't need a workstation-class GPU and you're willing to sacrifice those minimalist priorities.

Title: HP Spectre 15 x360 2019 review: Carving a niche in a crowded space
Summary: The "gem-cut" design isn't for everybody, but it sure is striking.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Good graphics performance.
Cons: I'm not a fan of the eye-catching design; personally, I find it gaudy. But that's subjective, and someone else might love it.
Product Name: HP Spectre 15 x360 2019
Verdict: So no, this device is not perfect. But it's nice to see OEMs like HP trying new things, and some of them (like the webcam switch and the port placement) are wins in our book. The Spectre 15 x360 isn't for everybody, but it carves its own earned niche into the crowded 15-inch two-in-one space.

Title: 15-inch MacBook Pro mini-review: How much does Apple’s fastest laptop offer?
Summary: We tested it decked-out with an 8-core Core i9 CPU and Vega 20 graphics.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Very strong graphics performance for this form factor
Cons: It's extremely expensive, treading well into professional-use-only territory
Product Name: 15-inch MacBook Pro mini-
Verdict: Is that a recommendation? I think so. But it's a recommendation to an ever-smaller group of people, and Apple seems to be cool with that. At least with this spec, the "Pro" moniker is a lot harder to dispute.

Title: Dell Inspiron 13 7000 review: Premium and practical all in one
Summary: Dell gives this Inspiron 2-in-1 a glow-up without sacrificing power or features.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Subtle yet professional design.
Cons: Fans can get loud.
Product Name: Dell Inspiron 13 7000
Verdict: That being said, affordability factors in with this machine as well: the Inspiron 13 7000 Black Edition that we tested ($1,420.99) comes in about $300 less than the XPS 13 laptop that we tested ($1,709.99). There will always be some people who want the top-of-the-line product, and the XPS remains at the head of Dell's ultraportable lineup. However, that's not the only option if you want a high-quality machine with a lot of power as well as a lot of capabilities that aren't hindered by design or the latest laptop trends. Those looking for a great value for your money should consider the Inspiron 7000 series, especially the new Black Edition convertible.

Title: ThinkPad X1 Carbon 7th-gen mini-review: Minor updates made to a stellar machine
Summary: Lenovo promised 18 hours of battery life, and it delivered with this $1,462 notebook.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Thinner, lighter design with MIL-SPEC durability
Cons: IR camera is optional and cannot be paired with shuttered webcam
Product Name: ThinkPad X1 Carbon 7th-gen mini-
Verdict: Those who want the fastest and most up-to-date X1 Carbon should wait for the models with 10th-generation Intel CPUs to come out in the next few weeks. Just keep in mind that those new models only differ from the seventh-gen in CPU—the same hardware improvements exist on both models. If you can live with an older (yet still speedy) processor, the seventh-generation X1 Carbon is just as solid of a laptop as its predecessors, and it's made better by an updated design, good performance, and a killer battery life.

Title: Apple Watch Series 5 review: A better, more independent timepiece
Summary: An always-on display finally comes to the Apple Watch, but watchOS 6 steals the show.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Solid build quality and design.
Cons: Activity Trends isn't as detailed as it should be.
Product Name: Apple Watch Series 5
Verdict: You'll likely always need an iPhone to use an Apple Watch, but with every update it continues to get easier to leave that iPhone behind and remain connected to the most important aspects of your digital life by using the Apple Watch.

Title: iPhone 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max review: High quality for high prices
Summary: Apple’s new flagship shows the X-series iPhones have matured.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: You’ll get greatly improved battery life over your current iPhone
Cons: Even with improvements to the glass, it’s still awfully fragile for something so expensive
Product Name: iPhone 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max
Verdict: In the event that money is no concern, though, buy the iPhone 11 Pro or iPhone 11 Pro Max—it's an outstanding handset, and you absolutely get what you pay for. Just, maybe get AppleCare+, too. And you might want some AirPods as well. This is adding up quickly, isn't it? That's probably by design—and Apple remains a leader in design.

Title: iPhone 11 review: The most attractive choice in Apple’s best lineup in years
Summary: It's only a slight update to the iPhone XR, but it's the best iPhone for most.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: It's a little cheaper than last year's XR, but it offers all the same features and more
Cons: It's made of fragile glass and can generally only be repaired by Apple at great expense (unless you buy AppleCare+)
Product Name: iPhone 11
Verdict: If you're looking to live in Apple's mobile ecosystem, but you don't care about bleeding-edge OLED displays or attention-grabbing designs and premium materials, this is the way to go. Like the iPhone XR last year, we're giving it the Ars Approved badge and recommending it as the iPhone to buy for most people. Just be ready to spend a little more than the price of the phone on extras like AppleCare+, protective cases, or AirPods if you want the best experience.

Title: iPhone XR review: Keeping compromises to a minimum
Summary: Apple’s slightly cheaper handset is the best new iPhone for most people.
Author: Samuel Axon
Pros: Powerful CPU, GPU, and machine learning chips give this phone the same industry-beating performance we measured in the XS.
Cons: The screen’s pixel density is not optimal, and Apple’s OLED implementation offers many advantages you’ll be missing out on here as compared to the XS phones.
Product Name: iPhone XR
Verdict: But even if it’s not the entry-level handset some might want, the iPhone XR at least brings most of the benefits of the iPhone X-series phones to consumers who aren’t too keen on raising the bar on the cost of a flagship. For that reason, it's the iPhone we'd recommend to most people.

Title: Dell XPS 13 two-in-one review: Lots to flex, few weaknesses
Summary: The XPS 13 many have been waiting for, but it may not be the two-in-one for everyone.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Well-designed, attractive body.
Cons: No IR camera.
Product Name: Dell XPS 13 two-in-one
Verdict: All of those things exist on last year's Spectre as well as on the newest Spectre x360 13. The updated version was just announced earlier this month, and it also includes Ice Lake architecture and Project Athena features (we haven't gotten the chance to test it yet, but keep an eye out for impressions in the future). You'll get more value for your money with the Spectre x360 13, but the XPS 13 two-in-one is a great option for those who need a little more flexibility than the XPS 13 laptop can provide.

Title: Garmin Vivoactive 4s review: So many fitness features, so little time
Summary: More fitness chops than you'd expect in a $349 device but largely the same smartwatch.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Streamlined, round case design.
Cons: On-screen animations not available for custom workouts.
Product Name: Garmin Vivoactive 4s
Verdict: But if you want your wearable to work harder for you, particularly in the health and fitness department, the Vivoactive 4 is a good option. It's more well-rounded in features than Forerunner smartwatches, and it's nowhere near as expensive as Fenix devices, making it a solid, mid-tier fitness watch for those who are more active than most.

Title: ROLI Songmaker Kit mini-review: Rediscovering my musical roots with fancy new tech

Title: Fitbit Versa review: Slowly but surely pushing Fitbit past the “fit” bit
Summary: If you think Fitbit is just for fitness, this $200 smartwatch might change your mind.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Lightweight design that's water-resistant up to 50 meters.
Cons: Interchangeable bands are hard to remove and replace on the device.
Product Name: Fitbit Versa
Verdict: Past success should tell Fitbit that ecosystem is everything. The company's mobile app is the best health and fitness program for any wearable because it has the flexibility to suit both serious athletes and novices alike. It didn't become that successful overnight, and neither will Fitbit OS. However, Fitbit has the opportunity to make its wearable operating system just as killer as its mobile application and overall ecosystem—if it can do that, its devices will be strong contenders in the smartwatch world. It may not have made a splash as Fitbit's first smartwatch, but if any device can entice users to take a chance on Fitbit as their smartwatch provider, it's the $200 Versa.

Title: Galaxy Tab S4 review: Even Samsung’s Dex desktop can’t save Android tablets

Pros: MicroSD card slot for more storage.
Cons: Inconsistent pen Translate feature.
Product Name: Galaxy Tab S4
Verdict: On top of all that, the competition still offers more reliable ways to get work done on a tablet.

Title: Nokia 6.1 Review—The best answer to “What Android phone should I buy?”
Summary: HMD does nearly everything right with this $269 wonder phone.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: An ultra-rigid metal body makes the Nokia 6.1 feel indestructible.
Cons: No always-on "OK Google" support.
Product Name: Nokia 6.1 Review—The best answer to “What Android phone should I buy?”
Verdict: Still, the Nokia 6.1 is beautifully built to a price—it's just that this price point means you miss out on the latest-and-greatest SoC, a modern slim bezel design, a top-tier camera, and a better display panel. Personally, I want something more high-end than the Nokia 6.1. But the people who casually ask for a phone recommendation probably aren't as big of a smartphone snob as I am. After testing this device, I suspect many users would likely be fine if not happy with this. The Nokia 6.1 stands as a functional, secure smartphone that does all of the basics right—it's hard to go wrong with that for $270.

Title: The 25th-anniversary ThinkPad: Every laptop should add some retro appeal

Cons: The 16:9 screen isn't a surprise, but I do wish Lenovo had gone for 16:10 or 3:2

Title: Agents of Mayhem review: Destroying a really dull open world
Summary: Saturday morning cartoon style struggles against a fatiguing open world.

Title: Nidhogg 2 review: Violent, disgusting, and hilariously fun
Summary: A better game for series fans old and new, this is everything a great sequel should be.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Original game's solid formula has been intelligently built upon, not thrown out.
Cons: Online mode sacrifices speed for frame-perfect accuracy, so it can feel clunky even on a good connection.
Product Name: Nidhogg 2
Verdict: : A must-buy for couch battlers. Online players should try.

Title: Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle is a great introduction to tactical RPGs
Summary: Odd combo is more peanut butter and chocolate than, say, steak and chocolate.
Author: Kyle Orland
Pros: Lots of variety in enemies and situations keeps things fresh.
Cons: Lucky shots can carry you through or ruin a battle quickly.
Product Name: Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle is a great introduction to tactical RPGs
Verdict: An engaging, lighthearted introduction to the genre that will appeal to novices and veterans. Buy it.

Title: Knack II review: A slightly better class of boring
Summary: Sequel improves on the PS4 launch title but ends up utterly forgettable.
Author: Steven Strom
Pros: Surprisingly complex, satisfying combat
Cons: Completely unremarkable story and characters
Product Name: Knack II
Verdict: : There are plenty of better games to spend your time and money on right now. If you absolutely, specifically need an inoffensive couch co-op brawler right now, try it.

Title: Huawei Matebook X Pro review: No longer just a MacBook clone
Summary: Huawei’s strategic choices make this new laptop much better than the original.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Sleek, all-metal design.
Cons: Heavier than the original.
Product Name: Huawei Matebook X Pro

However, both the HP Spectre 13 and the XPS 13 have thinner, lighter designs, more biometric security options, and similar internals and performance without the questionmarks regarding availability and price.

Title: 2018 iPad review: Content creation with compromises

Verdict: The iPad comes with too many compromises to be the ideal creative or education device Apple wants it to be, but it's still the best tablet for most consumers.

Title: Owl Car Cam review: A data-connected dash cam for car lovers

Product Name: Owl Car Cam
Verdict: The standout features of the Owl Car Cam are all optional dash cam perks—LTE and constant power don't make a solid dash cam, but they make one that can do more for you when you're not actually driving. Those who hold their cars near and dear to their hearts should consider the $349 device and one-year service bundle because, while expensive, they're a good deal considering the alternative prices ($299 for the device, plus $10 per month or $99 per year). Otherwise, more affordable dash cams provide many of the same essential features that the Owl Car Cam has, allowing you to protect you and your car while on the road for as little as $50.

Title: Samsung Notebook 9 Pen review: Stylus convenience, devoid of style

Hopefully the second-gen Notebook 9 Pen (if it exists in the future) addresses these issues, making it better suited for the $1,399 price tag than the current version.

Title: Android 8.0 Oreo, thoroughly reviewed

Author: Ron Amadeo

Product Name: Android 8.0 Oreo, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: As always, it's going to be a while before we see the true ramifications of this release. The first big third-party phone to launch with Android 8.0—and therefore Project Treble—will probably be the Galaxy S9 or something else in the "early 2018" window, and then we'll have to wait some more to see what the ROM community can do with it. The shakeout from the background processing lockdown will take even longer—it only applies to apps that target Android 8.0, and it should be about a year before the majority of apps do that. Android Go will take a while to play out, too—the first commercial devices aren't due out until 2018. The endless upgrade treadmill continues.

Title: iMac Pro review: Working as intended

On a good day, the price can be respectable, albeit unambiguously high end. On a bad day, it can be positively eye-watering. As much as I love it, I'm not sure I could quite justify paying list price, but find a day with a good discount and you may be getting yourself the greatest PC laptop that has ever shipped.

And if you can get a couple hundred bucks knocked off the price in some kind of sale—common enough on Amazon, Newegg, OEM sites, Best Buy, and elsewhere, especially as newer products come out and inventories need to roll over—the value proposition is a lot better. Keep it in mind as you shop around.

Verdict: At $229, the G5 is still a great budget Android phone. But these days that’s just as much about the total lack of credible competition in the space as it is about the G5 itself. If Nokia and HMD’s Nokia 6, for instance, can deliver on its promise of a well-built phone with unskinned Android and fast updates for about the same price, the Moto line is suddenly going to start looking a lot worse. Nokia and HMD need to prove themselves, but unfortunately Lenovo has already proven that it doesn’t especially care about quick updates anymore.

Title: Battle of the buds: How Apple AirPods stack up against other wireless earbuds

Author: Valentina Palladino
Product Name: Battle of the buds: How Apple AirPods stack up against other wireless earbuds
Verdict: Battery life is so important because people listen to music for hours on end. Nothing can beat the nearly endless life you get from wired earbuds, but their wireless counterparts can be better than they are now. I'd like to see at least six hours of onboard battery life on every pair of wireless buds, and most of the devices we tested came close to that. We're only just dipping our toes into the wireless future that Tim Cook described, but these buds show that the future is hopeful. There's no doubt that companies will be compelled to make better, more affordable wireless earbuds in the future because, when we're all forced to give up our wires, they'll become necessities rather than just a fancy optional accessory.

Title: Moov HR review: Everyone should wear heart rate monitors on their heads
Summary: If you like HRM chest straps, you may like Moov’s pulse-tracking head gear.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Small design that sits comfortably in headband
Cons: Headband is one size fits all
Product Name: Moov HR
Verdict: The only other thing consumers will have to grapple with is the idea of buying two sensors. If they want to track both motion and heart rate, they'll need the $99 Moov HR and the $69 Moov Now. On the surface, the double-purchase is frustrating: you have to buy two things, you need to remember to bring both to the gym to do certain workouts, and both sensors are small enough to lose easily. But the flexibility of Moov's Now and HR duo is a good alternative to a traditional tracker: wear one or wear both, use Moov's app or use your favorite fitness app. The choice is up to you. And once you try the HR, you'll likely find that wearing a sensor on your head isn't as weird as you thought.

Verdict: This would be a great laptop if it was positioned at the $1,300 starting price of the old MacBook Pros, though the 12-inch MacBook might need to move downmarket a bit to make room for it. At its current price, the $1,499 Pro feels like a laptop with a new design that just happens to be missing a bunch of the features that make the new design worthwhile.

Title: Review: Small, slick design makes Dell XPS 13 2-in-1 the PC laptop to beat
Summary: Dell added Windows Hello, removed the fan, and kept the good stuff the same.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Thin-bezeled design is still eye-catching and futuristic-looking two years later.
Cons: Y-series Core i5 and i7 processors are better than they once were, but not as good as the 15W processors in slightly larger laptops.
Product Name: Review: Small, slick design makes Dell XPS 13 2-in-1 the PC laptop to beat
Verdict: The XPS 13 convertible has only three marks against it. If you plan on using it as a developer machine or something else that crunches code, the low-power Y-series processors still fall short of the beefier 15W versions in laptops like the Spectre and the regular XPS 13. Even if USB-C will carry you to the year 2050, chances are USB-A ports will still be useful for the foreseeable future. Dell includes an adapter, but the ports aren’t available on the laptop itself. And though it enables the slick-looking razor-thin top bezel, the below-the-screen webcam placement continues to be something you begrudgingly work around, not something you prefer. Overall, though, Dell has taken one of the PC market’s best designs and made it better. It’s hard to complain about that.

Title: Huawei Fit review: Better than a TalkBand, but only on-par with competitors

Title: Pebble 2 reviewed: Proof that a heart rate monitor doesn’t make a fitness tracker
Summary: $130 may get you a HRM, but that doesn't mean it's a serious fitness device.

Pros: Pleasant and comfortable throwback design.
Cons: Tracking exercise on the watch only shows you heart rate and duration.
Product Name: Pebble 2 reviewed: Proof that a heart rate monitor doesn’t make a fitness tracker
Verdict: But a look at the big picture reveals that the Pebble 2's $130 price is a pretty good deal. It's a solid smartwatch that delivers notifications and alerts, lets you read and reply to messages and control music playback, and has great battery life (especially compared to the Apple Watch and Android Wear watches). The inconveniences in its smartwatch features, like necessary manual dismissal of alerts and sub-par voice recognition, wouldn't deter me from buying the Pebble 2. It's ideal not just for anyone who wants a smartwatch and doesn't want to shell out hundreds of dollars for an Apple Watch or an Android Wear device, but for anyone who would benefit from basic activity tracking with heart rate monitor integration. Title: Samsung Smartcam PT review: Never miss a beat thanks to pan-and-tilt

Samsung strategically built upon the Smartcam device line with the Smartcam PT, taking what works well in existing devices and folding them into a new device that has a different, utilitarian design rather than simply bumping the resolution or giving us a new design. At $200, the PT may be on par with the rest of the competing security cameras, but I still think that Blink's muli-camera system is a better value for the money than one, stand-alone device. But if you're not concerned with watching over many rooms and want to focus your security efforts on one main room in your home, the Smartcam PT does that well.

Cons: Most of my favorite voice commands from the Google app don't work—no reminders, messages, or creating calendar events.
Product Name: Google Home
Verdict: If you're just looking for a media slinging box, go for it. If you really need a solid voice command system, though, just install the Google app on your phone. It's way better, and you've already got the hardware in your pocket.

Title: The (updated) history of Android
Summary: Follow the endless iterations from Android 0.5 to Android 7 and beyond.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: The (updated) history of Android
Verdict: With these changes, we're probably at the most uncertain point in Android's history. But ahead of the platform's recent October 2016 event,

Title: Good and bad news: Withings Go is a tiny tracker you’ll forget you’re wearing
Summary: It could help you develop new healthy habits, but otherwise it's unremarkable.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Small design makes it lightweight, while e-ink display makes it easy to see time and activity progress.
Cons: No vibration motor for one-wrist alarms.
Product Name: Good and bad news: Withings Go is a tiny tracker you’ll forget you’re wearing
Verdict: Withings had to make the Go. With every fitness tracker company trying to fill in all the price gaps (and create new ones sometimes), Withings had to provide customers an under-$100 option. Adding a vibration motor to the Go would likely raise its price, but for me, I'd rather spend the extra money for a device that plays an active role in my life. Misfit's $100 Ray does this pretty well as it monitors all of the fitness metrics that the Go does sans swimming. But if you can live without those taps on the wrist, the Withings Go may be a good option that not only tracks activity but also integrates the app thoughtfully to help build healthy habits.

Title: Review: iRobot’s $199 Braava Jet is a robo-Swiffer for small spaces
Summary: It gets points for cleanliness and ease of use, but its audience is limited.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Small, compact design that's easy to carry and store out of sight.
Cons: Only meant for hard surfaces, will not work on carpet.
Product Name: Review: iRobot’s $199 Braava Jet is a robo-Swiffer for small spaces
Verdict: Everything that the Braava Jet was made to do, it does well—but your experience with it will depend on the type of home you live in. Just because it has a tempting price tag of $199 doesn't mean it'll be the best robotic vacuum for your money. If most of the rooms in your home have carpet, you might not want to spend the money on a robot that will only clean a portion of your place. Similarly, if you've got a large home full of hardwood, tile, and stone floors, the bigger and more powerful Braava 300 will be able to clean them more efficiently. Those who will get the most out of the Braava Jet are small- to medium-sized apartment dwellers—a Braava Jet in those homes can easily replace brooms and mops, while paying for itself in convenience.

Title: Samsung Galaxy TabPro S review: A taste of a future I’m not ready for
Summary: OLED looks incredible, but no one wants constant reminders that their screen is breaking.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: The OLED screen really does look amazing
Cons: Only 4GB RAM
Product Name: Samsung Galaxy TabPro S
Verdict: This concern isn't restricted to the TabPro S; I believe that all the OLED systems that are coming to market this year include various kinds of screen-preservation tech. In 2016 (and not 1996), it's too worrisome for everyday machines.

Title: Amazon’s beautiful, functional, impractical Kindle Oasis reviewed
Summary: $290 Oasis doesn’t do anything Paperwhite doesn’t do, it just does it better.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Slimmer, sleeker, and altogether more usable design pushes the Kindle lineup forward.
Cons: Shorter battery life when separated from its case.
Product Name: Amazon’s beautiful, functional, impractical Kindle Oasis reviewed
Verdict: As it stands, those of you who are looking for the best reading experience at any price should buy the Oasis. If you're looking for a good e-reader at a sensible price, you should buy the Paperwhite without hesitation. The base model Kindle is still decent if you just want the cheapest dedicated Kindle you can get. The vestigial Voyage should be avoided entirely.

Title: Review: HP’s EliteBook Folio G1 is the MacBook as it could’ve been
Summary: Two Thunderbolt 3 ports and a great keyboard and trackpad help it excel.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Thin, light, and fanless laptop made of premium materials.
Cons: The USB Type-C transition is still a work in progress, and you'll need adapters for a lot of your current stuff.
Product Name: Review: HP’s EliteBook Folio G1 is the MacBook as it could’ve been
Verdict: That aside, though, the EliteBook is a really great ultraportable laptop. It’s a dramatically improved version of

Title: Dell XPS 15 review: A bigger version of the best PC laptop [Updated]
Summary: Dell has taken the best 13-inch laptop on the market and made it bigger.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: The good looks and light weight we've come to expect
Cons: No SSD option in the cheapest configurations
Product Name: Dell XPS 15
Verdict: I'm a big fan of the XPS 13, so it's not a surprise that I like the XPS 15. The external features that made the XPS 13 so good are all retained, and some of the internals have received a hefty upgrade. If you're more comfortable with a larger laptop or want to run heavier workloads that need the extra oomph that the XPS 15 has to offer, it's a fine choice.

Title: Broadwell-E arrives: Testing Intel’s 10-core, $1,700 desktop CPU
Summary: New enthusiast CPUs include new tech and more cores but stick with old chipsets.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Broadwell-E arrives: Testing Intel’s 10-core, $1,700 desktop CPU
Verdict: On the other hand, if money is no object, if you want respectable single-threaded performance, and if you want a really fast CPU that you can overclock even faster, Broadwell-E is an option for you. It’s going to find some fans regardless of the price, but it would have been nice if Intel had offered more performance at the same price as last year rather than coming up with a whole new price point for the faster CPU.

Title: Triby review: A speaker, message-board device is an obvious home for Amazon’s Alexa
Summary: Alexa-enabled devices have potential, but they also have some flaws to overcome.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Cute design that easily lets you take Alexa, a radio, and a primitive messaging system around the house with you.
Cons: Some of Alexa's features don't work on Triby, including Spotify music playback and some skills.
Product Name: Triby
Verdict: If you want the fullest experience of Alexa, it's still best to go with one of Amazon's products. That will ensure you'll have every feature Alexa could possibly have, with fewer hiccups that can occur from using her on a third-party device. However, Triby is a useful device for large, busy families that want to stay connected via their homes. Triby acts like a tangible (yet largely digital) home base so you can communicate with everyone in your household through a device that everyone will see at some point during the day. I do think it's slightly overpriced at $199, especially considering the Echo is $179, but I also see its potential to be one of those devices that you use every day without realizing how much you use it.

Title: Gear Fit 2 review: A thoughtful marriage of smartwatch and fitness band
Summary: Samsung's $179 Gear device improves upon the first and should make others sweat.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Curved and slim design makes it comfortable to wear.
Cons: Only works with Samsung or Android 4.4+ smartphones.
Product Name: Gear Fit 2
Verdict: Finally, the $179 price tag is enticing. The Microsoft Band originally started at $200 but has been discounted now to $175. If you like guided workouts, it's worth it to go with Microsoft's device, but for nearly any other purpose the Gear Fit 2 is the better deal. In comparison to Fitbit devices, the Gear Fit 2 manages to make the top-tier Blaze and Surge look outdated. The $200 Blaze has a heart rate monitor but needs a phone to provide GPS. The $229 Surge has both built in but is larger, has a smaller monochrome display, and costs much more. The main thing Fitbit's devices have going for them is their universal support for Android, iOS, and Windows Phones. If Samsung adds iOS support in the future, the Gear Fit 2 would be the fitness watch to beat.

Title: Intel’s quad-core “Skull Canyon” NUC is a workstation for the size-obsessed
Summary: Review: Pricey PC has Thunderbolt 3 and Iris Pro, but it's not for everyone.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Nice, fast quad-core CPU and impressive integrated GPU.
Cons: Fan gets loud under load.
Product Name: Intel’s quad-core “Skull Canyon” NUC is a workstation for the size-obsessed
Verdict: This is a neat little PC for people with really specific needs. I’m not convinced that it’s going to be overwhelmingly popular, but I prefer a product with a small-but-defined audience to one that doesn’t seem to be made

Title: Review: HP’s Elite x2 is a Surface clone you can actually upgrade
Summary: Surface Pro 4 is better in many ways, but you'll want the x2 when things break.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A Surface clone that’s actually repairable.
Cons: Smaller, lower-resolution screen than the Surface Pro 4, and it’s a little larger, too.
Product Name: Review: HP’s Elite x2 is a Surface clone you can actually upgrade
Verdict: There are other good points, too—the standard keyboard cover, the integrated fingerprint sensor, the Thunderbolt 3 port, the LTE option. None of these things make it a better computer to use than the Surface, but they all make it a good workhorse convertible that has ripped a lot of important pages from the Surface’s playbook. If you’re already in the market for one of Microsoft’s tablets, it’s at least worth a good, long look.

Title: The Moto 360 Sport reviewed: Good, but not enough fitness to be worth it
Summary: The $299 smartwatch is a runner's companion; all other athletes look elsewhere.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Moto Body Running doesn't require your smartphone to work—you can leave it at home and go track a run with only the watch
Cons: Moto Body is good for tracking daily activity and running, nothing more
Product Name: The Moto 360 Sport reviewed: Good, but not enough fitness to be worth it
Verdict: The $249 Fitbit Surge and the $249 Garmin Vivoactive offer way more than the Moto 360 Sport in terms of activity variety, and the Vivoactive works on both Android and iOS devices identically and can deliver smartphone notifications as well. Unless you're a hardcore Moto fan, there isn't a strong enough reason to buy the Moto 360 Sport over other dedicated fitness watches, especially when many of them are more comprehensive and less expensive at the same time.

Title: Review: Battery life and keyboard problems hinder HP Envy 13 Ultrabook
Summary: It's a good laptop, but it's competing against some great laptops.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good performance thanks to Skylake
Cons: No DisplayPort means no 60Hz 4K output
Product Name: Review: Battery life and keyboard problems hinder HP Envy 13 Ultrabook
Verdict: If you're in the market for an Ultrabook right now, the Envy 13 has its charms, but unfortunately it's not one of the first ones we'd recommend.

Title: Nabu Watch reviewed: Razer gets into smartwatches in a big way (literally)
Summary: The $150 smartwatch makes a statement with its design, but it's otherwise basic.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Secondary display makes it easy to read notifications without losing date and time information on main display.
Cons: This watch is gigantic and definitely better suited for larger wrists.
Product Name: Nabu Watch reviewed: Razer gets into smartwatches in a big way (literally)
Verdict: Until then, the Nabu Watch falls as flat as a fitness gadget when compared to similar devices from Garmin and Fitbit. If you're not a hardcore Razer fan, there's no reason to invest in the Nabu Watch over another, more capable fitness tracker with smartphone notifications.

Title: Under Armour and HTC’s HealthBox: Decent together, weak individually
Summary: Review: At $400, the whole package doesn't come cheap.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: The band, chest strap, and smart scale work well together and make up an easy-to-use health tracking ecosystem
Cons: Individually, each product is expensive compared to other fitness trackers, chest straps, and smart scales
Product Name: Under Armour and HTC’s HealthBox: Decent together, weak individually
Verdict: If you're willing to spend that money to make healthy changes in your life, you'd better be serious about it. And that's who HealthBox is for—those who are serious about tracking their exercise routine and diet in order to reach a goal. Anyone else who just wants to joke around with step count can buy another, better standalone tracker.

Title: Review: HP improves its $200 laptop a lot, but it’s still a $200 laptop
Summary: New HP Stream 11 is a well-built budget PC, but most users will find it limiting.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Just $200.
Cons: 32GB of storage is expandable via microSD, but it's still limiting if you're trying to keep a media collection or install and run a bunch of apps.
Product Name: Review: HP improves its $200 laptop a lot, but it’s still a $200 laptop
Verdict: But once you put all of those caveats aside, you really are getting good value for $200 here. Battery life, the keyboard, and the wireless are all exceptional at this price, and most other features—from the build quality to the screen to the GPU performance—are firmly Good Enough. Processor performance is disappointing, and the low RAM limits multitasking, but if you approach this laptop with appropriately calibrated expectations, you’ll be pleasantly surprised.

Title: Neato Botvac Connected review: A LIDAR-powered robot vacuum is my maid now
Summary: Vacuuming is for chumps. Make a robot do it.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: It vacuums; I don't. It saves me about 95 percent of the time I would spend cleaning, and since I rarely have to do anything, the floor gets vacuumed far more often than it would if it was just up to me.
Cons: The app needs work. It's missing obvious features like a full set of notifications, and it's unreliable.
Product Name: Neato Botvac Connected
Verdict: Neato is on the fourth generation of its robo vacs, and they really are powerful effective cleaning devices that save a ton of time. We'd only pick up the high-end version if you just

Title: Under Armour’s Gemini 2 sneakers make running smarter without extra baggage
Summary: Review: Connected shoes take the intelligence (and the weight) off your wrist.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Look and feel just like regular shoes—no extra parts or wires to worry about, no charging required.
Cons: Battery life is questionable—if Under Armour's prediction is true, runners might have to spend $150 twice a year to sustain working pairs of the shoes.
Product Name: Under Armour’s Gemini 2 sneakers make running smarter without extra baggage
Verdict: But what's really intriguing about the smart Gemini 2s is their price compared to the originals. The regular shoes cost $130 and the smart sneakers are only slightly more expensive at $150. That's a much easier gap to jump than, say, trying to go from a regular $30 athletic shirt to a $400 smart shirt that tracks your breathing, heart rate, and a bunch of other stats. Hopefully this is a sign of things to come in the smart clothing world, and eventually we won't have to pay exorbitantly more for a healthy mix of features and convenience.

Title: Android 6.0 Marshmallow, thoroughly reviewed
Summary: Marshmallow brings a lot of user-requested features but still has no update solution.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: The new home screen adds tons of genuinely useful features. App Search, predictive apps, vertical scrolling, and the uninstall shortcut are all great time savers.
Cons: There still isn't auto rotate support for the home screen. Google teased us in the developer preview but the feature was cut.
Product Name: Android 6.0 Marshmallow, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: Android is far, far behind the competition when it comes to device security. The only real solution we can see is a

Title: Same design, new insides, better screen: 21.5-inch 4K Retina iMac reviewed
Summary: Fusion Drives desperately need to be standard, but otherwise this is a nice Mac.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Gorgeous screen with an improved color gamut.
Cons: No dedicated GPU options, and the integrated GPU chugs if you increase the resolution or hook up another 4K display.
Product Name: Same design, new insides, better screen: 21.5-inch 4K Retina iMac reviewed
Verdict: If you're OK with the list of omissions and you can spring for the storage upgrade, the 4K iMac gets you a great professional-quality screen and a powerful quad-core processor for a pretty reasonable price. The 27-inch iMac is the computer that most blurs the line between consumer all-in-one and high-end workstation, but as long as you aren't gaming you can get some pretty serious work done on the 21.5-inch iMac. If Apple can make Fusion Drives and 4K screens standard on all iMacs when the Skylake refresh comes around, we won't have much left to complain about.

Title: The 2015 Chromecast and Chromecast Audio: Small blips in the stream [Updated]
Summary: Tons of apps and functionality for $35, but are these devices worth a two-year wait?
Author: Sam Machkovech
Product Name: The 2015 Chromecast and Chromecast Audio: Small blips in the stream [Updated]
Verdict: After publication,

Title: Amazon’s 2015 Fire TV: Finally, Amazon gets the streaming box right
Summary: Review: Connectivity, interface issues met with gaming, search boosts. Plus, it's fast.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Loading times for non-live streaming content are the fastest yet on a streaming box—even surpassing the more expensive Xbox One.
Cons: Fire OS 5.0 interface still suffers from too much pecking through menus; it would be nice if you could pin favorite apps and content.
Product Name: Amazon’s 2015 Fire TV: Finally, Amazon gets the streaming box right
Verdict: : This streaming box nails the sweet spot between performance and price.

Title: Review: Nest Cam watches over your home so you don’t have to
Summary: Quality is good and it plays well with other Nests, but subscription costs add up.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: 1080p video is a slight but welcome upgrade from Dropcam's 720p video
Cons: Two of the most useful features, activity zones and clips, are only available with a Nest Aware subscription
Product Name: Review: Nest Cam watches over your home so you don’t have to
Verdict: However, most home security cameras don't do much to secure your home right out of the box. While Nest Cam lets me see what's going on in my home at all times, it alone doesn't do anything to

Title: Jawbone’s Up4 is its most advanced, and expensive, tracker yet
Summary: Review: The $199 device passively monitors heart rate and lets you pay with NFC.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Svelte design meshes well with different outfits and is easy to wear all day long.
Cons: Hook-and-eye closure has been improved, but can be tricky to secure with one hand.
Product Name: Jawbone’s Up4 is its most advanced, and expensive, tracker yet
Verdict: But it seems like the Up4 wants to be the best convenience fitness tracker. After putting it on your wrist, you don't have to touch it again except to take it off when showering and charging. It monitors heart rate passively, sleep automatically, and acts as a credit card when you're in a pinch and need to pick something up on the way home from your morning jog. With the recent software update, Jawbone succeeded in making the already-capable Up4 much more useful than any of its previous counterparts were at launch. However, with smartwatches and multipurpose devices creeping up in popularity, it's going to be hard for a little band to compete in a world that's slowly being overrun by wrist-bound computers.

Title: Surface Pro 4 review: The tablet that still doesn’t quite replace your laptop
Summary: But it's a fine machine if you don't mind that it can't.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Bigger, better screen.
Cons: It's very short on USB ports.
Product Name: Surface Pro 4
Verdict: This leaves scope for Microsoft's partners to undercut it. The Surface Pro 4 is certainly a good machine, but is it going to be better, or a better value, than the competition? We'll have to wait a few weeks to find out.

Title: Microsoft Band 2.0: Big steps forward mean you just might ditch your trainer
Summary: Review: Better than the original, but not perfect.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: The Band's improved design makes it much easier and more comfortable to wear.
Cons: The clasp remains difficult to secure and is bulky compared to the rest of the Band.
Product Name: Microsoft Band 2.0: Big steps forward mean you just might ditch your trainer
Verdict: The Microsoft Band is a work in progress, but Microsoft has made real progress in this second iteration. I still believe the best thing the Microsoft Band has going for it is Microsoft Health. It takes a lot for me to get excited about a new fitness band—and when I saw how robust Microsoft Health had become as a fitness platform, I was truly excited. Guided workouts will soon be necessary for any high-end tracker because to be a true fitness device, you have to do more than count steps. But custom workouts that you can assemble yourself and take anywhere will be the future—and maybe they'll persuade millions of fitness tracker users to keep wearing their bands instead of abandoning them in cluttered drawers.

Title: Incredibly loud and always watching: Canary’s security camera reviewed
Summary: An alarm, emergency contacts, and night vision make Canary a capable watchdog.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Canary's chic design lets it double as a decorative piece as well as a home security device.
Cons: Setup process is a little long and tedious.
Product Name: Incredibly loud and always watching: Canary’s security camera reviewed
Verdict: Unlike the Nest Cam, however, Canary has no smart home protocol, which means you cannot connect it with a smart door lock or other device to have them work together. If Canary added this feature in the future, it would only make a strong product stronger. Canary's only current downfalls are the small bugs that made downloading clips and automatic mode switching complicated. Thankfully Canary already knows about these issues and can continue to make app and firmware updates to address them. Considering Canary provides more security features than other smart home cameras and has a few affordable subscription plan options, it's a solid investment for anyone looking to keep a more watchful eye on their home.

Title: Nexus 5X and Nexus 6P review: The true flagships of the Android ecosystem
Summary: With little to no compromise, these are now the Android phones to beat.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Nexus 5X and Nexus 6P
Verdict: In some ways these devices feel like a combination of the best ideas from the Android ecosystem. You get Motorola's ambient display and always-on voice commands, LG's laser auto focus, and Google's software design, security, and fast updates. This year's crop of Nexus phones are devices that stand alone atop the Android ecosystem, with a combination of features you won't find anywhere else. If you're in the market for an Android phone, you've run out of excuses not to get a Nexus.

Title: Review: Netatmo’s Welcome home security camera gets facial recognition right
Summary: It doesn't require a subscription, but lag and image quality can be problems.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: You'll be happy to display the Welcome anywhere in your home thanks to its sleek, understated design.
Cons: Image quality is significantly reduced when your mobile device and the Welcome are not connected to the same network at the same time.
Product Name: Review: Netatmo’s Welcome home security camera gets facial recognition right
Verdict: But if you're looking for a surveillance camera that will only cost you its sticker price of $199, the Welcome is a solid choice. Its system of recording video to a microSD card rather than making you pay a monthly fee for basic services is really convenient. It was refreshing to use a security camera that didn't threaten to take away some of its key features after my free trial expired, and Netatmo definitely hopes that will entice customers to welcome the Welcome into their homes.

Title: Mini-review: Hisense’s ARM Chromebook actually isn’t awful for $149
Summary: The laptop doesn't cut corners that $199 Chromebooks aren't already cutting.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Feels pretty well-made for $149.
Cons: Keyboard and trackpad are OK but sometimes tweaky.
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: The biggest downside to either of the $149 Chromebooks might be their retailer exclusivity. Schools and businesses buy lots of Chromebooks, and they usually need to deal with more established OEMs with better support options. For any individual looking for a cheap Chromebook, though, you could do a lot worse.

Title: New Apple TV wants to be more than just a streaming box (but it isn’t yet)
Summary: Review: Game console? Mini PC? Media player? There's a lot of potential here.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Fast, small, and unobtrusive.
Cons: Optical audio out is gone.
Product Name: New Apple TV wants to be more than just a streaming box (but it isn’t yet)
Verdict: But today, right now, when you buy a new Apple TV, what you’re really buying into is its promise, something that is only hinted at by the handful of solid apps and games that are already in the App Store. There’s no guarantee that Apple TV apps will make a ton of money or that its App Store will ever be as well-stocked as the iOS App Store is today. But for all intents and purposes, the new Apple TV is a small, iOS-based desktop computer that sits underneath your TV. There’s a lot of possibility here, and I’m excited to see where it is in three or six or 12 months.

Title: Mini-review: Test driving a fully loaded, $4,000 27-inch 5K iMac
Summary: Skylake CPUs, fast GPUs, a 1TB SSD, and 32GB of RAM make this iMac fun to use.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Great screen with an improved color gamut.
Cons: Other than RAM, aftermarket upgrades are difficult-to-impossible.
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: To put it in context: the iPhone 6S’ CPU is over 20 times faster than 2010’s iPhone 4. 2015’s best iMac is only around twice as fast as 2010’s best iMac. On the one hand, it’s frustrating that high-end desktop performance is improving so slowly. On the other, at least you know it’s going to last for a long time.

Title: An Ultrabook that works with your projector: Lenovo T450s reviewed
Summary: Ports, end-user servicing, docking stations, and legacy connectors live on.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: That keyboard, that TrackPoint
Cons: The screen is only OK
Product Name: An Ultrabook that works with your projector: Lenovo T450s reviewed
Verdict: It makes me wonder, now that thin and light are the norm, how far could we swing the balance the other way to recapture some of what the MacBook Air and its Ultrabook offspring have given up. For example, my understanding is that to fit 16GB into a laptop you need to use socketed RAM; the soldered kind for whatever reason doesn't go that big, which is why so many Ultrabooks are limited to 8GB. And if I could have a machine that was 0.1 inches thicker than an X1 and 0.2lbs heavier than an X1, but it had a pair of RAM sockets for up to 16GB and an RJ45 port? I'd grab one in an instant.

Title: A review of Android for Work: Dual-persona support comes to Android
Summary: Google aims for the enterprise with separate work and home data on a single device.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: A review of Android for Work: Dual-persona support comes to Android
Verdict: Android for Work makes a dual-persona smartphone finally feel like something that isn't a clunky hack. If you're still carrying around one phone for work and one for home, it's time to save some pocket space. Bug your IT department to roll this feature out.

Title: Ultrabook Plus: The 2015 13-inch Retina MacBook Pro reviewed
Summary: It's not a quad-core workstation, but it's faster than most 13-inch laptops.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good CPU, GPU, RAM, and storage specs for this price, size, and weight. Few PC OEMs use the faster 28W Broadwell-U chips, and so far few have opted to use 1866MHz DDR3 RAM.
Cons: Good battery life for light workloads, but it drops off quickly under load.
Product Name: Ultrabook Plus: The 2015 13-inch Retina MacBook Pro reviewed
Verdict: If you're looking at a MacBook Air but you want a Retina screen, though, the Pro becomes very tempting. We'd recommend you upgrade the Air to 8GB of RAM anyway, and by the time you've done that, the price difference isn't all that big. The sharpness and added versatility of the screen and the better CPU and GPU come at the expense of a little weight and a little battery life, but for power users especially, we think these tradeoffs are worth it.

Title: Roku 4 review: A future-proofed 4K version of the best streaming box (so far)
Summary: $130 box is larger and faster, and it's overkill for most people right now.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Huge selection of channels (including Google Play and Amazon) that doesn’t prioritize one provider over any others.
Cons: Requires HDCP 2.2 for 4K streaming, something that not all 4K-capable TVs and receivers will support.
Product Name: Roku 4
Verdict: If you want a Roku but don’t yet own one, the Roku 4 is a little more expensive than the rest of the lineup at $130, but it’s also the most future-proof. When your TV hardware and the content providers are all streaming 4K, you’ll be ready. And even if you don’t have a 4K TV yet, the Roku 4’s UI seems marginally crisper at 1080p than the Roku 3’s, and performance while you’re navigating through different streaming apps is improved, if not completely free of jankiness (that said, it’s hard to spot the differences if you’re actually streaming video). You get all the benefits of the Roku 3’s Enhanced Remote support with the promise of 4K support and software updates going forward.

Title: HTC One M9 review: HTC’s flagship feels like an afterthought
Summary: A design from 2013 and a heavily throttled SoC make for a disappointing update.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: HTC made some good changes to the M9, like getting rid of the gimmicky Duo Camera.
Cons: The M9 runs hot and performance suffers. Our CPU benchmark showed a 30 percent drop in performance.
Product Name: HTC One M9
Verdict: Look at what Samsung is doing. The company suffered

Title: The 2015 MacBook previews a future that’s not quite here
Summary: Review: This laptop is defined by the features it doesn't have.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: So thin and light that it out-MacBook-Airs the MacBook Air.
Cons: Performance is a step or two behind recent Broadwell-U Macs.
Product Name: The 2015 MacBook previews a future that’s not quite here
Verdict: Ultimately, the new MacBook feels like a first-generation product—a very good first-generation product, but a first-generation product nevertheless. It has some promise and a couple of major shortcomings, and you don't need to be the first person who takes the leap into the Brave New Future it represents. I use an iMac as my primary computer and a 13-inch MacBook Air when I’m sitting on the couch or in a café or on a plane, and perhaps 90 percent of the time this MacBook can replace the Air without issue. If this is going to be your main computer or only computer or if you’re one of the bare handful of people who use Thunderbolt for something, it’s hard to recommend.

Title: Mini-review: Intel’s powered-up Core i7 Broadwell mini PC
Summary: 28W chips give a nice CPU and GPU performance bump to the first Core i7 NUC.
