Title: Samsung Galaxy S6 review: It’s what’s on the outside that counts
Summary: A great camera and premium materials offset the loss of power-user features.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A spectacular camera. Better than the iPhone 6 Plus—yep, we said it.
Cons: TouchWiz is still bad. The Flipboard home screen is a laggy hack. Apps hide the status bar for no reason. Things look different for no reason. Your OS looks like TouchWiz, but you'll be using an entire ecosystem of Material Design apps.
Product Name: Samsung Galaxy S6
Verdict: We would still like to see the company refresh the stale front design and do something about TouchWiz, but it's nice to see Samsung finally break some of its bad habits. The S6 is a great device and is something that should help Samsung's newly uncertain market position. There are some tradeoffs, but, finally, we've got a Samsung phone that feels nice. What the heck took so long?

Title: Surface 3 review: Smaller, slower, cheaper... better?
Summary: Switching to an x86 processor has made the Surface so much better.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Immensely versatile machine
Cons: Atom is fast enough, but still not really
Product Name: Surface 3
Verdict: The Surface 3 is a very neat, versatile little machine. A lot of people will be able to make it work well for them. It works as a tablet. It works in most ways as a laptop. With the dock, it can even power a big screen and connect to a ton of peripherals. This is simultaneously a great digital notepad and a fine Office workhorse.

Title: HP Spectre x360: The surprisingly good offspring of a MacBook Air and Lenovo Yoga
Summary: Review: Good looks and great battery life make for a compelling laptop.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: I love how it looks
Cons: The keyboard is mediocre
Product Name: HP Spectre x360: The surprisingly good offspring of a MacBook Air and Lenovo Yoga
Verdict: Price-wise, there's nothing to really separate the XPS 13 from the Spectre x360. Which one you prefer will be a product of personal preference, and it's a tough choice. As much as I relish the XPS 13's size, I also enjoy the x360's "tent mode." The XPS 13 has a slightly better keyboard, but the Spectre's larger touchpad is perhaps a little easier to use. I'd veer slightly toward the XPS 13, though I'd regularly curse its awful webcam positioning. On the other hand, you wouldn't be going wrong to pick the Spectre...

Title: LG G4 Review: More than competent, but less than stunning [Update]
Summary: The G4 is a decent phone, but struggles to stand out against the competition.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A great camera with full manual controls and output to DNG. And the color sensor seems to actually work!
Cons: No matter which back panel you get, the major contact points—the sides and buttons—are still plastic.
Product Name: LG G4 Review: More than competent, but less than stunning [Update]
Verdict: LG also has plans to offer wireless charging via an extra back option. Like the charger, it's another thing that is built into other phones that you have to pay extra for for the G4. It's better to have the option than not, though.

Title: Lollipop on the 2012 Nexus 7: Not great, but not much worse
Summary: The older tablet's problems stem mostly from hardware, not software.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Lollipop on the 2012 Nexus 7: Not great, but not much worse
Verdict: Your experiences on the 2012 Nexus 7 may be different from ours, particularly if you have the 16GB or 32GB models—their storage speeds were still pretty low, but they were measurably better than the 8GB model. In either case, Lollipop does little to save or ruin your tablet. Go ahead and upgrade. If you absolutely hate Lollipop, you can always

Title: The Nexus 10, Lollipop, and the problem with big Android tablets
Summary: When it comes to tablets, Google doesn't even follow its own design guidelines.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: The Nexus 10, Lollipop, and the problem with big Android tablets
Verdict: The Nexus 10 actually runs Lollipop just fine—it's still an attractive-looking OS and performance is as good as it was in KitKat. It's just that there aren't many reasons to use an Android tablet with a screen this large, and if Google isn't willing to make its redesigned OS and apps work great on these big widescreen tablets, why should other developers bother?

Title: Review: Tesla’s new Model S P85D—double your engines, double your fun
Summary: But at $130,000 loaded, it’s hard to overlook flaws—even if the car is McLaren F1-fast.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Product Name: Review: Tesla’s new Model S P85D—double your engines, double your fun
Verdict: I floored it and whacked my head against the head rest, giggling at the acceleration, then quickly let the car regen-brake back down to 30 miles per hour. I couldn’t help it. The feeling was just as impressive as the first time. Even if this wasn’t a McLaren F1, I felt like I was about to give up my own electric-powered pocket supercar.

Title: Review: iRig UA finally brings amp modelling to Android but lacks killer tone
Summary: Solid hardware and latency-free performance is let down by dated software, in-app purchases.
Author: Mark Walton
Pros: Well-constructed, portable hardware
Cons: Limited selection of core sounds
Product Name: Review: iRig UA finally brings amp modelling to Android but lacks killer tone

Title: Yoga Pro 3 review: Broadwell is a mixed blessing
Summary: The design is ever more exotic, but the performance is worse.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Beautiful screen
Cons: The Broadwell Y processor makes it slower than the old one
Product Name: Yoga Pro 3
Verdict: Can we recommend the Yoga Pro 3? I think so, but less whole-heartedly than the Yoga Pro 2. It's still a well-built, flexible, and attractive system. Just one that feels slightly more compromised than its predecessor.

Title: Asus’ Chromebook Flip looks and feels great, unless you’re typing on it
Summary: Review: $250 convertible Chromebook compromised by cramped keyboard.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Really nice design and build quality—it would be great in a laptop that cost two or three times as much.
Cons: A 10.1-inch screen feels pretty small, even compared to 11.6-inch screens.
Product Name: Asus’ Chromebook Flip looks and feels great, unless you’re typing on it
Verdict: For most people, we’d still recommend a Haswell Celeron Chromebook with 4GB of RAM for the best experience—

Title: First look: OS X El Capitan brings a little Snow Leopard to Yosemite
Summary: We spent a week with the first beta to save you from breaking your laptop.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: First look: OS X El Capitan brings a little Snow Leopard to Yosemite
Verdict: So, exciting? No, not really, not unless you're a window management enthusiast who is excited to dance on Helvetica Neue's grave (hi). But it's going to be a free update. It will, hopefully, feel solid right from launch day (this beta is a pretty good Beta 1 from a stability perspective, but buggy and crashy enough that it's far from a daily driver). And that will be fine.

Title: Xiaomi Mi 4i review—The best specs for $200, but not the best software
Summary: A Snapdragon 615 and 3120 mAh battery are a steal, but the skin needs updating.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Outstanding value for money.
Cons: MIUI was fine when it was replacing KitKat, but as an alternative to Lollipop's Material Design, it feels dated. Everything has been paved over with the KitKat-era UI, so a lot of features are missing.
Product Name: Xiaomi Mi 4i review—The best specs for $200, but not the best software
Verdict: For now, we have a phone with definitively better specs than the current low-price champ, the Moto G, but the Mi 4i offers worse software. Normally it would be a tough decision if both of these phones were equally easy to buy, but Xiaomi only sells phones in China, India, and a handful of other territories. For now, the decision has been made for us.

Title: First look: iOS 9 public beta is the update the iPad deserves
Summary: A smallish update for phones is a Mac-sized leap for tablets.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: First look: iOS 9 public beta is the update the iPad deserves
Verdict: If you're at all interested in the public beta and you have an iPad Air 2, iPad Air, iPad Mini 2, or iPad Mini 3, that's the hardware that will see the most benefit from the upgrade. It will run more-or-less fine on anything from the iPhone 5 up to the iPhone 6, but unless you have a phone you can dedicate to testing, we think the potential risks outweigh the rewards for you at this point. And those with Apple A5 hardware (the iPhone 4S, iPad 2, iPad Mini, and iPod Touch) should stay away for now—performance is bound to improve by the time the final release rolls around, but it's pretty inconsistent on that older hardware right now.

Title: Great gadget, small audience: The sixth-generation iPod Touch reviewed
Summary: iPhones have eaten the iPod, but this new release is still useful for specific purposes.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Fast. It includes a fully modern SoC and 802.11ac Wi-Fi, both of which keep things moving.
Cons: Missing a few iPhone niceties, including but not limited to TouchID, a vibration motor, a GPS, and an auto-brightness sensor.
Product Name: Great gadget, small audience: The sixth-generation iPod Touch reviewed
Verdict: The days of yearly (or even regular) iPod refreshes are long past, and a big hardware update won’t shove this thing out of its niche. But if you’re one of the few people in the market for one, the new iPod Touch is going to serve you much better than the old one.

Title: The Arlo and Flir FX security cameras: plug-and-play, mobile ready omnipresence
Summary: In which the author explores being the voyeur in her own house.
Author: Megan Geuss
Product Name: The Arlo and Flir FX security cameras: plug-and-play, mobile ready omnipresence
Verdict: And of course, ghosts don't exist, so you'll never catch any of those anyway. (Or will you?!)

Title: Nexus 6 review—The “premium” price still comes with compromises
Summary: Slow storage hurts load times, multitasking on Google's new flagship. Plus, why 6 inches?
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Lollipop isn't perfect, but it's the best Android update in years.
Cons: Really slow sequential read times means slow app loading and multitasking.
Product Name: Nexus 6 review—The “premium” price still comes with compromises
Verdict: Given that we're lacking in the storage speed department and neither the battery nor software takes advantage of the massive size of the device, the Nexus 6 is a tough sell at $650. The $350 Nexus 5 has held up well, but it's out of the running thanks to the lack of a voice chip enabling the fantastic new always-on features. For now, we guess that makes the best Lollipop device the 2014 Moto X.

Title: Android 5.0 Lollipop, thoroughly reviewed
Summary: Android's biggest update ever revamps nearly every part of the OS.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Material Design brings a fresh, beautiful look to the entire OS.
Cons: no phone support for landscape in the home screen and lock screen.
Product Name: Android 5.0 Lollipop, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: As it stands now, Lollipop is a great foundation for the future. Its visible changes are nice, but they are only the beginning of an Android ecosystem upgrade.

Title: Nvidia Shield Tablet review: Great gaming, great price, terrible battery
Summary: Nvidia delivers the best Android tablet this side of a Nexus.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Stellar gaming specs for the price
Cons: Stuttering and pauses between app switches are too common
Product Name: Nvidia Shield Tablet
Verdict: So long as you can stomach the thickness and hold out hope for a patch to resolve its slight performance issues—and hellish battery drain—this is your best 2014 bang-for-the-buck tablet option by a long shot, whether you game or not.

Title: Microsoft’s mid-range Lumia 735 and 830 reviewed: price is a problem
Summary: The phones aren't really the issue. We actually like the phones.
Author: Peter Bright
Product Name: Microsoft’s mid-range Lumia 735 and 830 reviewed: price is a problem
Verdict: Both of these phones should be priced in the ballpark of the Moto G, and they'd be easy to recommend if they were. Right now, however, they're overpriced to the point of irrelevance. They're both nice phones. We just can't imagine any scenario to buy at these prices.

Title: The BlackBerry Passport enigma: TCOB-machine or “worst designed thing, ever”
Summary: Review: It’s not your teenager’s smartphone, which is kind of the point.
Author: Sean Gallagher
Pros: Business features make Passport a real workhorse for the "always be closing" crowd.
Cons: AT&T is the exclusive carrier in the US and doesn't even mention the phone on its site—let alone sell it.
Product Name: The BlackBerry Passport enigma: TCOB-machine or “worst designed thing, ever”
Verdict: Still, I'm personally now willing to consider what was once unthinkable—a jump back to a BlackBerry for my next phone upgrade—if my carrier (AT&T) ever gets around to offering it on contract. And if my employer were to force me to use one, I wouldn't complain that much.

Product Name: iWork ’14
Verdict: Being free for all users is a mixed blessing. Sure, it's always nice to save the money, but by teaching users that software should be free, Apple is making life harder for independent developers. And that likely leaves all of us with even fewer viable choices in the future (again, a daunting scenario—

Title: Yoga Tablet 2 Pro review: So close to being good
Summary: Bulky and underpowered, but multitasking and projector gimmick get our attention.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: A bright, beautiful 13.3-inch screen matched with legitimate Android multitasking
Cons: Uh, this thing is HUGE
Product Name: Yoga Tablet 2 Pro
Verdict: We'd gladly pay $100 more to bolster even half of those complaints in a future revision, and should that revision come along, we'll hold the next massive Yoga Tablet Pro model up high. We didn't walk away feeling like the machine was an undercooked tablet with a mere projection gimmick thrown on top, but we're also perfectly aware of the $500-700 range of 13-inch, touch-enabled devices that can handle users' needs on the go and

Title: Learning the science behind silencers on the range with SilencerCo
Summary: Hollywood gets it consistently wrong—in the real world, they're merely less loud.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Product Name: Learning the science behind silencers on the range with SilencerCo
Verdict: The precision manufacturing necessary to produce an effective suppressor far exceeds what the average person can bang out in their garage; SilencerCo does all of their own design and manufacturing at their Utah facility with millions of dollars' worth of CNC capability. The result is a pleasant earmuff-free shooting experience—and as someone who has spent a fair amount of shooting time with earmuffs on, that’s a good thing. If I actually owned any guns that were compatible with SilencerCo’s products, I’d likely spring for a suppressor myself.

Title: The Lumia 535: Microsoft’s first phone reviewed
Summary: Is a low-end flagship a thing? It should be.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: 1GB RAM
Cons: The camera button will be forever mourned
Product Name: The Lumia 535: Microsoft’s first phone reviewed
Verdict: Should this kind of pricing come to the US, the Lumia 535 will be truly the king of the entry-level smartphones: a well-built handset with all the features you need, a nice big screen, and for the price, some great cameras.

Title: Don’t call it a netbook (or a “Chromebook killer”)—HP’s $200 Stream 11 reviewed
Summary: Windows adds much-needed versatility, but low-end hardware limits it anyway.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: $200, or $230 for the 13-inch model.
Cons: Bay Trail Celerons are markedly slower than the Haswell ones that were more common a year ago.
Product Name: Don’t call it a netbook (or a “Chromebook killer”)—HP’s $200 Stream 11 reviewed
Verdict: Outside of that niche, Chromebooks can still be difficult to recommend as general-purpose PCs—all else being equal, we think most home users will be better off with a Windows computer than a Chromebook. Don't even stop to consider it if you're a power user seeking an inexpensive primary laptop, but if you just need a well-built Windows PC for as little money as possible, the Stream should be the first place you look even if you end up buying something more flexible.

Summary: Instead of telling you what's "best," let us tell you what we liked the most.
Author: Andrew Cunningham

Verdict: Best of all, it’s still dirt-cheap for an unlocked, travel-friendly handset. If you’re in the market for a larger powerhouse phone, put your name into OnePlus’ stupid invite-only hat. Who knows—by the time they draw your name, they may have announced an even dreamier follow-up device.

Title: The state of smartphones in 2014: Ars Technica’s Ultimate Guide

Title: Review: In its second generation, the Moto X becomes a true flagship
Summary: We miss the smaller size, but everything about this $499 phone feels high-end.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Everything about this new Moto X looks and feels high-end.
Cons: Leather back looks nice but scuffs pretty easily.
Product Name: Review: In its second generation, the Moto X becomes a true flagship
Verdict: If we have one major criticism, it's that the new Moto X just doesn't feel as good to hold as the old one did. It doesn't feel bad—the contours and curves see to that—but the original Moto X crammed a 4.7-inch display into a phone that felt much smaller than that. It was unique in a field where most OEMs seem to have settled on five inches as a reasonably average screen size. Large-screened phones are undeniably popular, so it probably makes better business sense for Motorola to go with the flow. Still, we can't help but feel a little wistful when we pick up the original Moto X.

Title: Space-ready materials, race-tuned dynamics—meet the most credible Corvette yet
Summary: Ignore its shine to see aerospace design, a top drawer engine, and race-ready interiors.
Author: Jonathan M. Gitlin
Product Name: Space-ready materials, race-tuned dynamics—meet the most credible Corvette yet
Verdict: So the 2014 Stingray may be a luxury, but if you're in the market for that, it's quite the luxury to have. Chevrolet has bettered the technology, maintained the sleek and drool-worthy exterior, and managed to create a car that can both function day-to-day

Title: Android Wear hardware review: Sometimes promising, often frustrating
Summary: The Samsung Gear Live and LG G Watch aren't as essential as they want to be.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Fluid UI performance.
Cons: Android 4.3 and 4.4 required. Forget earlier versions, forget alternative OSes.
Product Name: Android Wear hardware
Verdict: Maybe Android Wear will be useful enough to become indispensable in six months. Maybe the Moto 360 will strike a balance between semi-useful-thing and fashion accessory that hits a mass-market nerve. Right now, though, these watches are like their predecessors in that their promise is greater than their real-world utility. I might miss a couple things about the Gear Live when I take it off my wrist and ship it back to Google, but it's not going to be difficult to part with.

Title: Exclusive: A review of the Blackphone, the Android for the paranoid
Summary: Custom-built with privacy in mind, this handset isn’t for (Google) Play.
Author: Sean Gallagher
Pros: Excellent Security Center feature of PrivatOS does what stock Android should do, giving you fine control over app permissions.
Cons: The phone’s performance, while acceptable, is mediocre (even though it isn’t the phone’s selling point).
Product Name: Exclusive: A review of the Blackphone, the Android for the paranoid
Verdict: What’s really important in the end about the Blackphone is that it has made the idea of a privacy-focused phone a reality—and it opens a conversation about what security technology can do for average people. And if it brings enough people into the conversation, the next generation of the Blackphone, and of mobile security products in general, could reach a much wider audience—and perhaps force some of the bigger mobile players to pay more attention to privacy.

Title: HP EliteBook 1020 review: A business Ultrabook you’ll want to bring home
Summary: Core M needs speed and the trackpad is weird, but there's a lot to like here.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Attractive design that’s consistent with some other HP laptops.
Cons: CPU and GPU performance is lower than regular Haswell-U laptops—we’d like to see a Broadwell-U version with a PCIe SSD, even if it meant adding a fan.
Product Name: HP EliteBook 1020
Verdict: The biggest problem is probably the price, honestly—some of the 1020's value-adds, including NFC and the fingerprint reader, aren't even included in the $1,199 base model. If you’re willing to put up with a fan, you’ll be able to find Broadwell or even Haswell-U laptops of a similar size and weight but better performance and lower prices.

Title: $1,099 iMac review: Lose 50% of your performance to save 18% of the money
Summary: MacBook-turned-desktop isn't bad, but only makes sense if you're buying in bulk.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: The iMac is still an attractive, capable all-in-one computer.
Cons: Spinning hard drives. Spring for the Fusion Drive upgrade.
Product Name: $1,099 iMac
Verdict: Finally, there's the matter of the chip inside this thing: it's a little strange that, with Intel's next-generation Broadwell architecture just months away, Apple would release a new Haswell-based computer to the masses. As with the price, it's probably best explained by this thing's intended audience—we're right around the point when schools are going to be replacing old computers with new ones. For regular people who don't need a computer right this very second, try to hold out for the next model.

Title: OnePlus One review: Big, fast, cheap, open, efficient, and unlocked
Summary: But there's a catch—It's hard as hell to actually buy one.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Astounding battery life averages 1.5 days of heavy use per full charge, even with a bright screen and meaty specs taking their toll.
Cons: A little too huge for comfortable one-hand use, even after shrinking the screen by enabling on-screen buttons.
Product Name: OnePlus One
Verdict: If you can accept those caveats (and get into the invite pool), you can look forward to a highlight of the modern Android generation.

Title: FLIR One gives your iPhone infrared Predator vision
Summary: For $349, you too can see in the dark like an intergalactic big game hunter.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Dead easy to use—very much an "it just works" device
Cons: No Android or Windows Phone compatibility—iPhone only
Product Name: FLIR One gives your iPhone infrared Predator vision
Verdict: From that perspective, this is a damned interesting device. If this cost $99 instead of $349, I’d buy it in an instant. And I suspect that in a couple of years and after a few iterations, that price point is exactly where FLIR’s consumer products will be.

Title: The big One: Ars reviews the HTC One Max
Summary: Not quite an HTC One successor, the One Max loses a lot, gains 1.2"
Author: Jason Inofuentes
Pros: So much like the HTC One
Cons: So huge, but with no stylus or UI tweaks to account for it
Product Name: The big One: Ars reviews the HTC One Max
Verdict: The only laudable improvement over the One is the One Max’s battery life. From there, things either stay the same or suffer. In the end, we’d have preferred to see a big refresh to the HTC One, rather than a great, big One.

Title: KDE Plasma 5—For those Linux users undecided on the kernel’s future
Summary: Review—new release straddles traditional desktop needs, long term multi-device plans.
Author: Scott Gilbertson
Product Name: KDE Plasma 5—For those Linux users undecided on the kernel’s future
Verdict: What's perhaps most heartening about this release is that KDE has managed to get a lot of the groundwork done for alternate interfaces without messing with their desktop interface much at all. The speed improvements are also good news. If you've tried KDE in the past and found it too "heavy," you might want to give Plasma 5 a fresh look.

Title: Xiaomi Mi4 review: China’s iPhone killer is unoriginal but amazing
Summary: A big iPhone that runs Android ends up being the best of both worlds.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Impeccable build quality. One of the most premium feeling Android phones out there.
Cons: Unoriginal design. Everything looks like something else, usually something from Apple.
Product Name: Xiaomi Mi4
Verdict: Everything here is top notch: The best specs, fantastic build quality, a beautiful screen, a dirt cheap price, and software that, while different, works both aesthetically and functionally. If only the company came up with its own hardware design. If Xiaomi ever does apply itself with some original designs, look out world, because this company will be going places.

Title: Western Digital My Cloud Review: The $150 personal cloud
Summary: WD's small single-disk network storage system is surprisingly cheap and good.
Author: Jason Inofuentes
Pros: $150 gets you a $100 drive and a pretty solid $50 NAS
Cons: No per share size limits means you might fill your drive with Time Machine backups
Product Name: Western Digital My Cloud Review: The $150 personal cloud
Verdict: For the capacity and the convenience, the WD My Cloud is a solid choice for backing up files from your PCs and mobile phones on your home network. It’s big enough to serve double duty as a media server and easy enough to configure for almost anyone. Plus, there's plenty of support from WD. Add to that the ability to easily access your files from outside of your home network, and you’ve got a lot of features for not a lot of cash. The experience isn’t perfect, for sure. But for the value, the WD My Cloud makes an awfully good case for itself.

Cons: Windows Phone really is better with a camera button.
Product Name: HTC One (M8) for Windows: Crazy name, great phone
Verdict: For the time being, this means that Verizon has the two best Windows Phone phones on the market. The Lumia Icon is Verizon exclusive (and it looks unlikely that its Lumia 930 sibling will ever make its way to American shores), and right now, so is the HTC One (M8) for Windows. It will eventually come to AT&T too, but there's no public indication of when that will happen.

Title: Review: Mophie’s Space Pack doubles your iPhone’s battery, storage, and size
Summary: 16 and 32GB battery cases try to solve three problems at once with mixed results.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: More than doubles battery life, while offering extra protection
Cons: Bulkier than most iPhone cases
Product Name: Review: Mophie’s Space Pack doubles your iPhone’s battery, storage, and size
Verdict: This is an accessory that will appeal mostly to Apple diehards who use their phones all the time and want to carry as much of their stuff with them as possible. There are better cases out there if protecting your phone is Job One, and Mophie's stand-alone batteries are better if you've got something to charge that isn't an iPhone 5 or 5S.

Title: Sony Z Ultra Google Play Edition Review: big, beautiful, and buggy
Summary: Sony made a great piece of hardware, but someone dropped the ball on the software.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Outstanding build quality
Cons: The camera, unless your favorite color is
Product Name: Sony Z Ultra Google Play Edition Review: big, beautiful, and buggy
Verdict: While the device has yet to be delivered to consumers, the bugs on our review unit are awful. If you are thinking about getting a Sony Z Ultra, wait for an OTA update first. Right now we can't sideload apps, or set a lock screen, or uninstall anything. It all makes the device pretty hard to live with.

Title: A Nexus 8, more or less: LG’s G Pad 8.3 Google Play edition reviewed
Summary: Google's software and LG's hardware make for an appealing, if imperfect, tablet.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Nice hardware that looks and feels good
Cons: Screen doesn't get as bright as either the Nexus 7 or the Retina mini
Product Name: A Nexus 8, more or less: LG’s G Pad 8.3 Google Play edition reviewed
Verdict: The one aspect in which the G Pad could stand to be more like a Nexus is in price—$349 isn't unheard of for an Android tablet, but if you can stand a slightly smaller screen, the Nexus 7 can be had for over $100 less. This close to $400, the Retina iPad mini is the better buy—it has a slightly denser screen, better performance, better battery life, and a much stronger app and media ecosystem. None of that will matter to you if you can't abide iOS, but things that are easy to overlook in the Nexus 7 become more difficult to dismiss when you put an iPad and an Android tablet on even financial footing.

Title: Smallness über alles: Intel’s tiny, Haswell-based NUC desktop reviewed
Summary: Diminutive desktop is a workstation, game console, and HTPC all rolled into one.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: So small. Much tiny.
Cons: Not as cost-effective as building your own
Product Name: Smallness über alles: Intel’s tiny, Haswell-based NUC desktop reviewed
Verdict: The NUC isn't for you if you're looking for a ton of computational power, or if you're looking to get the most computer bang for your buck. This computer is modern and reasonably fast on the inside and the price stacks up reasonably well next to tiny PC offerings from the OEMs, but if you have more room it's not difficult to buy or build yourself something faster for less money. If what you're looking for is a decent desktop that will fit anywhere and look pretty good doing it, the NUC is well worth considering, and it's a nice improvement over the Ivy Bridge version.

Title: A pro with serious workstation needs reviews Apple’s 2013 Mac Pro
Summary: Apple’s latest Mac Pro is powerful, but it isn’t always a clear upgrade.
Author: Dave Girard
Pros: Impossibly quiet operation, even under load.
Cons: Some low OpenGL results for the FirePro D700 in OS X need to be addressed.
Product Name: A pro with serious workstation needs reviews Apple’s 2013 Mac Pro
Verdict: It sounds like ending on a sour note, but I am cautiously optimistic about the newly shrunken Mac Pro. Apple has made an exceptional machine for the future that just needs some tweaks to really shine. It's a machine the company could be proud of at any point in its history.

Title: Review: A $229 unlocked phone that marries the Galaxy S5 to the Moto G
Summary: Kogan's Agora 4G is a solid midrange phone with a couple of quirks.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: All-plastic construction, but it feels solid instead of cheap and slippery.
Cons: Has a removable back, but no removable battery.
Product Name: Review: A $229 unlocked phone that marries the Galaxy S5 to the Moto G
Verdict: If you want a competent Android phone and don't want to pay $500 or $600 or more for the privilege, an small but growing group of phones in the $150 to $250 range are coming out of the woodwork to suit your needs. Given that even the US carriers are slowly moving away from subsidies (and that many markets worldwide never relied on them in the first place), that's got to be scary for any company making most of its money from more expensive phones.

Title: Linux on the NUC: Using Ubuntu, Mint, Fedora, and the SteamOS beta
Summary: Intel's mini desktop handles four prominent distros with a few headaches.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Linux on the NUC: Using Ubuntu, Mint, Fedora, and the SteamOS beta
Verdict: For more advanced users who don't mind these kinds of hardware headaches (or simply don't intend to use Wi-Fi), the NUC is a capable little Linux box. Assuming you can get the hardware working the way you want, the system's power consumption numbers are impressive, and the small fan is no more annoying than it is under Windows. If you're a Linux neophyte looking for a completely seamless experience, the NUC isn't quite there, but there's nothing wrong with it that can't be fixed by a few driver and BIOS updates down the line.

Title: Mini-review: People who already use Office will love Office for iPad
Summary: Better-late-than-never effort will please its core audience, but others have moved on.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: Microsoft Office for iPad is a great suite of applications that suffers from few Version-One-Point-Oh deficiencies, printing support aside. But by coming to market so late, Microsoft has missed the chance to appeal to people outside its (admittedly large) core audience.

Title: The Pebble Steel review: Wearables 2.0 arrive
Summary: With a new look and new SDK, Pebble sets the bar for all the wearables to come.
Author: Jason Inofuentes
Pros: Excellent design update makes Pebble look like a watch you'd wear on a date
Cons: The price might scare away thrifty shoppers, but they'd be best steered toward the original Pebble
Product Name: The Pebble Steel
Verdict: The Pebble Steel, and more importantly the Pebble platform, is the high bar. Any other manufacturer planning to release a smartwatch in 2014 should take notes.

Title: Synology offers a Dropbox substitute—meet the personal cloud
Summary: Cloud Station doesn't do everything you might need, but it does several things well.
Author: John Timmer
Product Name: Synology offers a Dropbox substitute—meet the personal cloud
Verdict: And Synology seems committed to improving its users' experience. As noted above, the client's auto update feature is new and solves what had been a seriously annoying problem. The client software itself is also significantly improved and appears to be adopting some visual cues from Microsoft's latest offerings. Things may get even more convenient soon: Synology is already plugging the next version of its firmware, which promises a QuickConnect that no longer needs any port forwarding to work.

Title: A turbo-charged, quad-core mini desktop: Gigabyte’s Brix Pro reviewed
Summary: A pretty capable workstation that can fit in the palm of your hand.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Lots of performance in a still-tiny box
Cons: Consumes as much as double the power of a Haswell NUC (but still pretty good for a full-on desktop)
Product Name: A turbo-charged, quad-core mini desktop: Gigabyte’s Brix Pro reviewed
Verdict: Any way you cut it, the worst thing about the Brix was also the worst thing about the NUC: by the time you buy the hardware and software you need to use the thing, you’ll have paid much more than you would have paid to build or buy a larger, more conventional desktop with an equal or greater amount of computing power. If you care more about size than performance or cost, these mini PCs make sense. If you care more about performance or cost than size, the value proposition just isn’t great.

Title: Refinements, additions, and un-breaking stuff: iOS 7.1 reviewed
Summary: Apple's first major iOS 7 update makes the operating system feel whole.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Improved performance across the board
Cons: No major, consistent battery life improvements
Product Name: Refinements, additions, and un-breaking stuff: iOS 7.1 reviewed
Verdict: iOS 7.1 will probably be iOS 7's last big update before iOS 8 comes out, assuming Apple sticks to its usual fall release schedule. Whatever new features and design tweaks we see when that happens, iOS 7.1 gives the company an excellent foundation to build on.

Title: Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro review: You say you want resolution
Summary: Lenovo’s thin, powerful tab-top brings the PPI. Can Windows 8 keep up?
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Full-screen multimedia looks stunning on the 13.3-inch, 1800p touchscreen.
Cons: Windows 8's ecosystem hasn’t caught up to this screen’s resolution, making this laptop falter in desktop mode.
Product Name: Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro
Verdict: If you seek a pristine, touch-screen multimedia portable, crossed with a capable notebook that (currently) works best using keyboard shortcuts, you’re the Yoga 2 Pro’s target audience. And if you don't mind the current issues getting in the way of this souped-up alternative to the likes of the Surface 2 Pro, then the price and package combined may be worth a few, if significant, GUI complaints. Otherwise, keep your fingers off its Windows 8 screen, and instead cross them until software developers catch up with Lenovo’s otherwise impressive hardware.

Title: Review: Asus crafts a tiny $179 Chromebox out of cheap, low-power parts
Summary: It's too bad that booting into non-Chrome OS operating systems is so difficult.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Small
Cons: Medium-to-heavy users will want more RAM
Product Name: Review: Asus crafts a tiny $179 Chromebox out of cheap, low-power parts
Verdict: If there's even one must-have, accept-no-substitutes Windows application you need, though, Chrome OS becomes a much tougher sell. This is still probably the biggest factor that will keep you from replacing lightly used family Windows desktops at home with Chromeboxes.

Title: Review: Dell’s Venue 8 Pro is a Windows tablet you might actually want to buy
Summary: Better hardware and software address worst flaws of early 8-inch Windows tablets.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Snappy performance in an attractive package
Cons: A little larger and bulkier than some Android and iOS tablets
Product Name: Review: Dell’s Venue 8 Pro is a Windows tablet you might actually want to buy
Verdict: If you need Windows on a small tablet, the Venue 8 Pro is one of the few we would actually recommend. It's fast enough, attractive enough, and comfortable enough. Regular people buying their first tablet will still be served better by Android or iOS, but Dell, Intel, and Microsoft are beginning to close that gap.

Title: Haswell saves another Ultrabook: The 2014 Toshiba Kirabook reviewed
Summary: Just ignore the high starting price and Windows' scaling issues.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Sturdy, attractive design with good port selection
Cons: Fan spins up quite loudly under moderate-to-heavy load
Product Name: Haswell saves another Ultrabook: The 2014 Toshiba Kirabook reviewed
Verdict: Pricing aside, Windows and its applications continue to be the single biggest argument against buying a PC with a high-density screen. Not to drive the point into the ground, but if you install 10 different third-party applications, you're likely to see 10 different ways in which those applications aren't made for high-res screens. Improving this situation is going to happen one application at a time, and it's only going to happen as more PCs pick up these high-density screens, but early adopters are going to be putting up with inconsistently scaled elements for the foreseeable future.

Title: Haswell to the rescue: Acer’s refreshed Aspire S7 Ultrabook reviewed
Summary: The keyboard and the price are the only remaining barriers to entry.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Attractively styled and well-built
Cons: Keyboard still uses an odd layout that seems unnecessary given the unused space in the palmrest
Product Name: Haswell to the rescue: Acer’s refreshed Aspire S7 Ultrabook reviewed
Verdict: If there’s one non-keyboard-related thing to complain about, it may actually be the price. The S7 starts at a whopping $1,399.99, which will get you the Core i5-4200U, 128GB of storage, and 8GB of RAM. Stepping up to the faster Core i7-4500U and 256GB of storage will run you $1,649.99. By comparison, a 2013 MacBook Air with 128GB of storage and 8GB of RAM costs $1,199.99, and stepping up to a faster processor and 256GB of storage will run you $1,549.99 (if you just want the larger SSD and not the faster processor, that costs $1,399.99—there’s no way to get one without the other in the S7). Compared to the Air and some of its other Ultrabook contemporaries, there’s no denying that the asking price is steep.

Title: Review: Qualcomm’s Toq smartwatch lasts an extra, extra, extra long time
Summary: 5+ days of battery life are great—unfortunately, not much else about the watch is.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Battery life—it really does last five days or more
Cons: Definitely priced at the "crazy early adopter" crowd
Product Name: Review: Qualcomm’s Toq smartwatch lasts an extra, extra, extra long time
Verdict: KITT? Get me out of here, buddy.

Title: The Amazon Kindle Fire HDX: A tablet apart
Summary: The right display, the right silicon, and, maybe, the right tablet.
Author: Jason Inofuentes
Pros: Through calibration, this is now the best screen on an Android tablet
Cons: No Google means the company's communication services aren't there
Product Name: The Amazon Kindle Fire HDX: A tablet apart
Verdict: The Amazon Kindle HDX is a powerful, capable device with one of the best displays we’ve ever seen. Amazon has produced a top-tier device whose only condition is adoption of its services. If you’re a longtime Amazon Video and MP3 customer, that's great news.

Author: Brian Won
Product Name: Ars Technica System Guide: Bargain Box, April 2014
Verdict: As is the case with the HTPC, a full discussion of what might be a DIY storage server is beyond the scope of the Bargain Box, but what's laid out above again provides a surprisingly suitable baseline.

Title: Review: Garmin HUD is sharp, functional, pricey
Summary: The device works great, but it does nothing without a smartphone plus a pricey app.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Cons: Very visible and crisp display
Product Name: Review: Garmin HUD is sharp, functional, pricey
Verdict: So I liked it. It worked well. But I'd still choke on the price if I were buying one for myself.

Title: Review: LG’s G2 smartphone gets caught living in the shadows of giants
Summary: LG makes a great device, but Samsung and Google crush any reasons to buy it.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: KnockOn. Double tapping to wake your phone completely changes the way you use it
Cons: All of LG's software design
Product Name: Review: LG’s G2 smartphone gets caught living in the shadows of giants
Verdict: It sounds harsh, but I can't come up with a single reason to buy a G2 right now. Samsung makes the same thing with a removable battery and SD card, and Google is going to take everything good about this phone and pair it with KitKat in a month or two. The G2 is stuck between the two biggest forces in smartphones with nothing unique enough to warrant attention.

Title: Blue, green, yellow, white, and pink are the new black: The iPhone 5C reviewed
Summary: Take one iPhone 5, remove $100, and add one rainbow of plastic. Market aggressively.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: The iPhone 5's hardware has aged pretty well, and even without internal changes the 5C is competitive with similarly priced offerings from other companies
Cons: Phone's speaker is noticeably muffled-sounding compared to the 5 and 5S
Product Name: Blue, green, yellow, white, and pink are the new black: The iPhone 5C reviewed
Verdict: That's the 5C in a nutshell. Apple's positioning and marketing of the phone and its implications for the future are ultimately more noteworthy than this particular phone itself. That's not to say it's a bad phone by any stretch. Minor component differences aside, it's mostly an iPhone 5 in a colorful plastic shell. It's only technically "new," but that may be as new as it needs to be.

Title: Review: Thunderstorm iPad speaker-case is a boombox for the digital era
Summary: Get out your rollerblades and hotpants: Belkin's new case makes your iPad louder.
Author: Megan Geuss
Pros: Excellent, room filling sound
Cons: A bit expensive for an older-model-iPad case (though Belkin says it will have a new version for the latest iPad model sometime in May or June of this year).
Product Name: Review: Thunderstorm iPad speaker-case is a boombox for the digital era
Verdict: All in all, if you move your iPad occasionally—that is, it doesn't always stay in one place but you're not commuting with it daily—this is just the case for you. You can still plug in your headphones when you're on the go, but you don't have to carry along an extra dock or speaker if you want to use your iPad to watch movies and play games in multiple rooms of your house or in a hotel room. This could similarly work for the strong-of-stomach riding in the back of your car on a road trip, or for the bodybuilders who want to blast their iTunes library from their shoulders as they rollerblade along the beach.

Title: The Seagate Wireless Plus portable hard drive—when 128GB just isn’t enough
Summary: Ars reviews a solution to store all your media, stream it to iOS or Android devices.
Author: Florence Ion
Product Name: The Seagate Wireless Plus portable hard drive—when 128GB just isn’t enough

Title: Review: Samsung’s Galaxy Note 10.1 may need more time in the oven
Summary: Want to watch a movie while jotting down notes and checking Twitter? Don't.
Author: Jason Inofuentes
Pros: Charming 10.1-inch 2560×1600 display
Cons: Janky and unresponsive UI
Product Name: Review: Samsung’s Galaxy Note 10.1 may need more time in the oven
Verdict: The Mama Palma's margherita pizza is divine, as is the sundried tomato over mascarpone with pistachios. Less successful, for me, is the Peking Duck. It tries to be the pizza for the guy who wanted Chinese food but finds himself instead in a pizza parlor. It's trying too hard. The Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 (2014 edition) has reached just a little too far in the interest of features and costs. And what rewards are garnered by those concessions to cost? With a sticker price of $550, the savings certainly aren't being passed on to the buyer. There are plenty of reasons that this might be the right tablet for you; I just can't recommend a product with more warts than beauty marks. This menu is awfully big, and if nothing looks good, there's always Lorenzo's.

Title: Review: HP’s $279 Chromebook 11 raises an admittedly low bar
Summary: But beware: even a pretty nice Chromebook is still a Chromebook.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Great-looking IPS display
Cons: No SD card slot
Product Name: Review: HP’s $279 Chromebook 11 raises an admittedly low bar
Verdict: The Chromebook 11 removes at least a few of those compromises. Too many cheap laptops are crippled by bad screens and crappy keyboards, and HP and Google get both of them right here. The build quality is fine for the price, though the screen wobbles and hairline scratches in the glossy plastic finish will eventually be an issue, even if you're careful with it. Performance is the biggest sticking point, since it’s basically in the same place that the Samsung Chromebook left it last year—Chromebooks with Intel’s Haswell CPUs will offer both superior performance and better battery life, and we’ll be giving them a closer look as they’re released. Hopefully one day soon we’ll be able to get a cheap Chromebook that’s reasonably fast

Title: To touch or not to touch: Poking the Windows 8 version of Lenovo’s Ultrabook

Title: Review: XPS 12’s Haswell upgrade improves an already-good convertible PC
Summary: Dell improves the battery life but doesn't fix what isn't broken.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Same great construction and 1080p touchscreen as last year
Cons: A chunky tablet at best
Product Name: Review: XPS 12’s Haswell upgrade improves an already-good convertible PC
Verdict: That said, the new XPS 12 isn’t a huge upgrade from last year. If you’ve been waiting on a Haswell version of the laptop to boost battery life, this revised version is the answer to those prayers. If the older XPS 12 wasn’t your cup of tea for other reasons, go ahead and move on—this is just a slightly updated version of the same laptop.

Title: Review: Sony’s VAIO Flip 13 dies the death of a thousand cuts
Summary: Pen input is a great feature, but the complete package is better on paper than in person.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Attractive styling
Cons: Despite aluminum and plastic construction, the laptop is overly flexible throughout
Product Name: Review: Sony’s VAIO Flip 13 dies the death of a thousand cuts
Verdict: There’s still plenty to recommend here. The digitizer is a big plus for fans of pen input, and we like the full-size palmrest and trackpad of the Flip 13 more than we like the ones included in the pen-centric

Title: Death by incompatibility: A Samsung Galaxy Gear review
Summary: Samsung built a smartwatch but forgot to make it do stuff.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: First!
Cons: It makes no single part of your smartphone usage easier
Product Name: Death by incompatibility: A Samsung Galaxy Gear review
Verdict: Do not buy this device expecting apps to show up and save the day. Taking a serious stab at ecosystem building is one thing, but the limited device compatibility means the only "developer" that will initially be supporting this watch is Samsung itself. Judging by what software is available at launch, Samsung may find that being a one-company ecosystem is extremely difficult. Samsung's thinking seems to be that if you make it to market first, you'll magically grow an ecosystem. But by not having a robust ecosystem in place, Samsung isn't giving consumers a compelling reason to buy its product in the first place. In my time testing the Gear and trying to integrate it into my life, I was left with the impression that I was wearing little more than a $300 wrist vibrator.

Title: Review: Kaleidescape’s $3995 Cinema One is everything except affordable
Summary: Fancy movie machine rips, downloads, and catalogs your disc collections.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Extremely easy to set up—no more complex than plugging in a DVD player
Cons: Blu-ray discs have to be in the player—or in an extremely expensive add-on vault—to play, even after being ripped
Product Name: Review: Kaleidescape’s $3995 Cinema One is everything except affordable
Verdict: Still, it's nice to dream.

Title: The Nokia Lumia 1020: The smartphone to render point-and-shoots obsolete
Summary: Review: Shoehorning a huge sensor into a smartphone does result in a great camera.
Author: Peter Bright
Product Name: The Nokia Lumia 1020: The smartphone to render point-and-shoots obsolete
Verdict: Unlocked and available on any network, I think the Lumia 1020 would be easy to recommend. But the price and exclusivity makes it a much trickier proposition. If I used AT&T anyway, I would go for it. But I wouldn't switch networks for this phone—or any other.

Title: Review: Lumia 928 is screentastic, camerarific
Summary: PureView camera does well in low light, and PenTile AMOLED looks great with WP8.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Brilliant, beautiful AMOLED display
Cons: AMOLED display is PenTile, which is going to make some people angry no matter what
Product Name: Review: Lumia 928 is screentastic, camerarific
Verdict: Still, if I were buying a new smartphone today, this one would be pretty darn near the top of the list.

Title: Review: Android 4.3’s multitude of minor changes future-proofs the platform
Summary: New Jelly Bean is faster, more power-efficient, more secure, and still fragmented.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Three versions in, Jelly Bean is refined without feeling stale, and stock Android continues to be our preferred Android experience
Cons: Few major user-facing changes
Product Name: Review: Android 4.3’s multitude of minor changes future-proofs the platform
Verdict: Finally, it's worth noting that (thanks in part to the Google Play edition program) Google is officially supporting more hardware than ever before with the Android 4.3 release—three tablets and four phones. I've seen Android fans mock Apple's iPhones and iPads because new iOS versions rarely bring all of their new features to

Title: Review: High-PPI Toshiba Kirabook goes after Retina MacBook Pro
Summary: Price, Intel's impending refresh, desktop scaling undermine likable Ultrabook.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good screen, excellent build quality, and thoughtful design
Cons: No 5GHz Wi-Fi, an unfortunate oversight for a device this expensive
Product Name: Review: High-PPI Toshiba Kirabook goes after Retina MacBook Pro
Verdict: Finally, the most unfortunate part for Toshiba is that the worst thing about the Kirabook—the often-blurry, inconsistent mess that is Windows' desktop scaling—isn't really anything it or even Microsoft can wholly remedy. The companies are at the mercy of third-party application developers, some of which don't properly support high-ppi displays in Windows despite supporting them in OS X (or even on the Chromebook Pixel, in Google's case). As was the case when the Retina MacBook Pro launched, buyers will have to wait for all of these applications to update before the things on their screens look as good as they're capable of looking. And if your software won't take advantage of the screen's extra density, why not consider one of the many cheaper 1080p alternatives?

Title: Cheaper than most, better than all: the 2013 Nexus 7 reviewed
Summary: Great screen, fast internals make this refreshed tablet a great deal at any price.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Gorgeous screen
Cons: Speaker placement may be awkward in landscape mode
Product Name: Cheaper than most, better than all: the 2013 Nexus 7 reviewed
Verdict: Even with the slight price hike, the Nexus 7 has once again set the bar for not just small Android tablets, but all small tablets from all ecosystems. If Apple responds with a Retina-equipped iPad mini in the fall, the balance of power may shift back in the other direction. But if it sticks with its current display, it will become more difficult to recommend.

Title: ThinkPad quality, tablet-style: Lenovo’s ThinkPad Tablet 2 reviewed
Summary: The best an Intel Atom-powered tablet can be, at least until later this year.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Clover Trail runs all of your desktop apps without making the tablet too large, heavy, or hot
Cons: Keyboard layout itself is good, but dock doesn't allow for multiple screen angles and doesn't extend the tablet's battery life
Product Name: ThinkPad quality, tablet-style: Lenovo’s ThinkPad Tablet 2 reviewed

Title: Review: Lego Mindstorms EV3 means giant robots, powerful computers
Summary: My inner 9-year-old is blown away, but my outer 35-year-old balks at the $349 price.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Product Name: Review: Lego Mindstorms EV3 means giant robots, powerful computers
Verdict: Still, price is really the only downside to this set. They're ludicrously fun to play with, and I had a great time sitting on the floor like a kid piecing a robot together (and the whole process was made even better by the fact that I got to do it on the clock!). It's hard to deny that making robots and then programming them to do your bidding is just straight-up

Title: HTC First review: Don’t call it the Facebook phone
Summary: Instead, Facebook Home is here. So how does the app integrate into this handset?
Author: Florence Ion
Pros: First is stylish, feels great in the palm of your hand
Cons: Awkward placement of micro-USB charging port on the side of the phone
Product Name: HTC First
Verdict: Android is one of the most widely used operating systems, so it makes sense that Facebook would target this demographic. With a mid-range handset that's affordable and allows users to remove the Facebook Home application, it offers the aura of choice. Ultimately, the purchase question still hinges on whether you really want a social network to be the driving force on a device that you use daily.

Title: 480GB is the new 240GB: Crucial’s M500 SSD reviewed
Summary: SSDs are cheaper than ever. How does the latest generation stack up?
Author: Geoff Gasior, The Tech  Report
Product Name: 480GB is the new 240GB: Crucial’s M500 SSD reviewed
Verdict: Crucial seems to have focused more on capacity than performance with the M500, and that's probably a good thing for consumers transitioning from mechanical storage. Even the 240GB model trounces traditional hard drives. That said, discerning enthusiasts should skip the M500 unless they're shopping for the 480 or 960GB models. That 960GB monster is the real star of the lineup in terms of both sheer capacity and overall value. No wonder it's sold out pretty much everywhere.

Title: How much would you pay for a stylus? Samsung’s Galaxy Note 8.0 reviewed
Summary: The Note 8.0 is nearly a great tablet, but that $399 price tag gives us pause.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Better-made than the Note 10.1
Cons: Worse battery life than the competition
Product Name: How much would you pay for a stylus? Samsung’s Galaxy Note 8.0 reviewed
Verdict: It's possible that Samsung's branding, as well as the unique features the Note 8.0 brings to the table, will be enough to move units despite the price. Android tablets have historically needed to undercut the iPad on price to gain a foothold, though, and the Note 8.0 is in the unenviable position of being not only more expensive than the comparably specced iPad, but

Title: It just works: Dell XPS 13 Developer Edition Linux Ultrabook review
Summary: Dell's substantial investment in making a functional Linux Ultrabook pays off.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Trouble-free Linux on good hardware
Cons: One-handed opening leads to whole laptop lifting up instead of smoothly opening
Product Name: It just works: Dell XPS 13 Developer Edition Linux Ultrabook review
Verdict: "Maybe now there could once again be a Dell in my future. That to me is the truly amazing thing," Rick finished. Coming from an unrepentant Slackware reprobate who's been compiling his own kernels since I was in junior high, it was a pretty incredible admission.

Title: Review: All thumbs on deck with the BlackBerry Q10
Summary: A smartphone from an alternate universe where the iPhone was a flop.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Excellent build quality
Cons: BlackBerry 10 still doesn't have many apps

Verdict: The Q10 is a very solid and well-built little phone, and it's one of the few options available from any smartphone ecosystem for the physical keyboard holdouts. For most buyers, though, it's going to feel like a throwback, and we don't mean that in a good way.

Right now, though, when you buy Windows RT you're exchanging decades of Windows software development for an app store that's still in diapers. I had the time to explore and to find the ways in which I like to use the device, and even though the section on mods was the shortest part and likely has the least reader appeal, it's the portion of the device that I've enjoyed the most. Installing lighttpd on the thing and making my NAS accessible over the Web so that I can effectively carry my content with me was surprisingly easy, and the DS-412+ is both a joy to use and a joy to hack on. It was worth my money, and that's just about the best thing you can say for any bit of consumer electronics.

Mediocre battery life is our primary criticism, but if you can look past that the XPS 12 is the most convincing Windows 8 laptop we’ve gotten our hands on.

Title: Microsoft Surface with Windows 8 Pro: Hotter, Thicker, Faster, Louder

Verdict: Maybe other people can make use of the form factor better than I can. I'm sure the same markets that have used Windows tablets for the last decade will leap at Surface Pro—if they haven't already gone for the iPad. I'm sure some people will find it "good enough" as a laptop-like device, and for them it may be a viable purchase. But it's not for me.

Verdict: None of that mitigates the particular issues we have with the W510, but like the W700, it shows that an Intel tablet isn't quite as ludicrous as it might have seemed just a couple of years ago. The W700 needs to be thinner, lighter, and lose the fans, while the W510 needs to up its build quality and performance—if the Haswell or Bay Trail chips can bring us a Windows 8 tablet that can manage all of this, it will definitely help the OS fulfill its promise.

Its biggest challenge might be the way that American smartphone subsidies work—all things considered, you can easily buy a whole lot more phone for not much more money.

Verdict: Particularly perplexing is the lack of a standard SSD option in an age where most of Apple's laptops include them by default. You can get cheaper and larger SSDs than you could last year and Fusion Drive has proven itself to be a good, reliable way to mix SSD performance with HDD capacity, but even if you're buying the top-end iMac you still have to pay an extra $200 to eliminate the performance bottleneck that the mechanical hard drive has become. Owners of 2010 and 2011-model Airs who are looking to upgrade will see big boosts to GPU and storage performance, respectable boosts to CPU performance, and amazing boosts to battery life. Verdict: At this point, it's all subjective. Your decision to choose between the Google Play Edition of the Samsung Galaxy S 4 and Samsung's out-of-the-box version depends entirely on your own experience with the handset. I mostly enjoyed being able to use stock Android on the Galaxy S 4's form-factor. It's a stylish phone that feels good to hold in the palm of the hand, but it's made even better with stock Android as a part of the equation. The biggest setback may be how soon Google will push out updates for the phones, but the search giant has said that it's not solely responsible for the updates on the Google Play Edition of the phone. Samsung handles the kernel, while Google is merely behind the software that sits on top of it. In the end, this might be the deciding factor. If Samsung won't keep the Google Play Edition S 4's software up to date, its value will be significantly diminished.

Verdict: Long story short, if you currently own an iPhone that is not an iPhone 5, this is the one you should get, if only because the 5S will guarantee you the best software experience for the longest amount of time. If you do own an iPhone 5, stick with it until next year and you'll probably end up with all the 5S' improvements and more. The fact of the matter is that most people already know whether they want an iPhone at this point. It's a thoroughly known quantity. If you know you want an iPhone, this is the best iPhone that there is—at least until the next one comes out.

You’ll pay a little less, but you’ll get much better specs and impressive battery life that suits Chrome OS much better than the four-to-six hours you’ll get out of the Chromebook 11 (and previous-generation Chromebooks). The x86 architecture will also be more friendly to alternative operating systems if you intend to buy the C720 so you can make a cheap Ubuntu laptop out of it.

Product Name: Surface Pro 2: Less than a laptop
Verdict: Coming from a person who is still desperately seeking a new workhorse laptop, the Surface Pro 2 fails to deliver. There are people for whom it will make sense. If you really want to consolidate a laptop and a tablet to avoid having to carry both, the Surface Pro 2 is a strong contender. It means making certain sacrifices, but this is the kind of role it can fill. The pen support, likewise, means that it's a strong candidate for artists or even heavy OneNote-using students. There are people for whom the Surface Pro 2 will be the perfect device. But if you're wanting a laptop, get a laptop—and if you just want a tablet, pick up the Surface 2 for half the price.

Title: Review: Apple’s iPad Air is a big tablet without all the baggage
Summary: Apple's new tablet is an embiggened version of the perfectly cromulent iPad mini.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Thinner, smaller, and lighter body makes for a much more usable 10-inch tablet
Cons: The GPU can rarely actually double the performance of the A6X, counter to Apple's claims
Product Name: Review: Apple’s iPad Air is a big tablet without all the baggage
Verdict: The iPad Air throws the older Retina iPads' compromises into harsh relief. The third- and fourth-generation iPads sacrificed quite a bit in service of their high-resolution screens: They weighed more than the iPad 2. They took so long to charge that Apple had to increase the standard iPad charger's size from 10 W to 12 W just to take the edge off. Apple had to design and manufacture separate chips to make them run acceptably, even though the company normally goes out of its way to reuse components as a cost-cutting measure. Where the fourth-generation iPad was happy to improve performance and keep everything else the same, the iPad Air is a true successor to the third-generation iPad. Apple might not be able to sway those who have been wooed away by smaller tablets, but in the iPad Air the company has made a 10-inch tablet that's a whole lot nicer to use.

Those features alone are worth the update, and along with the neutral color scheme, they should give apps even more power to control the user experience. Android will look very different in a few months once developers get the hang of the new system bar APIs. KitKat is a great update that will offer a real benefit to users; Google just needs to pay attention to the things happening in its own ecosystem for the next update. There's no shame in copying.

Those low margins wouldn't be a challenge if they came with higher sales volumes, but in the face of steadily declining PC sales, those volumes aren't a sure bet. And that's how the T100 finds itself so ill equipped to suit the needs of this new era in personal computing. It’s easy to imagine what might have been, if Asus had taken the bold move to refine the T100 as far as it would go. Better materials, a better display, and tighter software would have made the T100 not just a competent device but a commendable one.

Title: Review: Google’s $179 Moto G puts every single cheap Android phone to shame
Summary: The unlocked, off-contract phone is much better than its price tag would suggest.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Dat price tag
Cons: 3G data speeds feel especially slow in the age of readily available LTE
Product Name: Review: Google’s $179 Moto G puts every single cheap Android phone to shame
Verdict: The Moto G could really shake the low end of the market up, and that's important because the low end is where the smartphone industry's continued growth is expected to come from. If you know someone who's still using a flip phone or a hoary old BlackBerry or something, the Moto G is a solid low-cost option that you can recommend to them without hesitation. Hopefully it goads the other OEMs into stepping up their efforts, too.

Title: LG G Flex Review: form over even basic function
Summary: The curve doesn't make up for a terrible display and baffling design decisions.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: LG is out taking risks and trying new things
Cons: The impossible-to-reach rear buttons do not work on a device this big
Product Name: LG G Flex Review: form over even basic function
Verdict: And that screen. The first generation of any new technology is often not very good, and the G Flex's display is no exception. We're sure P-OLED or some other kind of flexible display will eventually get its feet under it, but the choice of P-OLED ruined this device. The image quality is terrible, and it burns through the massive 3500mAh battery much faster than a 720p device has any right to. Devices are mostly screens, and when the screen is bad, the device is mostly bad. It's hard to recommend something that will have you constantly staring at grainy fuzz for two years, with your only respite from the hideous screen coming when the battery dies.

Title: Amazon Fire TV misses the same marks as Ouya, other media boxes
Summary: Review—Name recognition means zip if fixes aren't universal and devs have no lead time.
Author: Casey Johnston and Sam Machkovech
Pros: Device specs run circles around the nearest Android-driven competition.
Cons: Media browsing puts all Amazon content front-and-center, making Hulu, Netflix, and other apps less convenient, particularly since they can't tap into microphone search.
Product Name: Amazon Fire TV misses the same marks as Ouya, other media boxes
Verdict: : $99 nets users a robust media and games hub, but Amazon may want to back off its Amazon-first media searches and roll out a redder carpet for indie games if the company expects to disrupt the current kings of the media-hub world.

Author: Andrew Cunningham

Title: Review: Why buy an HTC One M8 Google Play edition instead of a Nexus 5?
Summary: There are some good reasons, just maybe not $350 worth of them.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: The M8 is a great-looking, great-feeling phone.
Cons: Kinda big, kinda bulky.
Product Name: Review: Why buy an HTC One M8 Google Play edition instead of a Nexus 5?
Verdict: Google has yet to produce a perfect Nexus phone, but in 2013 the company and its partners seriously stepped up their game. The 2012 Nexus 7 and Nexus 4 were merely great for the price; the 2013 Nexus 7 and the Nexus 5 are mostly just great. There are lots of areas where we'd prefer the M8 Google Play edition to the Nexus 5 if we were in the market for a phone with a clean version of Android, all else being equal. All else isn't equal, though. By our totally unscientific estimates, the Nexus 5 gets you a phone that is 85 to 90 percent as good as the M8 for 50 percent of the money. Even if you don't think the Nexus 5 is the most exciting phone in the world, that's basically impossible to pass up.

Title: Samsung’s Galaxy S5 has plenty of upgrades—so why does it feel so meh?
Summary: Review: Samsung tries to do too much, neglects to finetune design and software for users.
Author: Ron Amadeo

Cons: TouchWiz is a fragmented clash of three different operating system styles.

Title: Mini-review: Galaxy S5 Active doesn’t add enough to be worth buying
Summary: The regular S5 already has most of this rugged phone's best features.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Sturdy casing that's actually pretty nice to hold.
Cons: Lacks fingerprint scanner and USB 3.0 port. Neither is the vanilla S5's best feature, so the loss isn't debilitating.
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: Given the similarities between the S5 Active and the vanilla S5, for most people we'd recommend getting the standard edition of the phone and putting it in a case if you want extra protection. The good thing about having a separate case is that if you drop the phone, the case absorbs the damage while leaving the phone underneath relatively undamaged—in the long run, this will be good for extending the useful life of your phone and increasing its resale value. That's not true when your phone is your case.

Title: Review: Gigabyte’s AMD Brix gives Intel’s mini PC a run for its money
Summary: It uses a little more power, but at $250 it's a nice value option.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Offers a good mix of CPU and GPU performance for the money
Cons: Full CPU speeds not available without a BIOS tweak
Product Name: Review: Gigabyte’s AMD Brix gives Intel’s mini PC a run for its money
Verdict: This Brix isn't the best at any one thing, but it gives you a good combination of CPU and GPU performance, power consumption, size, and price. It performs roughly as well as Intel's best Haswell NUC but costs $140 less, and it has much better graphics performance than any of the lower-end, Intel-based NUCs and Brixes (even though we're still talking about integrated graphics performance here). It's a great option for light gaming, HTPC use, or even if you want a small, reasonably capable, no-fuss Ubuntu workstation.

Title: In a world of me-first smart home gear, can smarthubs make them all play nice?
Summary: Review: We automate this old house with the Revolv and SmartThings smarthubs.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: The $299 starter pack is currently the home automation industry's best value for novices.
Cons: Devices simply don't trigger consistently enough, whether by GPS or by manual app control.
Product Name: In a world of me-first smart home gear, can smarthubs make them all play nice?
Verdict: : Ready to dive into Internet-enabled devices? SmartThings gets you there at a reasonable price. While its performance is suspect, it also gets users up-and-running with a solid home security suite in the box. Revolv adds $300 to your tab just to make your desired gadgets play nice, but its wide device compatibility and smooth app are nearly worth the tab.

Title: Fast, but compromised: Gigabyte’s AMD-powered mini gaming PC reviewed
Summary: The Brix Gaming box is hobbled by heat, noise, and mediocre Linux support.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Unmatched GPU performance for the size
Cons: Mediocre CPU performance
Product Name: Fast, but compromised: Gigabyte’s AMD-powered mini gaming PC reviewed
Verdict: This particular Brix Gaming model isn't all it could be, but it comes close enough that we want to see what Gigabyte can accomplish next—a similar box that combines a

Title: Review: We wear Samsung’s Gear 2 and Gear Fit so you don’t have to
Summary: Samsung doubles down on wearables, but still doesn’t get it right.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Product Name: Review: We wear Samsung’s Gear 2 and Gear Fit so you don’t have to
Verdict: No. This slick device works as advertised and is no slouch, but it will only whet your appetite for a smartwatch that better integrates into your total smartphone ecosystem.

Title: Windows Phone 8.1 review: A magnificent smartphone platform
Summary: It's a 0.1 update that feels like a 2.0 update.
Author: Peter Bright
Product Name: Windows Phone 8.1
Verdict: We might still wish that there were a few more apps, and that developers spoke of the platform in the same breath as iOS and Android, but even in spite of this, Windows Phone 8.1 is a polished, fun, clever, and personal smartphone platform that's just about everyone can enjoy. It's a magnificent smartphone platform.

Title: iOS 8 on the iPhone 4S: Performance isn’t the (only) problem
Summary: New OS wants screen space and processing power that the old phone doesn't have.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 8 on the iPhone 4S: Performance isn’t the (only) problem
Verdict: If you'd prefer to play it safe and wait for a future 8.0.1 or 8.1 update to improve performance on older devices, that's fine too—we hope that Apple makes it a priority as it continues to work on iOS 8.

Title: LG G3 review: A great phone with way too many pixels
Summary: A 2560x1440 LCD sounds like it should be amazing, but it just eats the battery.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Ultra-slim bezels pack the 5.5-inch screen into a relatively compact body.
Cons: The Battery life during high usage. The screen uses
Product Name: LG G3
Verdict: Below you'll see a lot of stuff in the "good" column—the G3 has a lot going for it. Heavy users should be wary of the runtime, though. The screen can really chew through a battery, and all the pixels in the world don't matter if the phone is dead. At least you can bring a spare.

Title: Toshiba P50t review: So many pixels, too much bulk
Summary: The world's first 4K laptop fails to put out the red resolution carpet.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: The 15.6-inch multi-touch screen has been optimized to convince us that 4K density is worth something on a laptop-sized display.
Cons: Screen brightness, weight, and bulk combine to make this a difficult laptop to lug around.
Product Name: Toshiba P50t
Verdict: Find your personal balance between "need" and "want" before jumping in, then, because this highly powered, reasonably priced device is a good sign that more, better hardware (and more energy-efficient stuff, at that) should follow soon. Otherwise, if you're itching for the 4K computer plunge, a nice monitor for your existing, high-end computer is still a superior option to the P50t's rough edges.

Title: Mint 17 is the perfect place for Linux-ers to wait out Ubuntu uncertainty
Summary: Review: Long-term support and stability plus tweaks for desktop? Delicious!
Author: Scott Gilbertson
Product Name: Mint 17 is the perfect place for Linux-ers to wait out Ubuntu uncertainty
Verdict: Whatever ends up happening with future releases, Linux Mint 17 makes a fantastic Linux desktop right now. It's stable, familiar enough for Windows refugees to pick it up without missing a beat, and has all the familiar tools Ubuntu fans would expect. Enjoy the current experience, and we'll all stay tuned to see how Mint's major bet on stability plays out.

Title: Surface Pro 3 review: Is the third time the charm?
Summary: Microsoft wants its tablet-PC combo to go mainstream this time around.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Beautiful design
Cons: The dearth of USB ports
Product Name: Surface Pro 3
Verdict: Surface Pro 3 is the closest Microsoft has come yet to producing a laptop-killing tablet. But the laptop will live on to fight another day. This time around, the third iteration isn't the one that gets it right.

Title: The Ars NAS distribution shootout: FreeNAS vs NAS4Free
Summary: One is pleasantly functional; the other continues devolving during a journey of pain.
Author: Jim Salter
Pros: Coherent, responsive, intuitive Web interface.
Cons: No extensible architecture—what it does is what it does, and that's all it does.
Product Name: The Ars NAS distribution shootout: FreeNAS vs NAS4Free
Verdict: Ultimately, these are both great distributions that put a tremendous amount of power and advanced technology at an admin's—or end user's—fingertips. Which one is the right distribution for you is a question of what you need to do, what you want to do, and what you're willing to do.

Title: A slide into obsolescence: iOS 8 on the iPad 2
Summary: It didn't seem like 6 could be worse than 7, but 7 to 8 is a different story.
Author: Casey Johnston
Product Name: A slide into obsolescence: iOS 8 on the iPad 2
Verdict: Ultimately, the iPad 2 is still our couch Internet-surfing device, occasionally a night-reading device. We don't demand much at all from it in terms of performance and expect it's the same for others who are still using this model a full three and a half years after it came out. This means that upgrading to iOS 8 won't ruin the experience; then again, neither would just staying on iOS 7.

Title: Moto 360 review—Beautiful outside, ugly inside
Summary: Motorola creates an iconic design, but pairs it with an ancient, power-hungry SoC.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A round LCD that looks like something from the future. Yeah, it's missing a few lines at the bottom. So what?
Cons: Terrible performance. The decision to go with an ancient TI OMAP3 instead of a more modern Snapdragon 400 makes the device slow and stuttery.
Product Name: Moto 360 review—Beautiful outside, ugly inside

Title: Review: Motorola’s $129 Moto E is good and cheap (but mostly good)
Summary: Motorola makes a surprisingly capable smartphone with a few notable compromises.
Author: Andrew Cunningham

Cons: CPU, GPU, Wi-Fi, and cellular performance is good enough for the price, but objectively mediocre.
Product Name: Review: Motorola’s $129 Moto E is good and cheap (but mostly good)
Verdict: The Moto E is more for people who don't have that extra $50, or if you're looking for a good-quality low-cost handset to give to somebody who you know isn't going to turn into a smartphone power user. It's not
