Title: Review: The new Moto G doesn’t change much, but still a steal at $179
Summary: It's just the same specs with a bigger screen, but others still can't compete.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Great price.
Cons: No LTE or 42.2Mbps HSDPA cellular data rates and no separate LTE option (or CDMA option) as of this writing.
Product Name: Review: The new Moto G doesn’t change much, but still a steal at $179
Verdict: That's probably fine, though. Prominent Android players like Samsung, HTC, and LG have yet to field a response to the original Moto G, and so the phone still stands more or less alone as the best Android offering in this price range, big screen or not. It doesn't do anything particularly badly, and it does most things pretty well. While no single aspect is special, the Moto G gives you the full smartphone experience. It's not the best Android phone you can buy, but it remains the best one you can get for this kind of money.

Title: Amazon Fire HDX 8.9 (2014) impressions: Deja vu 8.9
Summary: New processor and Firefly app round out the few differences in the new model.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Product Name: Amazon Fire HDX 8.9 (2014) impressions: Deja vu 8.9
Verdict: We expect this year's model to quietly replace last year's as Amazon's default 8.9-inch sales option, and it's still strong in the price-to-performance department, but we noticed enough design and performance issues after a half-day of heavy use to hold back on excitement. Amazon asks a lot from Android tablet shoppers by way of its closed ecosystem, and while the HDX 8.9 is by no means a dud, we can already tell that it needed to do more in the year of the Nexus 9.

Title: iOS 8, thoroughly reviewed
Summary: A big, developer-centric update completes the overhaul started in iOS 7.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Extensions let you customize your phone and tablet to a degree previously disallowed in (non-jailbroken) iOS.
Cons: Still no public transit directions in Maps.
Product Name: iOS 8, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: With this release, Apple is trying to make additions that developers and power users want without upsetting people who come to iOS specifically because of its consistency and simplicity. It's telling that just about every major iOS 8 feature can be disabled or ignored, and that big transformative features like third-party extensions are hidden from view by default. A surface-level glance at iOS 8 suggests an operating system that isn't all that different from iOS 7. Look just a little deeper, though, and you'll see just how different it is.

Title: Samsung Galaxy Note 4 review: small tweaks to a big device
Summary: It's a little faster, but this is largely the same phablet.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: The metal frame with a chamfered edge is a nice step up in quality for Samsung's devices.
Cons: Physical home buttons and styluses don't mix. Imparting force through a plastic stick into a clicky button is extremely awkward.
Product Name: Samsung Galaxy Note 4
Verdict: It's a new year and new iteration, but this is much the same old Note. If you like the Note 3, you'll like the Note 4. It doesn't offer much for upgraders, but much of the industry is on a yearly cycle. Samsung seemingly had to release

Title: Testing a $35 Firefox OS phone—how bad could it be?
Summary: Review: A masochistic journey into the world of the Intex Cloud FX.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Per-app privacy controls. Block an app from seeing your location, contacts, or a host of other things on your phone.
Cons: The software—Firefox OS was a totally inappropriate choice of operating system for this hardware. There are literally zero considerations for the speed and memory of the Cloud FX, and most of the device's really serious problems come from running software on hardware that feels well below the minimum spec.
Product Name: Testing a $35 Firefox OS phone—how bad could it be?
Verdict: The Cloud FX doesn't make any sense, though, even at $35. It doesn't seem like anyone set out to choose the best software for this device, and that was really the crippling decision. Low-end smartphones need a low-end-appropriate operating system, and Firefox OS isn't up to that task. We get the feeling there are relatively good, sub-$50 devices out there—but this isn't one of them.

So far we've noticed no significant bugs, and two of the most common complaints we've read about in our comments (Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connection issues) are on the list of fixed bugs in the release. If you're already on iOS 8, install it. If you

Title: Galaxy Alpha review: A Samsung phone with chrome
Summary: Galaxy gets a much-needed facelift, but is a hot new body enough?
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Metal build is handsome enough to attract compliments, and bulges in the frame add a nice grip to the edges.
Cons: TouchWiz is almost exactly the same as other Galaxy offerings from this year, so issues with bloatware and visual design remain.
Product Name: Galaxy Alpha
Verdict: Had the Galaxy Alpha shipped with a top-of-the-line camera, complete with a wonderful sensor and other smart features, a competitive price, and a danged micro-SD card slot, we'd be shouting from the rooftops about this handset. As it stands, we'll whistle politely about it.

Title: iPhone 6 and 6 Plus: In deep with Apple’s thinnest phones
Summary: Review: Apple finally brings the big-screen love—with some strings attached.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Solid and attractive new design incorporates the big screens that so many people have been asking for.
Cons: The iPhone 6 Plus fits in exclusive features we'd like to see in both phones.
Product Name: iPhone 6 and 6 Plus: In deep with Apple’s thinnest phones

Title: Newer, but not better: The Nokia Lumia 530 reviewed
Summary: Microsoft’s budget Windows Phone is often outdone by its predecessor.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Can usually be picked up for between $50 and $70 if you don't mind carrier exclusivity.
Cons: Easiest to find in its carrier-locked form.
Product Name: Newer, but not better: The Nokia Lumia 530 reviewed
Verdict: Unless that display improves in future hardware revisions, we urge Windows Phone fans to either step up to the 630 or 635 or step sideways to the still-available 520. The 530 isn’t an awful phone, but other Lumias render it completely redundant.

Title: Review: Amazon’s Kindle Voyage e-reader is the king of its niche
Summary: At $199, even a great reading experience has limited appeal beyond its core audience.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Nice, even front light that you can use to read anywhere.
Cons: Accessing any books not in Amazon’s store is difficult-to-impossible, depending on what formats you’re using.
Product Name: Review: Amazon’s Kindle Voyage e-reader is the king of its niche
Verdict: If that describes you, you’ll really like the Voyage. It’s attractive and understated, and it retains and improves upon all of the good stuff from other Kindles. It’s just that a dedicated e-reader at this price is the king of a very small hill.

Title: Review: Toshiba’s Chromebook 2 has a gorgeous screen and not much else
Summary: We wish we liked the rest of the laptop as much as its 1080p IPS display.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: High-end model has a great 1080p IPS display.
Cons: Flexible plastic body is underwhelming, though not unexpected in a budget laptop.
Product Name: Review: Toshiba’s Chromebook 2 has a gorgeous screen and not much else
Verdict: If screen quality isn’t particularly important to you, you can safely ignore the base model of the Chromebook 2. Try to find a comparably priced Chromebook from Acer, Dell, or another manufacturer who uses Haswell (or even Broadwell) Celerons instead of Bay Trail ones, and you’ll be happier with the system’s performance in the long run. If screen quality is the

Title: Not the upgrade we were hoping for: The 2014 Mac Mini reviewed
Summary: Removed features and Intel's convoluted CPU lineup make the Mini less versatile.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Better storage, Wi-Fi, and graphics performance than last year.
Cons: The second 2.5-inch drive bay is gone.
Product Name: Not the upgrade we were hoping for: The 2014 Mac Mini reviewed
Verdict: Intel's confusing matrix of CPU options may be partially to blame here, but either way the 2014 Mini can be much slower than the 2012 model was. The Mac Mini may have gotten an update, but unfortunately that isn't the same thing as getting an upgrade.

Title: Signs of progress: One month with Android Wear 5.0
Summary: LG's G Watch R and better software make it easier to see Wear's pros and cons.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Signs of progress: One month with Android Wear 5.0
Verdict: The biggest problem for smartwatches as they exist today (and from what we've seen about the Apple Watch, its basic use cases don't seem drastically different from Android Wear's) is not the watches themselves. It's that any conversation about smartwatches tends to be dominated by comparisons to the rise of the smartphone, or the PC, or even the tablet market. There's definitely a niche for well-designed, reliable wrist-mounted phone companions, but it's just that—a niche. If we can stop expecting them to be the tech sector's next gigantic growth segment, we'll get closer to having the right conversation about them.

Title: Nexus 9 review: A “premium” tablet with a not-so-premium feel
Summary: Performance, price, and build lock heads in Google's most uneven flagship yet.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Game performance simply blazes
Cons: Stuttering and pauses between app switches are too common
Product Name: Nexus 9
Verdict: At the very least, the build quality is what it is. A thin, light device; a great screen with a white-bleed caveat; a plasticky body with a weird pressure-point issue; and a cool screen-tap-to-power function that's mostly required because the power button stinks. That all adds up to a tough sell on a crowded showroom floor; anybody working on commission will almost certainly turn to other devices if they plan to meet their holiday sales quota.

Title: The iPad Air 2: A host of hidden upgrades in one skinny package
Summary: Review: iPad's "off-year" update boosts specs and drops weight, but will users notice?
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Reduced weight and thickness make this easy enough to use with one hand, let alone held normally with two.
Cons: Apps, games, and iOS in general all have yet to catch up to the boosted specs.
Product Name: The iPad Air 2: A host of hidden upgrades in one skinny package

Title: Sling TV review: Do cord cutters and “cord nevers” even want live TV?
Summary: For $20 a month, Dish needs to convince customers that the live TV experience is great.
Author: Megan Geuss
Product Name: Sling TV
Verdict: Maybe we don't quite work as Dish's target demographic right now, but just wait 10 years, and we'll be handing over our $20 per month without any kvetching.

Title: Dell’s Venue 8 7000: A striking tablet that falls short of greatness
Summary: Review: A premium tablet with a cool design that doesn't always work in real life.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Unique, interesting design that defies tablet conventions, looks nice, and works most of the time.
Cons: GPU performance lags behind other tablets in its price bracket.
Product Name: Dell’s Venue 8 7000: A striking tablet that falls short of greatness
Verdict: $400 can get you either a first-generation iPad Air or an iPad Mini 3 (though we'd pocket the $100 and go with an iPad Mini 2 if you're looking at small Apple tablets). The Venue is one of the more interesting Android tablets in this price range, but unless you're dead-set on running Android, an iPad is probably going to be a better use of your money.

Title: Pono Player review: A tall, refreshing drink of snake oil
Summary: We give Neil Young's high-res music player a spin and do a few cochlea kegels.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Quality pre-amp and DAC do the heavy lifting in making music output sound quite good, whether using highest-res audio files or merely high-enough res.
Cons: No amount of testing made 192kHz/24-bit FLAC audio sound noticeably better than high-quality MP3s.
Product Name: Pono Player
Verdict: We could see a Pono Player 2.0 being a killer device, honestly, especially since the iPod Classic has exited the space. Perhaps now there's significant room for $300-ish high-end dedicated music players. Worry less about being particularly portable, we say, and add features like wireless audio transfer (so we can leave a Pono plugged into a home stereo), a suction grip for placing on surfaces like car dashboards, a slightly bigger screen, and a damned hold button, and we just might throw this overpriced bottle of wine into our messenger bags after all.

Title: A look at Android 5.1: speed, security, tweaks

Title: Review: Intel’s Broadwell mini PC is a next-generation Ultrabook in a box
Summary: This showcase for Intel's technology is also a pretty slick desktop computer.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A small, attractive box with good performance. To get a significantly faster computer, you'll need to move up to quad-core CPUs and dedicated GPUs.
Cons: You'll have to spend some money to get this performance. Lesser mini PCs can cost half as much.
Product Name: Review: Intel’s Broadwell mini PC is a next-generation Ultrabook in a box
Verdict: Our main criticisms of the consumer NUC are the same as last year. Because you need to track down and buy some components yourself, it might not be the easiest thing to recommend to a regular PC buyer. Once you've paid for the box, the RAM, and the SSD, you've spent more than you would have on an entry-level desktop or mini PC even though the NUC will usually be the faster computer. We still like it for what it is, though—a surprisingly capable desktop that can fit pretty much anywhere.

Title: Review: The absolutely optional Apple Watch and Watch OS 1.0
Summary: A pragmatist's guide to a nice but not quite necessary gadget.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Lots and lots of body and band options
Cons: Watch OS is tricky to learn and the Apple Watch app can be flaky.
Product Name: Review: The absolutely optional Apple Watch and Watch OS 1.0
Verdict: The Apple Watch sits right at the tippy-top of that hierarchy of needs pyramid. Of all of Apple’s products, it offers the fewest features for the price. It is not without value, but before you buy it, make sure that absolutely every one of those other needs lower on the pyramid has already been met.

Title: Asus Zenbook UX305: It’s no MacBook, but it’s a good midrange laptop
Summary: Review: This basic Core M Ultrabook offers a nice set of features for $700.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Solid construction.
Cons: No touch or backlit keyboard option, if you’re into those.
Product Name: Asus Zenbook UX305: It’s no MacBook, but it’s a good midrange laptop
Verdict: That said, those of you who think that this is just a cheaper Windows version of Apple’s latest MacBook are incorrect. The MacBook is smaller and lighter, its screen is sharper and better lit (unless you pay extra for the upgrade, though we can’t actually find that model on sale anywhere yet), it won’t slide around on your desk, it has faster 802.11ac Wi-Fi, and Apple is using better-performing versions of Core M that get a bit closer to standard Ultrabook processors. The Zenbook has more ports, and its more conventional keyboard and matte screen will be a draw for most, but it’s not really a MacBook stand-in so much as it is a very good midrange Windows laptop.

Title: The first Tizen smartphone isn’t an “Android killer”—it’s a bad Android clone
Summary: Review: Samsung's Android alternative arrives, but it's no match for the real thing.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: [This space intentionally left blank]
Cons: Tizen has almost no apps right now, and no one is building apps for Tizen—not even Samsung. As the creator of the OS, it's Samsung's job to lead the ecosystem forward. Who will support this platform when even the platform owner won't?
Product Name: The first Tizen smartphone isn’t an “Android killer”—it’s a bad Android clone
Verdict: Even with Samsung's full support, Tizen would be a tough sell. But when even the creator of the OS isn't supporting it, why would anyone invest in this ecosystem?

Title: Intel’s Compute Stick: A full PC that’s tiny in size (and performance)
Summary: Mini-review: Atom-powered mini PC is a good streaming stick but a slow desktop.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Small
Cons: Performs well enough for what it does, but compared to other mini-desktops, it’s slow
Product Name: Intel’s Compute Stick: A full PC that’s tiny in size (and performance)
Verdict: Right now, the Compute Stick feels like a version 1.0 product as well as a niche product. A revision with Cherry Trail would go a long way toward making its performance more acceptable for a wider range of tasks, and we hope that Intel gets around to lifting some of the OS restrictions in place here. It’s really neat that a full Windows PC will fit into something you can stick in your pocket. Now let’s make it a better PC.

Title: Review: The Dell XPS 13 is the PC laptop to beat
Summary: Stand aside Apple, Dell's just built the best ultraportable laptop.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: The size
Cons: The year is 2015. 8GB of RAM should be the baseline, with 16GB as an option. 4GB is barely enough to run Chrome.
Product Name: Review: The Dell XPS 13 is the PC laptop to beat
Verdict: As other manufacturers get their Broadwell-U refreshes on the market, I'm sure the Dell will be up against strong offerings from Samsung (provided that you're in one of the markets where Samsung still sells laptops), Acer, and others. Right now, however, its compact size means that it stands above all those. If you don't want to run OS X, it's a better machine than even Apple has produced. The MacBook Air ideal is no longer a far off target to aspire to; it's a baseline to surpass.

Title: Cheap, functional, upgradeable: HP’s Stream and Pavilion Mini desktops reviewed
Summary: These inexpensive Windows desktops have a surprising amount to offer.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Cheap and small.
Cons: Shipping memory configuration hurts memory and graphics performance.
Product Name: Cheap, functional, upgradeable: HP’s Stream and Pavilion Mini desktops reviewed
Verdict: I already bought a Stream Mini for myself. I had 8GB of DDR3 laying around, and I spent a total of $150 to add that 256GB SSD and 802.11ac Wi-Fi adapter. Even if you don't already have some spare memory somewhere, it's pretty great to be able to get a zippy, power-efficient, already-licensed-for-Windows general-purpose mini desktop for less than $400.

Title: Logitech’s rechargeable, switchable keyboard is a great choice for iOS 9
Summary: For those with iPads or any combo of devices, the convenience is worth the price.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Logitech’s rechargeable, switchable keyboard is a great choice for iOS 9

Title: Dell’s Linux PC sequel still “just works”—but it adds 4K screen and rough edges
Summary: 4k scaling issues keep it from being perfect—but, hey, it’s for developers, right?
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Ubuntu 14.04, factory-preconfigured to just work
Cons: Thunderbolt port doesn't really work in Ubuntu
Product Name: Dell’s Linux PC sequel still “just works”—but it adds 4K screen and rough edges
Verdict: It’s kind of a waffle-y answer to the "should you buy this" question, but it’s the best one we can give: The M3800 Developer Edition is a solid piece of hardware with some very smart folks at Dell committed to keeping it working well. If you want something that’s like a MacBook Pro but with more expandability and with an OEM-supported Ubuntu install, then this is definitely your bag.

Title: iOS 9 on the iPad 2: Not worse than iOS 8, but missing many features
Summary: Apple's oldest supported tablet hangs in there for one more round.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 9 on the iPad 2: Not worse than iOS 8, but missing many features
Verdict: The iPad 2 has had a good run, and this is probably the end of the line. If you're still using one, you should at least consider taking a look at a newer tablet like the iPad Air 2—

Title: ThinkPad X1 Carbon review: A fine heir to the ThinkPad name
Summary: A great keyboard and a great TrackPoint make for a great machine.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Glorious keyboard
Cons: The GPU performance mystery
Product Name: ThinkPad X1 Carbon
Verdict: Even with this wrinkle, if you spend the money you'll get a machine that you'll enjoy using and that will serve you well. In almost every way, it's the ThinkPad system I've been wanting for years. And it comes with a ThinkPad price.

Title: Review: New Chromebook Pixel is still lovely hardware with limited appeal
Summary: It's $300 cheaper and lasts over twice as long, but few need a premium Chromebook.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Outstanding build quality and an attractive if boxy design.
Cons: Chrome OS, while always improving, is still limited compared to Windows or OS X. That’s not a big deal at $300, but it’s harder to justify for $1,000.
Product Name: Review: New Chromebook Pixel is still lovely hardware with limited appeal
Verdict: This is not a practical mass-market product, but it’s not really intended to be. People who liked the first Pixel will love the new one. People who didn’t care about the first Pixel can continue not caring. This laptop will attract a specific kind of customer, but it still feels like hardware that’s begging for more versatile software.

Title: Xiaomi’s Mi Note phablet outclasses the competition for half the price
Summary: Review: China's disruptive OEM builds a premium, high-end phablet for $370.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Xiaomi’s Mi Note phablet outclasses the competition for half the price
Verdict: Xiaomi continually proves it is a disruptive force in the smartphone industry. It listens to user feedback and improves, it can make a competitive, top-tier device for half the price of the competition, and it offers weekly software updates. The device's biggest downside is the country availability, which for now, is mostly China. If you could buy this in the US, this would be the best Android phablet you can buy.

Title: Review: The new Moto E is the most phone you can get for $150
Summary: The first Moto E cut too many corners, but this one can hold its own.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A solid, well-built phone, especially for the price.
Cons: Camera goes from miserable to workable, but it's still a weak link.
Product Name: Review: The new Moto E is the most phone you can get for $150
Verdict: Motorola is still making the best budget Android handsets you can get for the money. Lenovo hasn't screwed that up yet, and hopefully the company doesn't try to fix what isn't broken.

Title: 13-inch Broadwell MacBook showdown: Should you go Pro or get an Air?
Summary: Review: The 2015 Broadwell refreshes are similar, but not identical.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good CPU, GPU, RAM, and storage specs for this price, size, and weight. Few PC OEMs use the faster 28W Broadwell-U chips, and so far few have opted to use 1866MHz DDR3 RAM.
Cons: Good battery life for light workloads, but it drops off quickly under load.
Product Name: 13-inch Broadwell MacBook showdown: Should you go Pro or get an Air?

Title: Review: The 2015 MacBook Air’s once-trailblazing design is showing its age
Summary: Its insides are more than competitive, but they're encased in 2010's design.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Internal specs are still top-of-the-line for this price, size, and weight class—PC OEMs aren’t going to give you this faster GPU, either.
Cons: A design that stood out for its portability in 2010 is merely average in 2015.
Product Name: Review: The 2015 MacBook Air’s once-trailblazing design is showing its age
Verdict: This year's Air is perched in an awkward place. It has ceded its position as Apple's thinnest, lightest, form-factor-pushing-est laptop to the Retina MacBook, but it doesn't have the speed, ports, or the screen of the Retina MacBook Pros. It's still got a place in the lineup (the Pro can't match its battery life and Apple's figures suggest that the MacBook won't, either), but it's not as broadly appealing or as easy to recommend as it was a couple of years ago. And its once-impressive design and screen are now uncharacteristically behind-the-curve.

Title: iOS 9 on the iPhone 4S: A stay of execution, nothing more
Summary: Small screen is even more of a liability, and speed still isn't what it used to be.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 9 on the iPhone 4S: A stay of execution, nothing more
Verdict: Apple might surprise us again next year, but this is probably the end of the line for the iPhone 4S. The

Title: Google OnHub review—Google’s smart home Trojan horse is a $200 leap of faith
Summary: Today it's a $200 Wi-Fi router. Tomorrow? We have no idea.  (Ok, maybe some idea.)
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: It looks nice. Most routers look like
Cons: Performance and functionality are not as good as a $200 router.
Product Name: Google OnHub review—Google’s smart home Trojan horse is a $200 leap of faith
Verdict: Right now, the router doesn't seem like anything special. It's perfectly functional but not much else. No one should buy the OnHub as purely a Wi-Fi router. What will make or break this device is the upcoming smart home functionality, and right now we just don't know what that entails. We'll keep it hooked up and continue to monitor it though. We'll let you know ASAP if it starts turning from "just a router" into... something else.

Title: Review: New $180 Moto G is a stylish upgrade worthy of the original
Summary: Meh GPU and flaky camera are outweighed by LTE, better CPU, 2GB RAM, and the price.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: At $180 and $220 unlocked, the Moto G still offers a good deal for the price
Cons: Qualcomm’s low-end GPU performance is becoming more of a problem
Product Name: Review: New $180 Moto G is a stylish upgrade worthy of the original
Verdict: The fact that the Moto G is so competent drives home the superfluousness of so many flagship phone features—the move from 720p to 1080p to 1440p and beyond, faster SoCs, ever-thinner metal-and-glass slabs. Those things are all nice to have, but you’d be hard-pressed to argue that any of them are essential.

Title: Powerful new hardware, same Chrome OS: Dell Chromebook 13 reviewed
Summary: Review: You could drop up to $899 on this premium Chromebook.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Its light carbon-fiber design makes the Chromebook 13 one of the most attractive Chromebooks and business notebooks available.
Cons: Dell security features and Citrix Receiver can only be used fully by companies and their employees.
Product Name: Powerful new hardware, same Chrome OS: Dell Chromebook 13 reviewed
Verdict: Thankfully more utilitarian apps and programs are making their way to Chromebooks, like

Title: Surface Book review: The hybrid that really does replace your laptop
Summary: It ain't cheap, but it is pretty.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Great screen
Cons: Base system has no discrete GPU
Product Name: Surface Book
Verdict: Nonetheless, it's never going to be a mass-market machine, which is a shame, because it's a truly a fine piece of hardware.

Title: iOS 9, thoroughly reviewed
Summary: Apple gives the iPad a lot of love as iOS goes back into spit-and-polish mode.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Visual tweaks continue to refine the aesthetic introduced in iOS 7. The software keyboard in particular is a big improvement.
Cons: Maps public transit supports a discouragingly small number of cities after three years of waiting.
Product Name: iOS 9, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: But if you're running iOS 8, update. There's no reason not to, and there's nothing keeping you from doing it.

Title: Android Auto review: A beautiful, but beta alternative to awful OEM solutions
Summary: The occasional frustration still beats the very low bar set by car manufacturers.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: Beautiful Material Design drags infotainment systems out of the design dark ages.
Cons: The text-to-speech system for messages is really dumb. It will read URLs, letter-by-letter, in their entirety.
Product Name: Android Auto
Verdict: Android Auto is very much a first-gen product. There are silly bugs and inconsistencies, you need to use a wire, and there are some obvious functionality gaps. The foundation of Android Auto is solid though. Google built the system to be not only independent of the car software, but independent of the phone's Android OS, too. It will be very easy to update going forward. Presumably updates will come, bugs will be fixed, more third-party apps will be made compatible, and more cars will be released with Android Auto compatibility. Android Auto still has some growing to do, but the ability for that growth is there. If you've got a compatible car, today Android Auto is going to be much nicer than the very low bar set by car OEMs—currently, it's hard to complain when the alternative is so bad.

Title: Mini-review: iWork ‘15 brings a lot of little changes but no headliners
Summary: And some longstanding issues remain—those decimal points will get you every time.
Author: Iljitsch van Beijnum
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: If you've been using iWork '13 or '14, expect iWork '15 to be pretty much the same with some refinements here and there. As before, Keynote is by far the best of the three iWork applications. Numbers is fine for limited-scale projects, trading better layout and ease of use against the raw power that its competitors bring to the table. But I can't recommend Pages in good conscience. It has tons of potential, but in its current state, it's just a mess of unfortunate user interface choices and bugs/omissions. And as evidenced by another year of updates, Apple doesn't seem to be interested in cleaning it up.

Title: Paranoid Android redux: “going dark” with Silent Circle’s Blackphone 2
Summary: Latest edition of Phil Zimmerman's favorite phone brings privacy with less pain.
Author: Sean Gallagher
Pros: Highly configurable security and privacy settings of Silent OS.
Cons: Silent Phone service may be overkill for the average person's privacy.
Product Name: Paranoid Android redux: “going dark” with Silent Circle’s Blackphone 2
Verdict: If you're instead looking for a phone with a stylus, a 20-megapixel camera, or a rotating credit line that lets you upgrade next year without buying another unlocked phone... well, the Blackphone 2 is not that phone and likely never will be. Privacy may be just as important to consumers as it is to the corporate set, but some people will just have to wait for Silent OS' features to trickle down to the rest of the Android world.

Title: Mini-review: Logitech’s Create is the iPad Pro keyboard case you really want
Summary: It’s not as svelte as Apple’s stuff, but it’s a cheaper, superior keyboard.
Author: Andrew Cunningham

Title: Review: It’s big, but at $400 the Moto X Pure Edition is a safe bet
Summary: A flagship that's cheaper than a Galaxy and easier to buy than a OnePlus Two.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good specs and great build quality, especially for the price.
Cons: Mediocre camera, again.
Product Name: Review: It’s big, but at $400 the Moto X Pure Edition is a safe bet
Verdict: If you're shopping for your own unlocked Android phone to bring to a carrier or MVNO and you're not interested in dealing with OnePlus' invitation system, the Moto X and G are going to cover most users out there. Enthusiasts, power users, and heavy gamers should probably choose the Moto X over the Moto G, but at half the price the Moto G still manages to provide most of the important features. The Moto X doesn't offer a different smartphone experience, just a better, faster version of the same experience.

Title: The gen-two Moto 360—a beautiful, compact design without much new tech
Summary: Review: It doesn't move the needle much, but design is what really matters in wearables.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A beautiful, compact design.
Cons: The heart rate sensor, like all of these green, reflective heart rate sensors, is a useless toy.
Product Name: The gen-two Moto 360—a beautiful, compact design without much new tech
Verdict: Future speculation aside, we don't think Motorola's lack of technical improvement is a deal breaker. For many, wearables are largely about how they look when you're wearing them, and Motorola clearly focused on that. This is the most compact Android Wear device out there and one of the best looking and most customizable. For those with small wrists, this is easily the best option. It's fast enough to smoothly run Android Wear, and the battery lasts long enough to survive the day. For wearables today, there may be more important things than the spec sheet.

Title: iPad Mini 4 review: A lighter, faster tablet with a better screen
Summary: Extra RAM and a better color gamut help make up for year-old guts.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Improved performance thanks to the Apple A8 SoC.
Cons: Doesn’t actually fit the performance of the now-year-old iPad Air 2 into a Mini-sized body.
Product Name: iPad Mini 4
Verdict: The iPad’s sales numbers have seen better days, and if you’re just looking for a small screen to use for Netflix you can pick up a six-pack of dirt-cheap Kindle Fires for less than the price of Apple’s least expensive tablet. But if you’re a heavy tablet user with an appetite for games and apps and you’ve been waiting for a mini tablet as capable as the iPad Air 2, the iPad Mini 4 is probably the best thing you can buy right now.

Title: A (3D) touch above: The iPhone 6S and 6S Plus reviewed
Summary: In the absence of a new design, 3D Touch and the A9 chip are the stars of the show.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: 3D Touch is still new, but once users get used to it and developers have time to add support to their apps it’s a genuinely useful feature.
Cons: “Hey Siri” will respond to just about anyone and can send texts, make appointments, and do other things without requiring a passcode.
Product Name: A (3D) touch above: The iPhone 6S and 6S Plus reviewed
Verdict: Our opening statement holds, even though it’s pretty obvious advice: The iPhone 6S is a good buy if you’re coming from a 5 or 5S, but keep your money if you’ve already got a 6 or 6 Plus.

Title: Huawei’s first Android Wear watch is a beautiful yet basic timepiece
Summary: Review: It looks great on the outside, but it's still Google's OS on the inside.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Every model features a beautiful, yet distinct design and a sharp, full-circle 400 x 400 display.
Cons: Huawei's fitness apps can be wonky and inaccurate.
Product Name: Huawei’s first Android Wear watch is a beautiful yet basic timepiece
Verdict: One thing's for sure: Huawei got the design right on the first try. While I appreciate the customization of the Moto 360, I applaud Huawei's ability to successfully create and edit a cohesive collection of timepieces that fit together as a group as well as provide a fashionable option for nearly every taste. With fashion brands like Fossil and Tag Heuer gearing up to release their own Android Wear devices, starting off strong never hurt anyone.

Title: OS X 10.11 El Capitan: The Ars Technica Review
Summary: Apple brings refinement and under-the-hood changes to Yosemite's new design.
Author: Andrew Cunningham & Lee Hutchinson
Product Name: OS X 10.11 El Capitan: The Ars Technica Review
Verdict: So, exciting? No, not really, not unless you're a window management enthusiast who is excited to dance on Helvetica Neue's grave. But it's a free update. It has its occasional bugs and quirks (trying to enable Safari’s new status bar was enough to crash it a few times), but Apple is already working on the initial 10.11.1 bugfix release that will begin anew the process of smoothing out the problems that come with any new OS. Like El Capitan at large, that seems just fine to us.

Title: Ezviz Mini security cam reviewed: Small, affordable, and surprisingly good
Summary: This $70 mini camera gives expensive competitors a run for their money.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: It's so cute and tiny. Aside from a pleasant aesthetic, this makes it easy to move around your home and easy to hide if necessary.
Cons: The camera's setup is long and tedious compared to other plug-in-and-go Wi-Fi cameras.
Product Name: Ezviz Mini security cam reviewed: Small, affordable, and surprisingly good
Verdict: But what you really give up with the Ezviz Mini is ease of use, along with bells and whistles. There's a learning curve to using the clunky app, since it it's so old-school and outdated. After using the Netatmo Welcome for a while, I grew to like its facial recognition feature which knew when I was home or away. I wish the Ezviz had something similar or another feature like the 90-decibel siren in Canary. But even lacking those features, the Ezviz Mini is an extremely useful, convenient, and affordable surveillance camera that is worth considering before you spend more than twice the amount of money on a fancier device.

Title: BlackBerry Priv review: Android fixes the OS, but the hardware can’t compete
Summary: $700 for a bad keyboard, poor camera, iffy build quality, and old software? No thanks.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: BlackBerry Priv
Verdict: From BlackBerry's perspective, the company is in

Title: Runtastic Moment Classic reviewed: refined style, strange subscription hurdles
Summary: The running app's new trackers are lovely, but you need to pay to use them fully.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: The Moment series contains stylish timepieces in a variety of styles and color options; there's something for everyone.
Cons: Many features are inaccessible if you don't have a Runtastic subscription, which is super annoying.
Product Name: Runtastic Moment Classic reviewed: refined style, strange subscription hurdles
Verdict: The Moment Series seems to be Runtastic's way of going after a new kind of customer—those who aren't hardcore runners or training for marathons, but rather those who just want to move more, look good doing it, and maybe eventually be sucked into running culture. If Fossil wasn't in the picture, the Moment watches would be the most affordable and stylish activity trackers available. But Fossil is big competition, as is Withings with its Activitè Pop. If you don't like the idea of paying for your historical step data, you probably won't be happy with Runtastic's subscription paywall. But if you're looking for a basic activity diary that comes in a fashionable package, the Moment series provides everything you need without the paid pro perks.

Title: iPad Pro review: Mac-like speed with all the virtues and restrictions of iOS
Summary: There's some promise here, but iOS makes this a very different kind of computer.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Excellent performance—the A9X is Apple's fastest chip by a big margin and the iPad Pro has double the RAM of any other iDevice.
Cons: Expensive, especially for a tablet, and
Product Name: iPad Pro
Verdict: For the rest of us, there's still the Mac.

Title: Mini-review: A week with Apple’s lumpy new iPhone battery case
Summary: Form follows function in one of Apple’s uglier accessories.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: iOS integration so you can actually see the battery case’s level from within the OS.
Cons: Too-grippy texture picks up dust, hair, and other grit and makes it hard to pocket the phone.
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: The best thing about the Smart Battery Case (aside from the extended battery life, which is always appreciated) is its integration within iOS. Adjusting iOS’ native battery indicator to give you some idea of the combined charge level of the case and internal battery would be great, but even so it’s nice to be able to see this information from within the OS rather than relying on colored LEDs. We’d like to see Apple extend that capability to third-party case makers. Until they do, OS integration and simplicity are the biggest points in this case’s favor.

Title: Mini-review: Asus’ Chromebit is somewhere between a Chromecast and a mini PC
Summary: 2GB of RAM hurts, but for $90 it's a decent productivity stick.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Inexpensive and pretty useful for what you get.
Cons: You'll probably lose the cap that covers the HDMI port.
Product Name: Mini-
Verdict: For anything more strenuous, the weak hardware is going to hold this thing back. Memory is the biggest limitation, and for any kind of moderate-to-heavy multitasking you'll see quite a bit of lagging—the GPU is weak, too, but gaming isn't exactly a core ChromeOS use case. It's hard to complain too much about the performance given the price, but it's definitely one of those cases where you get what you pay for.

Title: Lumia 950 review: Windows Phone finally has a new flagship—will anyone care?
Summary: Camera is great and Continuum is cool, but Windows Phone likely blew its last big chance.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: I only wish I could afford AMOLED monitors. I love the screen.
Cons: Continuum might not be the future.
Product Name: Lumia 950
Verdict: If the Lumia 950 were more keenly priced then it might be easier to get excited about it. Along with its bigger brother, it fills a glaring gap in the Lumia range and does

Title: Garmin’s Vivosmart HR reviewed: Don’t buy a Fitbit before considering this band
Summary: The $150 all-purpose tracker may not have Fitbit's modern exterior, but its internals are solid.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Smartphone notifications are discrete and comprehensive, letting you scroll to see full messages.
Cons: Syncing issues with old software—make sure to download Garmin Express and check if your device needs an update before using.
Product Name: Garmin’s Vivosmart HR reviewed: Don’t buy a Fitbit before considering this band
Verdict: The main thing holding the Vivosmart HR back is its design—it is pragmatic and utilitarian, but it doesn't have the slight chic factor you could get in a Fitbit. It's far from ugly, but it's not the prettiest device either. Also, compared to Fitbit's app, Garmin Connect is more confusing—partly because key settings aren't intuitive to find and partly because there are so many things you can customize that it can get overwhelming fast. Overall, the Vivosmart HR shows that Garmin is working to make trackers that are more mainstream, allowing anyone to go from regular daily tracking to more intense sport monitoring with just one device.

Title: Sensoria smart clothing reviewed: A ton of running data at your toe-tips
Summary: Can a pair of connected socks and a smart bra really up your running game?
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Both the smart socks and the smart sports bra are comfortable, despite having some technology built into them.
Cons: If you lose the proprietary charger for the anklets, you're basically out of luck.
Product Name: Sensoria smart clothing reviewed: A ton of running data at your toe-tips
Verdict: Overall, the smart socks are worth the investment for the right athletes that have specific goals in mind. But if you don't care about cadence or how often you land on your heel rather than the ball of your foot, Sensoria's socks become less useful. Depending on how highly you prioritize convenience, the smart sports bra could be worth your money. Though if you're willing bring an extra device with you to the gym, you could get a separate heart rate chest strap for half the price and get a "normal" sports bra that fits your body and style better. For some of the first pieces of smart clothing readily available, Sensoria's products make a good case to be potentially useful additions to your fitness routine—but like other pieces of smart clothing, that convenience currently comes at a steep price.

Title: Pebble Time Round reviewed: You can judge this book by its cover
Summary: Pebble's newest smartwatch is mostly different in design—and that's the point.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Sophisticated, ultra-thin design makes the Time Round the prettiest smartwatch Pebble has made yet.
Cons: Short battery life compared to existing Pebble devices.
