Title: Better wireless helps Intel’s new Compute Stick deliver on its potential
Summary: Review: Still a $159 niche PC, but at least it's a niche PC that works well.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Wireless performance is much better than the first model
Cons: Fan is a little annoying
Product Name: Better wireless helps Intel’s new Compute Stick deliver on its potential
Verdict: The Core M versions of the Compute Stick look more promising if you’re looking to replace an aging desktop tower with a nearly-invisible computer or turn a monitor into a functional all-in-one. This Atom Compute Stick mostly fulfills the potential of the first one, but that potential was pretty limited in the first place.

Title: HP Spectre x2 review: All the quality of the Surface Pro, hundreds of dollars less
Summary: Microsoft has defined a market. Now the other PC OEMs are getting in on the action.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Great keyboard
Cons: Core M may allow ditching the fan, but it's not winning us much battery life in return
Product Name: HP Spectre x2
Verdict: Put together, we have a machine with all the quality and flexibility of a Surface Pro 4, but quite a bit cheaper. If you really need the performance of the full strength processors (and the fan that comes along with the ride) you'll have to look elsewhere, but if you don't, the Spectre x2 will serve you very well indeed.

Title: Review: Asus’ excellent midrange laptop gets much better with Skylake
Summary: UX305C gives you Core m3, 8GB RAM, a 256GB SSD, and a 1080p IPS screen for $700.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good mix of features for the price.
Cons: No backlit keyboard.
Product Name: Review: Asus’ excellent midrange laptop gets much better with Skylake
Verdict: The UX305 remains merely a “good” laptop, but we need more good laptops to counterbalance the sub-$400 garbage and the over-$1,000 premium machines.

Title: Ars System Guide November 2015: Bargain Box
Summary: The most affordable system in the Ars Guides somehow makes the most—and least—sense.
Author: Brian Won
Product Name: Ars System Guide November 2015: Bargain Box
Verdict: A full discussion of what might be a DIY storage server is beyond the scope of the Bargain Box, particularly if you require ECC memory in your storage server. And in that case, you will need a different motherboard/CPU combo entirely.

Title: Dell XPS 13 review: Skylake and Thunderbolt 3 make the best a little bit better
Summary: Incremental updates make for incremental improvements.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Still a great size
Cons: Battery life feels like it should be better
Product Name: Dell XPS 13
Verdict: Well, that is unless you really need to use the webcam.

Title: OnePlus X Review: Not bad for $249, assuming you can actually buy one
Summary: A lame invite system puts a damper on a low price and great build quality.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: OnePlus X Review: Not bad for $249, assuming you can actually buy one
Verdict: With the OnePlus X, you're getting a good deal, but you're also getting what you pay for. It's pretty rare to get a decent smartphone for $249. The OnePlus X gives you a cheap price without constantly reminding you about it after the sale, and for that, we like it. It's just a shame it's so hard to purchase.

Title: Samsung’s Smartcam HD Plus is like a Nest Cam that’s not shackled to the cloud
Summary: Review: $190 camera stores video locally and lets you communicate with your home.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Sharp 1080p video recording, with the option to lower resolution to conserve storage.
Cons: Wider base than the Nest Cam, with frustrating power source port under the camera head.
Product Name: Samsung’s Smartcam HD Plus is like a Nest Cam that’s not shackled to the cloud
Verdict: In fact, the camera's reliance on local storage makes it more like the Ezviz Mini (which comes with a 16GB microSD card, as well as a cloud-storage option), even if the Ezviz is priced much more competitively at $70. On price alone, the Ezviz gives you everything you'd need to watch over your home, but the audio features and alarms of the Smartcam HD Plus are super tempting because of their convenience, ease of use, and security benefits. Overall, if you want a surveillance camera that lets you communicate with your home rather than just observing passively from behind your smartphone's display, the Smartcam HD Plus is worth the investment.

Title: Android on the desktop: Not really “good,” but better than you’d think
Summary: Surprisingly good mouse and keyboard support, but the interface can't scale.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Android on the desktop: Not really “good,” but better than you’d think
Verdict: Still, once you have full control over window sizes, phone apps on a desktop actually aren't that bad. Android tablets are bad because it takes tiny phone apps and stretches them out to a bigger screen, but in a windowed environment, if an app is better small, you can just let it be small, fill the screen with other tiny apps, and get things done. Still, Google will need to push itself and third-party developers if it wants to make Android a viable desktop OS. While Android tablet apps have never really happened, Google has used a much better strategy for Android's newer form factors. Android TV, Android Auto, and Android Wear all have custom-built apps that take advantage of the form factor.

Title: A review of the $10 Walmart phone—better than nothing, but not by much
Summary: We bought an LG Sunrise for the low, low price of $10. We regret it.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: A review of the $10 Walmart phone—better than nothing, but not by much
Verdict: Other than the screen issues, and it being very slow, it's a surprisingly functional little device. While it looks and feels like a toy replica of a phone, it can run just about any 2D app that serious phones can run. If you can snag one for $10, it's better than nothing. Maybe you could gut it or install some software and turn it into some kind of little project phone. And if you desperately need to get up and running with some Android software, it's hard to beat a price like this.

Title: Fossil Q Founder review: Bold, beautiful, but average with Android Wear
Summary: It's not stellar, but it could introduce Google's wearables to a wider audience.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Classic Fossil design yet it's universally attractive enough for anyone to find appealing.
Cons: No heart rate monitor, making it more limited than other Android Wear watches in terms of fitness.
Product Name: Fossil Q Founder
Verdict: Fossil didn't have to make the best Android Wear watch, nor does it have a responsibility to add unique features to Android Wear (though I do wish Fossil made more use of the Q smartphone app). Google will have to figure out ways to make its wearable OS more useful, an ongoing process that is out of Fossil's hands. What Fossil's Q Founder could do is present Android Wear to fashion-conscious buyers who otherwise wouldn't even consider a smartwatch. If that proves to be the case, it'll be good news for everyone involved: Android Wear will diversify even more with many stylish, unique hardware options, and other fashion companies will get into the game and start experimenting with smart accessories. But most importantly, people will realize that wearables aren't just for the most tech-conscious among us, and a new wave of users will help further define smartwatches' best and most needed features.

Title: Keyboards, OSes, pedals, and the other gadgets we liked most in 2015
Summary: The Ars reviews team takes stock after a busy year.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Keyboards, OSes, pedals, and the other gadgets we liked most in 2015
Verdict: The XPS 13 has been recently updated to include a Skylake processor and Thunderbolt 3, while retaining the same package and pretty screen. This brings an already great laptop right up to date. The only awkward spot? Its webcam is extremely awkwardly placed, pointing directly up your nose. If that doesn't bother you and you're after a conventional PC laptop, the XPS 13 is easily the one to beat.

Title: Pixel C review—New hardware ignores an Android tablet’s core problem: software
Summary: A "productivity" device that can only display a single app at a time?
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Pixel C review—New hardware ignores an Android tablet’s core problem: software
Verdict: The bottom line for every Android tablet is that until Google revamps its software to fully take advantage of the larger screen size, no Android tablet is worth your time.

Title: Got an old phone? Make it into a home security camera.
Summary: Apps let you turn that old iPhone into a home security camera, albeit with limits.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Product Name: Got an old phone? Make it into a home security camera.
Verdict: If you're just dabbling in smart home security, you may want to give one of the free apps a try to see if the features are worth the money for your home situation. You'll also find out if you crave extra utilities like alarms, local storage, or Internet of Things connectivity—in which case, a physical smart home security camera is worth the investment. The extra hardware might be extra money, but it gives you many options to expand your smart home ecosystem and have more control over your footage in the long run.

Title: Mini-review: tvOS 9.2 fixes all the Apple TV’s biggest problems
Summary: Text input and the home screen layout get most of the attention.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Mini-

Title: Nextbit Robin review: Novel hardware, absurd cloud storage
Summary: Nice hardware, but new OEM's cloud setup doesn't make sense when microSD cards exist.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A crazy, unique design that some people will like.
Cons: Nextbit wants you to install a lot of apps, but the launcher removes a lot of features that are useful when you have lots of apps. The app drawer is gone, app search is gone, and the app list displays seven apps in a text list instead of the 24 app icon view. It also removed the ability to mix app icons and widgets together. You'll want to quickly install a new launcher.
Product Name: Nextbit Robin
Verdict: While I'm not a fan of the cloud system, it's still really great to see a new smartphone OEM appear, create a product, and launch it. Nextbit seems like it can deliver solid hardware at a good price; it just needs to provide a more compelling reason to pick the company's offerings over the competition. It remains to be seen how this new OEM will handle software updates, support, and all the other post-launch trials it will have to go through. In any case, the smartphone market could definitely use some new ideas, so I'm happy to see some fresh blood. Welcome to the party Nextbit, we'll be watching you.

Title: Jaybird Reign fitness tracker review: Keeping you honest with heart rate variability
Summary: This $150 tracker tells you if you're actually ready for a hard workout.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Unique design that's comfortable and versatile; it comes with band extenders to get the best fit and a bike anklet to better track cycling.
Cons: Running and cycling carry more weight than other exercises and translate to more activity points than walking or other activities.
Product Name: Jaybird Reign fitness tracker
Verdict: Reign provides an alternative fitness tracker experience compared to the $150 Fitbit Charge HR, and one isn't necessarily better than the other. However, the Fitbit Charge HR is definitely more universal and will appeal to more customers—the Reign is for anyone who is constantly trying to be better and pushing themselves to the next level. Overall, Reign is a different kind of fitness tracker and it does what it does well, but you'll have to play by its rules to get the most out of it.

Title: Review: Sony’s Xperia Z5 Compact is the best small Android phone you can buy
Summary: If you hate big phones and don't mind last year's hardware, this one's for you.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Flagship performance in a smaller package.
Cons: Old Android, albeit with the promise of newer Android eventually.
Product Name: Review: Sony’s Xperia Z5 Compact is the best small Android phone you can buy
Verdict: The bottom line is that the Z5 Compact isn’t a

Title: Hexoskin smart shirt reviewed: Measuring your vitals so you don’t have to
Summary: But at $400, jumping on the smart clothing bandwagon is a big investment.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Hexoskin's tank fits comfortably and doesn't feel like you're wearing a piece of technology. And it's fully washable.
Cons: You can't set activity or workout goals.
Product Name: Hexoskin smart shirt reviewed: Measuring your vitals so you don’t have to
Verdict: Hexoskin is asking for a lot for a solid smart shirt and a partially unfinished app experience. Each adult Hexoskin pack is $399, which is no small investment for a first-generation product. If you're a newbie to exercise or someone who works out regularly but isn't necessarily worried about hardcore stats, you'd get more use and value from

Title: Review: Avegant Glyph delivers on “personal theater” promise
Summary: It’s a nice HDMI screen for your face—but it’s got one big problem.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: High build quality and solid design—it's clear a lot of care has been taken putting the device together
Cons: Priced like a first-gen product
Product Name: Review: Avegant Glyph delivers on “personal theater” promise
Verdict: If you want a nice personal theater device today and you don’t mind spending money, it’s probably an easy buy. If it were half the price, it’d be easy to recommend to anyone. But for now, unless you have the opportunity to try one for a few minutes and make sure it’s not going to get your inner ear upset, it might be best to wait.

Title: Fitbit Blaze reviewed: A totally unnecessary tracker with a few cool features
Summary: It's not a bad device, I just don't know why it exists.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Tracks activity and heart rate fairly accurately—it was never drastically off from my own measurements.
Cons: If you wear the Blaze, be ready for all the Apple Watch comments. Be ready to explain yourself.
Product Name: Fitbit Blaze reviewed: A totally unnecessary tracker with a few cool features
Verdict: However, the Charge HR is less bulky and the Surge has onboard GPS. They both automatically track workouts and they both have decent battery lives. As Fitbit (and similar companies) continue to diversify their tracker lineups, how you spend your money is going to come down to small details like being able to read a full text message, follow guided workouts, or use a built-in GPS. One thing is for sure—if you want a truly fashionable device, look elsewhere. Serious athletes who do any kind of running will want the Surge's onboard GPS, and those who can do without calendar alerts and text notifications they can't even answer can save $50 with the Charge HR. Who's left in between those two groups? I'm not entirely sure—but all of you out there have a new "smart fitness watch" made just for you.

Title: Samsung Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge review: The Galaxy S6 2.0
Summary: Samsung brings back water resistance and an SD card but shuns USB Type C.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: The curved sides on the back make the device a little more comfortable to hold.
Cons: Glass is still fragile. We'd prefer metal on the back.
Product Name: Samsung Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge
Verdict: The Galaxy S7's real strength will be its scale and marketing. The Galaxy S7 is going to be everywhere on TV and in every carrier and electronics store, and for that reason it will be successful. People that go and ask their local Verizon salesperson what to buy will be pointed to the Galaxy S7, but if you're comparing specs and features via reviews like this, the smartphone world has more to offer.

Title: Xiaomi Redmi 3 review: A $100 metal phone that crushes other $100 phones
Summary: It delivers specs that other OEMs struggle to match at twice the price.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: The price. For $100 you get a phone with better specs and build quality than some devices that are twice that price.
Cons: Slow updates. This has an Android 5.1 OS when Android 6.0 has been out for a few months now.
Product Name: Xiaomi Redmi 3
Verdict: Xiaomi has shown it can absolutely own the $100 phone segment if it wants to, with hardware that blows away the competition. It's just a shame we can't get it here.

Title: Review: Much-improved Iris GPU makes the Skylake NUC a major upgrade
Summary: Iris 540 gets 64MB of eDRAM, bringing big gains to low-power CPUs.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Cons: Still tiny. Still consumes relatively little power.
Product Name: Review: Much-improved Iris GPU makes the Skylake NUC a major upgrade
Verdict: If you're a current NUC owner looking to upgrade, the Skylake NUC is a particularly big leap from the first- or second-generation Ivy Bridge or Haswell NUCs. Memory, storage, and GPU speeds are all much increased, though you won’t notice the bump in processor performance very often. If you’re looking for a mini PC with more CPU power, you’ll want to wait for the high-end quad-core Iris Pro NUC that’s coming later in the year.

Title: 9.7-inch iPad Pro review: What makes something “Pro” anyway?
Summary: The smaller Pro straddles the line between the 12.9-inch version and the Air 2.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Great performance. The A9X is still a fast chip, and it’s a big upgrade over the A8X in some important ways.
Cons: Smart Keyboard is more cramped, which makes typing more frustrating.
Product Name: 9.7-inch iPad Pro
Verdict: And if you’re choosing between this tablet and the 12.9-inch iPad Pro, compare Apple’s iPad lineup to the current MacBook Air and Pro lineups. The 12.9-inch iPad, like the 15-inch MacBook, is larger and more capable than its 13-inch sibling. The 9.7-inch iPad, like the 13-inch MacBook, shares a few features in common with its larger sibling but also overlaps with the iPad Air 2, just as the 13-inch MacBook Pro overlaps with the 13-inch Air. The iPad Mini and the 11-inch MacBook Airs both sit at the bottom of the range, waiting for people who want the cheapest product possible or people who just know that they prefer small screens and have modest needs.

Title: Polar A360 reviewed: Another fitness tracker with smartwatch envy
Summary: The $199 tracker is the first with Polar's own wrist-bound heart rate monitor.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Customizable design with interchangeable bands.
Cons: Cannot read full smartphone notifications on the display.
Product Name: Polar A360 reviewed: Another fitness tracker with smartwatch envy
Verdict: All that being said, the A360 is a fine product, but if you're primarily looking for a fitness tracker that can track multiple workouts and deliver smartphone alerts, the Garmin Vívosmart HR is the better option for a lower price.

Title: Sorry, Everyone: The iPhone SE is an apology to big-phone haters everywhere
Summary: Review: There’s not much that’s “new,” but that’s not what this phone is about.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A familiar design that is compatible with current accessories and still feels great to hold and carry around.
Cons: Storage maxes out at 64GB while the bigger models offer 128GB.
Product Name: Sorry, Everyone: The iPhone SE is an apology to big-phone haters everywhere
Verdict: Ultimately, most people should still buy an iPhone 6S or 6S Plus before an iPhone SE, assuming money is no object or the full cost of your phone is being masked by some kind of carrier subsidy or payment plan. The 6S is a good sweet spot, offering a larger screen without being as unwieldy as the 6S Plus. By contrast, the SE is a great option for people who just don’t want to deal with something bigger. The flagships are likely to remain larger, and they’re likely to get new features faster (I wouldn’t be surprised in the least if the 4-inch iPhone only got a refresh once every two years or so), but the SE at least makes it so that people who prefer small phones don’t need to time travel back to 2013 to get a decent one.

Title: Xiaomi Mi 5 review: It’s hard to argue with $305 for a Snapdragon 820
Summary: Xiaomi's software needs a serious upgrade, though.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A Snapdragon 820 for an amazing $305.
Cons: Broken permissions system allows some apps to slip through without user consent.
Product Name: Xiaomi Mi 5
Verdict: For the majority of our readers, this Mi 5 isn't an option. It probably isn't sold in your country, and even if you import it, it doesn't have the right LTE bands to get a serious data connection. Xiaomi could easily make a Mi 5 that works internationally. This is looking more and more likely, judging by the company's appearance at the Mobile World Congress, its international

Title: Review: Garmin’s Vivoactive HR is more hardcore than Fitbit’s Surge
Summary: $250 tracker sits right in the middle of Garmin's convoluted lineup.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Chroma display is easy to read in sunlight.
Cons: Garmin Connect has a lot of information and options which can make navigating it and completing simply tasks confusing.
Product Name: Review: Garmin’s Vivoactive HR is more hardcore than Fitbit’s Surge
Verdict: In comparison to the $250 Microsoft Band, the Vivoactive HR lacks any coaching features or guided workouts. If that's more your style, you'd get more use out of Microsoft's device. Finally, Garmin's own $230 Vivosmart HR+ is best suited for anyone who wants a smaller device (with no chroma touchscreen) and can live with fewer sports profiles. But for anyone who goes back and forth between numerous sports and needs a tracker that can keep up with them, the Vivoactive HR will do the trick.

Title: Ubiquiti’s 8-port POE switch is a solid complement for a home Unifi setup
Summary: Fanless $199 managed device drives Unifi Wi-Fi gear—if you can find it in stock.
Author: Lee Hutchinson
Pros: Competitive price for an 8-port managed POE switch
Cons: No rack-mount option
Product Name: Ubiquiti’s 8-port POE switch is a solid complement for a home Unifi setup
Verdict: But if you can grab one, it’s a solid switch that meshes well with the Unifi ecosystem. If you’ve got Unifi APs in your home, this is probably what you should plug them into.

Title: HTC 10 review: HTC builds the best Android flagship of 2016
Summary: No gimmicks, no nonsense—HTC keeps it simple and builds an awesome smartphone.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A premium metal body without any silly coatings.
Cons: No always-on voice support.
Product Name: HTC 10
Verdict: The HTC 10 is a refreshing phone that manages to be great without any nonsense or gimmicks. Compared to the Galaxy S7, you're getting a better body, better software, louder speakers, more capable expandable storage, USB Type C, and (most of the time) a better camera. Force me to buy a phone that isn't a Nexus device and I know what I'm picking up.

Title: HP’s upsized 15-inch Spectre x360—a high quality device built for the mainstream
Summary: HP hits enlarge on its very pleasant 13-inch systems.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: Great build.
Cons: No Thunderbolt 3.
Product Name: HP’s upsized 15-inch Spectre x360—a high quality device built for the mainstream
Verdict: Even if you bump the Spectre up to have its top processor with the Iris graphics, 16GB RAM, the 4K screen, and 512GB SSD, the HP is only $1689.99. That feels very competitive for such a nicely put together system.

Title: Sony Xperia X Compact review: Small Android is still good, but not much better
Summary: Aside from camera tricks, the $499 handset is a slightly sub-par Z5 Compact.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Compact size is ideal for those who prefer smaller handsets.
Cons: Plastic material holds onto fingerprints, making the handset look dirty.
Product Name: Sony Xperia X Compact
Verdict: The X Compact is Sony's way of bringing a small handset into its new line of smartphones and is a way for it to bring its advanced camera experience to a compact device. It's a decent handset for those who want a solid Android device with a smaller footprint and also require the flexibility of full photo and video controls. But if you're not interested in the new photo perks, the Z5 Compact is the better option, as it has a longer battery life, a faster processor, and a more durable design. Also, now that the Z5 Compact has been on the market for a while, you can usually get it for less than an X Compact (around $400, as of this writing).

Title: Zotac Zbox EN1060 review: Better than console gaming in a tiny package
Summary: But don't expect the same performance as a full-size Nvidia GTX 1060.
Author: Mark Walton
Pros: Compact design that's smaller than a games console
Cons: GTX 1060 struggles to hit rated boost clock, and is slower than the desktop version
Product Name: Zotac Zbox EN1060

Title: LG G5 review: An interesting idea, shoddily executed
Summary: Fit and finish problems mar an otherwise promising phone.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: A removable battery!
Cons: The bottom release mechanism just isn't good enough. It holds the bottom part on unevenly, and on one side is so loose you can see through it.
Product Name: LG G5
Verdict: We hope LG keeps trying though. Too many smartphone manufacturers seem to think the smartphone is a finished product, and they're content to only push out spec bumps every year. So please, LG, keep trying new things—just don't forget about the basics next year.

Title: Lenovo ThinkPad X1 reviewed: a hybrid for the workaholics among us
Summary: With three attachable modules, this 2-in-1 has versatility on its side.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Lightweight and easily portable.
Cons: Keyboard combined with magnetic hinge makes the entire device, as a laptop replacement, feel flimsy.
Product Name: Lenovo ThinkPad X1 reviewed: a hybrid for the workaholics among us
Verdict: Still, the modules are the true selling points for the X1 since they add unique value to the tablet. No similarly priced MacBook Pro, Surface Book, or Surface Pro can act as a projector or 3D scanner, and adding five hours to the already great battery life of the X1 would put it ahead of its peers. If any of those modules catch your eye, you'd want to consider the X1 as a new primary work device. But if you prefer a more traditional design and you don't need your tablet to turn into a projector or scanner, you'll fare better with a device like the Surface Book.

Title: OWC’s Aura SSDs are a good way to add storage to newer MacBooks, with caveats [Updated]
Summary: Mini-review: SSDs have few drawbacks, but incompatibility with Boot Camp is one.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Adds a whole bunch of storage to Macs that typically aren’t very upgradeable.
Cons: Costly compared to standard SATA and M.2 PCIe drives.
Product Name: OWC’s Aura SSDs are a good way to add storage to newer MacBooks, with caveats [Updated]
Verdict: Overall, though, this is the best and most seamless way to add storage to a newer Mac. The drives are considerably more expensive than standard SATA or M.2 PCI Express SSDs on the market, but that’s the price you pay using a proprietary connector. OWC’s upgrade kit is well worth the $50, both because it gives you the tools you need and because it lets you re-use your old SSD as a slick external hard drive. I wish Apple would prioritize repairability and upgradeability in at least some of its Macs, but short of that dream becoming reality, the OWC Aura SSD is the best you could hope for.

Title: Review: Misfit’s Ray is a subtle, stylish fitness bracelet
Summary: The $99 tracker covers all the basics, but look elsewhere for extra perks.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Understated design that blends in with other watches and wrist jewelry
Cons: Doesn't have a display, so it can't double as a watch
Product Name: Review: Misfit’s Ray is a subtle, stylish fitness bracelet
Verdict: Aside from Fossil's own Q smart bracelets, the Misfit Ray is the closest you'll get to an affordable, fashionable accessory that is also a solid fitness tracker. If you want extra fitness features, especially heart rate monitoring and GPS, you'll definitely have to look elsewhere. But for those looking to add a smart fitness device to the collection of wrist accessories they wear every day, the Ray is a solid option.

Title: Mio Fuse reviewed: A fitness band that works better than it looks
Summary: Sure you could wear it all day long, but the Fuse doesn't shine 24/7.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Comfortable, adjustable design.
Cons: Does not have customizable alarms or receive smartphone alerts.
Product Name: Mio Fuse reviewed: A fitness band that works better than it looks
Verdict: Could you wear it all day long? Absolutely. Would I recommend it? Probably not. There are plenty of other trackers that provide a better all-day activity monitoring experience. The Fuse is at its best when you're sweating bullets on your morning bike ride with your heart pumping at 170 bpm, and that's reflected in Mio Go's detailed heart rate analysis and in the device's overall performance.

Title: A year with the Apple Watch: What works, what doesn’t, and what lies ahead?
Summary: Some features are more useful than others, and there's lots of room to improve.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: A year with the Apple Watch: What works, what doesn’t, and what lies ahead?
Verdict: The iPod and iPhone weren’t overnight successes. They took a few years to ramp up into mass-market moneymakers, and Apple spent those years iterating on the hardware and software, revising constantly until all the rough first-generation edges were smoothed away. The Apple Watch as it exists is still rough and limited in a lot of ways, but hopefully another year or two of improvements will help it realize its full potential.

Title: Review: $699 is a lot to ask for the fairly basic Sony Xperia X Performance
Summary: Even with impressive specs, there's something lacking in the X Performance.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Elegant glass and brushed metal design.
Cons: Overall performance isn't up to par with the OnePlus 3.
Product Name: Review: $699 is a lot to ask for the fairly basic Sony Xperia X Performance

Title: Review: The 2016 Retina MacBook is a faster version of the same machine
Summary: Improved CPUs, GPUs, and SSDs are all welcome, but the core compromises remain.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Better CPU and GPU performance than last year, if just by a bit. The upgrade path from a 2010 or 2011-era MacBook Air is much clearer now, at any rate.
Cons: 480p webcam is still low-res and ugly.
Product Name: Review: The 2016 Retina MacBook is a faster version of the same machine
Verdict: Evaluated on its own terms separately from the complaints of power users, the MacBook is a fine ultraportable laptop. The new model improves on the old one in the ways that will matter most to people who are currently using an 11- or 13-inch MacBook Air (or something older) and want to step down to something thinner, lighter, and quieter. If you mostly use your laptop as a

Title: Blink review: Two cameras are almost always better than one
Summary: Why spend $200 on one camera when you can get two for $170?
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Compact design with an easy setup.
Cons: Clips are limited to 10 seconds, and there are a few seconds of lag time between recorded clips.
Product Name: Blink
Verdict: While those oversights are frustrating, none of them impedes the Blink system from doing what it's made to do: capture footage of your home when you need it most. My Blink consistently and accurately detected motion (and continuously captured it when it went over 10 seconds) in my home, recorded incidents with decent video quality, and made it easy for me to save any clips I wanted. At their core, that's what all good home security cameras should do. If Blink refined its app and added a few extra software features, the system would be killer rather than just a solid, affordable option.

Title: The XPS 13 DE: Dell continues to build a reliable Linux lineage
Summary: You'll pay a premium for Linux out of the box and a great screen—for some, it's worth it.
Author: Scott Gilbertson
Product Name: The XPS 13 DE: Dell continues to build a reliable Linux lineage
Verdict: And that is probably the best thing about the XPS 13 Developer Edition. It works so well that it's really no different from the experience anyone would have with a Windows machine. Well, there is only one difference of course—no Windows.

Title: The macOS Sierra developer preview: Different name, same ol’ Mac
Summary: Siri ushers in a range of updates that refine but don't transform the Mac.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: The macOS Sierra developer p
Verdict: It has been a long time since the Mac was Apple's favorite child, and there are places in Sierra like the Messages app where it clearly feels like Mac users are getting a second-tier experience compared to people on iOS. But the Mac feels like it has settled into a quiet and reliable groove, a groove that Sierra is happy to trundle along in. The name has changed, but otherwise it's business as usual for

Title: OnePlus 3 review: A great $400 phone you can actually buy
Summary: With the death of the invite system, OnePlus is finally worth your consideration.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: $399 for a 64GB phone is a fantastic price.
Cons: 6GB of RAM with a 20 app limit is pretty pointless out of the box. Customers will need to root the device to take full advantage of the hardware.
Product Name: OnePlus 3
Verdict: The software is great—it's respectful of the Android design language while still adding a few features here and there. This is an approach we wish more OEMs would follow. The one downside to the software is that OnePlus hasn't been very swift when it comes to updating its devices. But even with that potential pitfall, the OnePlus 3 represents a great deal for $400, especially if you plan to root it and fix the memory issues.

Title: Moto Z review: Lenovo brings a huge price increase, lame modular system
Summary: The first Moto flagship under Lenovo's rule isn't a compelling one.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Moto Z
Verdict: Motorola has gone from one of the best OEMs under Google to just another face in a sea of competitors under Lenovo. The "bang for your buck" concept is gone, at least at the high end. Motorola has left us with $600 and $700 devices that will have to do battle with the Galaxy S7s and iPhones of the world. It's not a battle I think Motorola can win.

Title: Intel’s Core M Compute Stick is an actually usable computer with caveats
Summary: Mini-review: $380 stick bridges the gap between the Atom sticks and the NUC.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A decent multipurpose PC in a tiny package.
Cons: Core m3 in a small stick is slower than it is in a laptop.
Product Name: Intel’s Core M Compute Stick is an actually usable computer with caveats
Verdict: In essence, the improved performance of this Compute Stick expands its potential, but the higher price tag is going to keep it stuck in a niche. But it’s still pretty interesting, and a slightly cooler and quieter and cheaper version of this stick a year or two down the line could be a tempting prospect.

Title: iOS 10 preview: Apple goes back to ignoring the iPad in a wide-ranging update
Summary: iOS 10 gives developers plenty to do and lets its users have a little fun, too.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 10 p
Verdict: There are more new features in iOS 10—improvements to core apps like Photos, Music, and Health, tweaks to how the keyboard works, Apple Pay on the web, and a bunch of other minor changes—that we'll have more time to look at in our final review. But so far the majority of the changes are for the better. Old hardware is getting dropped, but that frees developers from worrying about actively supported devices with 512MB of RAM. The iPad isn't getting nearly the amount of love that it got from iOS 9, but in recent years Apple has been happy to dole out feature updates throughout the year in large point releases

Title: Lumo Run reviewed: Messing up your form? This running coach can fix that.
Summary: You run regularly, but are you running correctly?
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Compact design that doesn't move when you're running.
Cons: Module is difficult to slip into the very snug clip.
Product Name: Lumo Run reviewed: Messing up your form? This running coach can fix that.
Verdict: As a device, Lumo Run is well-made, simple to use, and easy to wear while running for a long time. Its companion app is thorough in its analysis of your form. While the voice coach can get a little annoying and the device can be hard to fit into its clip, those are minor issues that are easy to live with if you're looking for a device that could actually make a lasting change in how you run. But those who dabble in many sports will get more use out of the $79 Moov Now—it's cheaper than the Lumo Run and isn't limited to just run coaching.

Title: Review: A $60 Amazon phone that’s way better than Amazon’s actual phone
Summary: Selling your lock screen to Amazon cuts this cheap phone's price in half.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: Review: A $60 Amazon phone that’s way better than Amazon’s actual phone
Verdict: The Amazon ads feel skeezy in part because they take something that’s usually personal (lock screen photos, in my experience, are almost universally of treasured people or pets or locations) and turn it into a billboard for men’s deodorant. But the ads don’t

Title: Review: Without quick updates the Moto G4 is merely good, not great
Summary: $200 starting price, OK specs, and fingerprint sensor are still a solid value.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Solid, no-fuss design and build quality.
Cons: Appears to break Google's rules about on-by-default storage encryption.
Product Name: Review: Without quick updates the Moto G4 is merely good, not great
Verdict: The G4 is still a really solid budget smartphone. But I can't recommend it as loudly or as happily as I could recommend the original Moto G, nor is it the cheapest decent phone you can buy. Consumers could do worse, but Lenovo could do better.

Title: Review: Asus’ $700 Zenbook Flip isn’t quite worthy of the laptop it replaces
Summary: Trackpad woes and a lesser screen ruin one of the best midrange laptops.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Good specs for the price.
Cons: Air gap between the glass and LCD panel introduces glare, reduces contrast, and makes colors look more washed out.
Product Name: Review: Asus’ $700 Zenbook Flip isn’t quite worthy of the laptop it replaces
Verdict: Much more frustrating is the trackpad, which makes the laptop irritating to use when it’s on anything other than a flat, firm surface. It’s a great big usability flaw that crosses the line between “intentional compromise” and “unintentional flaw,” and even though the price and specs are still right, the trackpad makes it a difficult laptop to actually recommend.

Title: The connected renter: How to make your apartment smarter
Summary: Turning your rented space into a smart home can be tricky; we have some advice.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Product Name: The connected renter: How to make your apartment smarter
Verdict: Particularly if you hope to upgrade each and every room, outfitting your apartment with smart home devices is a big endeavor (and an even bigger expense). The devices we’ve vetted are merely a fraction of what’s out there, and any interested DIY renovators should take time to look around your place and decide where money can be best spent. It's also worth considering a few decision points we’ve covered elsewhere on Ars but avoided in this overview. Many smart devices fit squarely into the Internet of Things (IoT) territory, meaning potential security vulnerabilities open up. And since these are goods you may own that work within an apartment you don’t, thinking through the future can be vital. How easy will it be for you to take those devices from your smart apartment to another apartment or even a new home? With most devices, the transition will be fairly easy (especially if you, like me, stay away from anything that needs hardwiring into walls). Simply put, the modern-day decision to move toward a smart home or apartment is something you need to be, well,

Title: Android 7.0 Nougat review—Do more on your gigantic smartphone
Summary: Big smartphones are everywhere, and Nougat's new features make them more useful.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Android 7.0 Nougat review—Do more on your gigantic smartphone
Verdict: End-of-the-year Android "launches" rarely come at a single point, instead they feel more like a rolling month-or-so of continual releases. So with the release of a new base OS, we're seeing about half of this year's changes. A lot more is still to come.

Title: iPhone 7 and 7 Plus review: Great annual upgrades with one major catch
Summary: In-depth with the new phones, the AirPods, A10 Fusion, the cameras, and more.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: A10 Fusion and everything else in the phone is super fast.
Cons: Same basic design with the same basic quirks as the 6 and 6S, including the camera bump, the rounded slippery corners, and large width and height relative to the size of their screens.
Product Name: iPhone 7 and 7 Plus
Verdict: If you understand things best when they’re phrased as tired idioms: the missing headphone jack is a fly in the iPhone 7’s ointment. Plenty of people will be happy to scoop out the fly and use the rest of the probably-fine ointment. It’s good ointment! There’s just a fly in it. And the transition from wired to wireless is going to be more painful now than it will be a year or two down the line when more accessories and devices have adapted to follow Apple’s lead. Waterproofing and better battery life have been common iPhone feature requests for years, and the camera and speed improvements are nothing to sneeze at, but you’ll need to buy into Apple’s vision of the future if you want to get them.

Title: Caught in the act: How and why you should invest in a dash cam
Summary: You may never use it, but when you have to, it could be a life-saver.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Product Name: Caught in the act: How and why you should invest in a dash cam
Verdict: And if you really don't want to spend a ton on a dash cam, Polaroid's device will suit you well. It may not have the sharpest video or be the most elegantly designed, but it comes packed with all the essential features every dash cam needs while not breaking the bank at $60. Compared to dash cam apps, even the low-level dedicated device provides enough functionality to justify the upgrade.

Title: Galaxy Note 7 review: What’s the opposite of “bang for your buck?”
Summary: Samsung's latest offers the best of 2016 technology but with a 2013 price tag.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Product Name: Galaxy Note 7
Verdict: When you can already get a great phone with the best specs for $400, a $700 price point gets a lot harder to justify. There's no room for excuses or compromises. As the most expensive phone, the Galaxy Note 7 also needs to be the best phone. It isn't.

Title: iOS 10 reviewed: There’s no reason not to update
Summary: Apple puts together a comprehensive update with some smart app redesigns.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 10 reviewed: There’s no reason not to update
Verdict: All in all, though, iOS 10 is a good update with a lot to offer and there’s really no reason not to install it on any hardware that can run it. It doesn’t murder your battery, it doesn’t hurt performance too badly. It takes up more storage space, but that’s been a fact of life for every iOS update for years now. I’ve been running it on my actual production iPhone and iPad for the last month and a half, and the GM build seems stable. App updates are already rolling out. There really isn’t much of a downside.

Title: Fedora 24 review: The year’s best Linux distro is puzzlingly hard to recommend
Summary: Even for a great update, rollout trouble reminds us release cycles can mar a distro.
Author: Scott Gilbertson
Product Name: Fedora 24
Verdict: If you're OK with the frequency of Fedora updates and want a release-oriented distro, I would not hesitate to recommend Fedora 24. Even with a couple of issues, it's leaps and bounds beyond anything else I've tested this year, including Ubuntu 16.04 and Mint 18. Just make sure you take it for a test drive before you jump in with both feet.

Title: Fitbit Charge 2 reviewed: A calculated update that’s ideal for new users
Summary: At $150, the Charge 2 replaces the Charge HR as the best-value Fitbit device.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Larger display shows more information so you don't have to open the app as often
Cons: Only supports connected GPS, so keep your phone with you if you need maps
Product Name: Fitbit Charge 2 reviewed: A calculated update that’s ideal for new users
Verdict: The Charge 2's biggest competition is Garmin's Vivosmart HR, which is a more comprehensive device in that it can receive all of your smartphone's notifications, not just call, text, and calendar updates. It's also water-resistant up to 50 meters (which isn't for swim tracking, but more for peace of mind that it can survive a dunk in the sink). The upper hand that the Charge 2 has, though, is its auto-tracking feature. The Vivosmart HR doesn't automatically track running, walking, or biking activities, and if you want a device you can just put on and forget about when you're doing the most basic exercises, the Charge 2 is the better device.

Title: macOS 10.12 Sierra: The Ars Technica review
Summary: Apple's desktop operating system once again plays second fiddle to iOS.
Author: Andrew Cunningham and Lee Hutchinson
Product Name: macOS 10.12 Sierra: The Ars Technica review
Verdict: Sierra is fine software, but after a couple years of parity, it again feels as though it’s taking a backseat to iOS, primarily because of its half-hearted implementations of major new iOS features like Messages and Siri. The Mac is still a fundamentally stable, solid, usable platform, but its hardware is no longer running circles around the rest of the PC industry. Apple could be doing more—let's hope some of these long-rumored refreshes arrive sooner rather than later.

Title: HP Spectre x360 15 review: A large convertible that’s easy to love
Summary: Flexibility is usually left to smaller devices, but this one’s up to the challenge.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Premium design.
Cons: Too heavy to be a good portable laptop.
Product Name: HP Spectre x360 15
Verdict: However, those looking for a lighter device will always prefer the 13-inch Spectre x360 or even the

Title: HP Omen 17: An affordable gaming-caliber laptop almost worth buying
Summary: You have to make compromises to get to this price point, but HP makes too many.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: Incredible gaming performance in a laptop.
Cons: Plastic keyboard coating hurts after extended use—and picks up too many smudges.
Product Name: HP Omen 17: An affordable gaming-caliber laptop almost worth buying
Verdict: : Avoid.

Title: Review: The still optional but pleasantly refined Apple Watch Series 2
Summary: Hardware perks and watchOS 3 fixes bring it one step closer to finding purpose in life.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Accurate workout tracking.
Cons: No auto-tracking activity feature.
Product Name: Review: The still optional but pleasantly refined Apple Watch Series 2
Verdict: Overall, using the Series 2 as a fitness device is a great experience with very few hiccups. Apple has come closer to defining the practical value of the smartwatch with the Series 2 and watchOS 3, but I still need some convincing. The watch continues to feel non-essential when compared to Apple products like the obviously essential iPhone, and for now that will keep it in a relatively small niche.

Title: Huawei Mate 9 review: A big phone with enough battery
Summary: We still don't like Emotion UI, but at least the €699 handset itself is good.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Pros: Good overall performance.
Cons: Lots of crapware that you can't delete.
Product Name: Huawei Mate 9
Verdict: I also wish the camera performed better in low-light situations, but it does have a lot of other redeeming qualities, especially if you like manipulating photos before and after you take them. My main concerns now lie with the uncertainty of the Mate 9's availability in the US—we know it's coming, we just don't know when or how much it will cost. Huawei told me that information will be available in the next few months. We do know it will cost €699 overseas, which would put it around the $750 mark in the US. If that's the case, anyone as dissatisfied with Emotion UI as we are would be better off with a Google Pixel, and anyone looking for a cheaper phone would do well to look at the OnePlus 3 or 3T instead. The Mate 9's battery life is great, but it's really the only way in which the phone distinguishes itself from the crowd.

Title: Resident Evil 7 review: A new perspective, an old house, and a return to terror
Summary: First-person mode and (optional) VR are rad, but new emphasis on Evil wins out.
Author: Sam Machkovech
Pros: I will bring up
Cons: Plenty of ugly, last-gen visual effects stand out
Product Name: Resident Evil 7

Title: Yakuza 0 review: All aboard the crazy train
Summary: If you bowl well enough you win a live chicken!
Author: Steven Strom
Pros: An absurd world with equally bonkers characters.
Cons: The main campaign is slightly tame for a
Product Name: Yakuza 0

Title: Hear the pulse: Heart rate monitoring fitness earbuds tested
Summary: Accuracy can be spotty, but some of these fitness buds are worth checking out.
Author: Valentina Palladino
Product Name: Hear the pulse: Heart rate monitoring fitness earbuds tested
Verdict: This is where the user comes in. While audio manufacturers can use the best heart rate monitors in their products and give you a plethora of ear wings and tips to choose from, you have to do the work to get the best fit with the earbuds you buy. You'll also have to resist fiddling with the earbuds during a workout, which can be difficult since I tend to do that myself. But the better the fit and the less movement they are subjected to, the more accurate earbud trackers will be. Maybe by the end of 2017 we'll see some earbud trackers performing just as well, if not better, than traditional fitness trackers.

Title: Kingdom Hearts HD 2.8 Final Chapter Prologue review: As messy as its title
Summary: Still just marking time until we actually get Kingdom Hearts 3.
Author: Steven Strom
Pros: Measured strictly by volume, there’s a lot of
Cons: It’s a very muddled collection
Product Name: Kingdom Hearts HD 2.8 Final Chapter Prologue
Verdict: The slight amount of new content will only appeal to hardcore fans or those who desperately want to play

Title: Review: Dell’s Kaby Lake XPS 13 isn’t quite good enough to keep its crown
Summary: Dell's popular Ultrabook isn't much changed for Kaby Lake, and that's a problem.
Author: Peter Bright
Pros: The soft touch interior really is better than bare metal
Cons: No biometric support
Product Name: Review: Dell’s Kaby Lake XPS 13 isn’t quite good enough to keep its crown
Verdict: As with the Skylake system, the price range is also pretty striking: the cheapest system, at $800, with its i3 processor and 4GB RAM (in 2016!), feels a little underpowered. The top-end system (with an i7, 16GB RAM, and a 1TB SSD), by contrast, feels quite overpriced at $2,250.

Title: Review: The AirPods are fine wireless headphones for a certain type of person
Summary: If you're way into Apple, your EarPods fit, and you have expendable cash, welcome.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Really sturdy and hard to damage by accident.
Cons: Sorta dorky looking, though dorkiness is in the eye of the beholder, and this may fade as they become normalized.
Product Name: Review: The AirPods are fine wireless headphones for a certain type of person
Verdict: The AirPods are pretty good wireless headphones for a specific sort of person. You need to like Apple’s EarPod design and be OK with the way they sound and fit in your ear—the audio quality in the AirPods is noticeably better, but it’s not night-and-day. To get the most out of them, you’ll want to be embedded deeply into Apple’s ecosystem, since only Apple devices can seamlessly pair with the headphones. And you’ll need to have plenty of money—enough to spend $159 on these in the first place, and enough to spend $69 replacing individual AirPods or $49 replacing their batteries when they are inevitably lost or degraded. The pairing and charging experience is better than standard Bluetooth headphones, but once you’re using the AirPods, they aren’t all that different.

Title: Review: Acer’s attempt at high-quality Ultrabook isn’t quite good enough
Summary: $1,099 Acer Swift 7 is outdone by competing laptops from HP and Dell.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Pros: Well-built laptop with a fine (if not record-breaking) 1080p screen.
Cons: No touchscreen.
Product Name: Review: Acer’s attempt at high-quality Ultrabook isn’t quite good enough
Verdict: Acer has made a pretty good laptop, all things considered. But you can get a Dell XPS 13 or HP Spectre x360 for the same amount of money or less, and those laptops are superior in just about every way (save for fanlessness).

Title: Torment: Tides of Numenera review: Mind reading
Summary: Planescape-inspired title is fun to read, if not always fun to play.
Author: Steven Strom
Pros: The hodgepodge fantasy world is nearly always interesting
Cons: Succeeding at chosen tasks becomes almost unfairly easy in the latter half
Product Name: Torment: Tides of Numenera

Title: Nvidia GTX 1080 Ti review: The fastest graphics card, again
Summary: If you're interested in viable 4K gaming, then open up your wallet and buy one.
Author: Mark Walton
Product Name: Nvidia GTX 1080 Ti
Verdict: The rest of us can sleep soundly in the knowledge that today's high-end is tomorrow's mid-range. Roll on GTX 1170.

Title: LG Watch Sport review: Google’s bulky watch breaks free from the smartphone
Summary: First Android Wear 2.0 device takes the smartwatch platform in a new direction.
Author: Ron Amadeo
Pros: The machine learning powered QWERTY keyboard is fantastic. It quickly, easily, and silently inputs text into a smartwatch, adding a ton of great use cases.
Cons: This is not a fast device. Loading anything is a laborious task. Random slowdowns happen occasionally.
Product Name: LG Watch Sport
Verdict: Overall the LG Watch Sport and Wear 2.0 feel like a promising reboot of the smartwatch. If you've complained in the past that a smartwatch isn't very useful, the package here offers a significant amount of stand-alone functionality. If you have any situations where leaving your smartphone at home or in a bag sounds like an attractive proposition, you might have a real use case for Wear 2.0

Title: iOS 11, thoroughly reviewed
Summary: Wide-ranging update is full of changes, but iPad benefits the most.
Author: Andrew Cunningham
Product Name: iOS 11, thoroughly reviewed
Verdict: In the here-and-now, iOS 11 is a great update for anyone with an iPad Air 2 or newer and a pretty good update for everyone else. You’re bound to find at least one or two things in here to like, and little stuff like automated Wi-Fi password sharing or screen-sharing are going to get used by regular people over and over again.
